full_transcript: new decks hi everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd and going to do a quick track video here talking about a few songs that I would love for you to check out especially the new single came out a few days ago blogged about it on the website and it has been growing on me ever since if you don't know MGMT they're in new york-based psychedelic pop and rock outfits some electronic and indie tronic and very catchy poppy singles in their early discography but it seems as they have released more material they've been getting stranger and stranger but I like seeing the duo go into more adventurous territory and that seems to be the case with the few songs that have dropped from this new falling fell pew so far we have the song alien days very textured but not a ton of replay value for me however with this new track even though it is kind of repetitive the title being your life is a lie with kind of a broken record guitar riff some very repetitive vocal phrasing but it's a very kind of silly playful absurd short and earworm kind of track not only do the lyrics have this kind of tongue-in-cheek existentialism to them that I like a lot but the music video is awesome and features Henry Winkler for a few seconds also while we're here experimental electronic music producer food-man has a new album out a new collection of tracks that I would love for you to check out this and more link down in the description box as well as a really fantastically long vivid and heavy piece of drone metal from Northumbria young father's experimental Scottish hip hop trio has a new track out that is being featured on my friends of friends compilation the song effigy and also an album down there from Jung booth they have put out an LP a new full-length LP that features some really fast heavy aggressive and melodic post-hardcore and scream oh okay cool Anthony Fantana tracks new MGMT you

tec-9 something else hi everyone MP Fantana here internets busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new tech 9 album something else tech 9 Kansas City rapper been at rap music for a few decades now and if you're the kind of person that analyzes rap music as a game as an industry and I know there are a lot of people who do tech 9 is a pretty interesting figure since the late 90s and early 2000s he's been making hardcore hip-hop with a slight slight horrorcore edge and his alternative lyrical topics and his alternative style and get up when he would do live shows or take promo pictures sort of set him in this outcast light and a lot of this guy's old outfits and get ups when he would perform live actually had him looking a lot like hip hop's answer to nu metal which is not that far of a comparison when you consider the fact that System of a Down Serj Tankian is actually one of the vocal guests on this album so there are some new metal and some rat metal vibes too coming through on tech nines music in general and this album too but the fact that he's dabbling in this genre that a lot of people consider to be kind of on the downturn hasn't really affected his popularity and the fact that he is an older rapper who has been in the underground for a long time hasn't really affected his popularity either because let's face it a lot of these older underground rappers didn't really transition over when the underground kind of exploded in the last handful years however it seems that tech 9 has really thrived in this brand-new Internet age for rap music and that's something that is wrapped about a handful of times here on this album and yes tec-9 is really eccentric style and image helps but I feel like the fact that he is a very technical and proficient and fast rapper is maybe his biggest selling point I love hearing this guy spit in a cypher doing a freestyle doing something acapella he's just a mind-blowing spitter has a really great flow and the thing is he enunciates really well and comes through with some really blunt lyrics that you get the first time or second time around definitely a guy who kind of straddles that line between being accessible and clever clever it's this sort of balancing act that has made tec-9 a popular rapper has brought him success and and as success has come things with him have changed especially his feature lists as of late with his recent albums tec-9 has featured artists that you would expect a guy like tec-9 to work with guys like three 6 mafia or local boys like Chris calico or big Scoob and also young up and comers who have a similarly dark edge to them like Hopson but then there are some sort of artists that are either really popular much more popular than tech 9 in the mainstream or ones that that sort of feel like are outside of his dark realms as well people like Kendrick Lamar Danny Brown who appears on this album little Lane yellow wolf t-pain the game and Wiz Khalifa are on this album too even Big KRIT who tec-9 did a pretty awesome BET's cypher with a few years ago there's even a legal and clear doors sample of Jim Morrison singing all over one of the tracks on this LP and even though things have been changing for tec-9 stylistically he stuck to his guns pretty much even though he is a different artist than he used to be in the early 2000s he's still pretty recognizable as the same guy I think the biggest surprise is on this LP are maybe the club ear tracks especially fizzles which has Danny Brown on here one of the bonus tracks from this LP where of course it's a banger beat really noisy and Tek is rapping about Mali which I guess is just something you have to do and in rap these days especially if you're rapping with Danny Brown so even though in a slightly objective way I can acknowledge that this album has versatility it has style tec-9 has technical ability with rapping quite a bit of it I don't like it I don't like this LP not even a little bit you know I I just don't get the sentiment of this album on a lot of tracks especially right from the start of this LP where you have these monotone girl voices talking about force trying to reduce us I guess us being tec-9 listeners or those who listen to tec-9 and think alternatively but what the alternative is is never really explicitly said I just feel like there are all these vague feelings of isolation thrown all over this album why it's almost like the music on this LP is trying to feed like an emotional vulture on anybody who's ever felt like they were unaccepted at any point in their lives and of course around every corner on this LP were reminded of how nobody accepts tec-9 and he's an outsider and he's different there are moments like on the song bitch breaking into colored houses where tec-9 comes off really funny clever and self-aware talking about how for a majority of his career his audience has been predominantly white however as he's been getting more popular and accepted into a rap community that is increasingly growing more open-minded toward things like gay rights as well as darker expressions and hip-hop music but then there are spots on this LP where I feel like texts personal observations aren't that fantastic or just his personal experiences which I'm not sure he's putting on display if he's not going to at least twist them in a way that has interesting word play or subtlety like on the song with the BS which has a pretty great bang or beat and some solid guest verses I love big scoob's contribution to this track the dude raps fast he's got a phat smooth husky voice but tec-9 he's just completely over-the-top about his financial troubles and getting his kids through college he puts it on display in the most obvious way possible where I don't really feel like anything for the situation really like okay you have to put your kids through college that's okay it's great that you have kids going to college which he cleverly rhymes with knowledge but still even though there are moments of this track that I do enjoy the instrumental kind of keeps me back from from full enjoyment I think because of just the the kind of weird Halloween style synthesizers playing in the background not everything needs to sound subtly creepy in a cartoony way especially college enrollment I mean one of my issues instrumentally with tec-9 kind of goes back to the song bitch where he mentions that he was one of the first rappers to try to make putting classical and opera music sampled into hip-hop big to me this trend has consistently been very corny gaudy and just in bad taste which are adjectives I would use to describe other tracks on this LP like the song love to dislike me which sounds like this rat metal Evanescence collaboration hybrid with this corn s guitar wails screaming in the background again I feel like these feelings if I don't belong are put on in the most vague way possible where just about anybody listening can hear this and be like I identify it just feels so manipulative to me it feels so shady and then there are moments where tec-9 doesn't really feel that relatable at all like on the track fortune force field which essentially is texts personal lyrical diary about the trials and tribulations of attempting to trademark a mixed drink that he wrapped about in a previous song as soon as the first verse was over I was just thinking what am I even listening to will tec-9 be rapping about his stock options later in the tracklist I realized that trademarking your own thing and trying to start your own business is is a very personal thing it could lead to a lot of money it may be really important to tec-9 however it does not make for a very passionate and harrowing and meaningful song topic to be completely honest maybe this is the kind of thing that jay-z could write like a really cocky clever lying about with a double entendre and then it would sort of fit into his song and get annotated on rap genius but it is just beating a dead horse when you've worked it out into song form if there's one single thing I can give him props on at least some regards to this track and others on here he's topical he takes a concept and he runs with it even if it's a concept that is is really stretched too far thin by the time he's run out to the length of a full song I do have to give him props on the song fragile though one of the few tracks on here I really dug a song where he felt real if like he was passion evil heart fell on this track really a song where lyrically he was responding directly to critics of his music I guess it's kind of ironic that the critic would love the song that kind of is a shot at critics but hey it was one of the more captivating tracks on this LP am I offended by some of what tec-9 said on this song not really I do understand kind of where he's coming from being a guy who is an alternative face in hip-hop he's had a lot of people who don't really understand him or his music listening to it over the years essentially labeling him as a joke as a character as a gimmick essentially for doing things that had been carried out in rock music for years like you would never write an article about kiss calling them a gimmick rock band because they wear suits and have face paint and I feel like he answers these criticisms well in this verse he ends off the verse by saying yeah you know what I am sensitive about my stuff he sort of answers the hate and I like how on the flip side Kendrick Lamar's on this track also rapping about critics rapping about the intense love in some of the hate that he has gotten over the past few years and how that can kind of drive one crazy as well tec-9 seems like a cool down-to-earth dude who is self-aware enough to the point where he shouldn't need to respond to people who are going to just sort of tag him with such a shallow criticism and not really dive deeply into the things that he's saying however as far as more serious critics of tec-9s music go I don't feel like you can be this guy who gets angry and gets upset saying that you put all this effort into your lines and you're mad that people are criticizing your music when you come out with songs like Wham you like Bailey's I like ladies I'm quite crazy there are people who are listening closely to lines like this in our life this line is like not good it gets a little one-dimensional after a while especially when I'm here in lines like I'm the biggest and baddest um matter than maddest I got this I had this it's a good rip homie Thanks and it just feels like so huge it feels like this big put-on to me but maybe what's even more disturbing when tec-9 comes through with a song that feels really personal like a track that's my kid where where he comes off like a proud father and if he has two kids like he says that are stable contributing members of society that's great but in this tracks lines he's rapping about using physical discipline clocking with the right hand so you have a kid who doesn't end up like Adam Lanza didn't he have a mental problem and as far as one of the final tracks on this LP Strange Days which features Jim Morrison's sampled vocals on the track well the song isn't terrible I feel like the sample Jim Morrison vocals are you so uncreated Lee really just singing entire lines of lyrics in between tech nines lines and it just does nothing for me really as a matter of fact most of this album really did nothing for me while again I I realized and I respect the fact that tec-9 has technical ability he has kind of a persona and a style of his own for me the choruses almost zero appeal on this LP especially that CeeLo hook on that's my kid where he sounds half asleep or like in the middle of eating a sandwich or something and as far as the instrumentals ago very few of them actually appeal to me many of them are just far too synthetic flat and when they're not just really club' they're just gaudy again with some of these Halloween style sounds or musical phrases or these more classical or operatic musical sounds phrases an instrumentation I'm feeling a strong three to a life four on this thing if you've given this up he'll listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it this review is my opinion if you don't like it I'm sorry but here's a straw I want to give a shout out to Billy woods who does not get in props all mistakes were intentional only the strong subscribe so do it Anthony Fantana tec-9 something else different forever [Music]

hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for you review the new dead in the dirt album the blind hole after just a few IPS this Atlanta Georgia band is now dropping its full-length debut album on the infamous southern Lorde records a label that as you may know lately has been kind of dabbling in the sludgy er side of extreme music and this new record that they are presenting with dead in the dirt is a 22 track of fair and time-wise lands out around 24 minutes averaging just over a minute per track I decided to give this thing a listen give it a review even though I feel like labels like Southern Lord and maybe to an extent Deathwish records have been kind of saturating the loud rock scene with heavy sludgy hardcore punk records or grindcore records power violence records kind of like this but I feel like at least this album was interesting enough to catch my ear for the short amount of time that it did we've got mosh friendly friendly riffs all over this LP and D beat drums as well these groovier points on the album which are backed up with these drums are occasionally interrupted by syncopated blast beat drums and guitars so and of course feedback plays a pretty gigantic role on this album as well and of course we cannot forget the vocals which are a range of different extreme music styles we have death metal s growls on this LP some just straight-up hardcore punk screams maybe a few moments that these shrieks on this LP feel a little scream O influenced the recording and the mix the heavy bass on this thing and just the overwhelming compression not too overwhelming though but the compression on this LP just makes this album sound so massive and yet it's really clear too even though the guitars are so just and the drums are just so pummeling but very resonant to every single crushing bass drum kick and bloody crusty sledgehammer guitar riff come through as clear as a bell a lot like a wrecking ball just kind of careening through your bedroom wall not only do these faster spots feel clear not too blurry even though that does sort of happen to an extent because of how fast the band is playing but there are slower moments on this LP that feel nice as well like the 11th track or the closing track here - which have some simple but effectively dreary guitar parts as well as some very slow slow riffs on the closer here the low-end on these riffs gets so heavy that there's this tangible Rumble to the bass it's moments like this that actually kind of lead me to believe that the band does have some kind of idea of what subtlety in music is however it's not really often on display with this LP and that could be a good or a bad thing depending on what you're looking for if you didn't already know power violence and grindcore bands can kind of be a dime a dozen if you're looking for nothing more than kind of a completely unmemorable slugfest where over the course of a stereotypically short album you are beaten almost within an inch of your life but you don't really remember much of any of it sure there are bands like nails that are really catchy really groove heavy and just have an insane sound that is just more powerful than most in this genre and there are others like worm rot who I continue to sing the praises of who are a grindcore act but come through with some real absurdities and eccentricities to the music they're creating for sure dead and the dirt has come through on this record where they fantastic recording immense recording for this kind of music but sometimes I can't help but feel like a lot of what is presented here songwriting wise and and vocally - is just kind of very standard I don't really feel like the vocals are legitimately wild or furious sometimes just really kind of following in the footsteps of a lot of expectations coming from death and hardcore punk I definitely don't feel like the vocals here are as infuriated as what I've heard from either in fest or Charles Bronson and on the shorter tracks I do tend to feel like the bands writing especially on the riffs can be sort of unmemorable it's really the longer and Meteor tracks and then sometimes even the slower and sluttier tracks where I feel like dead and the dirts potential kind of comes through while they do have that physical intensity that you would want from some of the shorter tracks on here there's not much to them that I gravitate toward and while I wouldn't say that this record was boring to me I'm actually surprised that I stuck with it and wanted to listen to it again and again there's definitely something to be said for that but as I listen to this record more and more and totally enjoyed the recording enjoyed the ferocity enjoyed the intensity and I was looking for a little bit more in other places but I just wasn't finding that stuff meaning more creativity from the noisy sounds or the riffs or the vocals or just the song structures though this record is fast and enraging I just wish it pulled some more punches offered more surprises had a little bit more personality it's not a record that I see sticking with me for the long run but if you're into something extreme straight up and no BS then I would definitely give this thing a listen regardless of whether or not you agree with me on this review I'm feeling a decent strong 6 on this thing if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's about it I want to give a shout out to Paul tec-9 fans I hear you Sammy Jerusha over at the rocket out blog I just did a video with him you can find a link down below in the description box and moms who buy their children tonight on vinyl only the stronger subscribe all mistakes were intentional straw anthony Fantana dead in the dirt forever you

Kandee claws snap snap okay okay okay I have heard you I have listened to you and I understand y'all don't want no scrubs so I'm going to cut my hair you should just get that hair cut on your head you hippie man you just you can't argue with that hi everyone Anthony Fantino here internet's busiest music art and it's time for a review of the new kandi clause album series and calypso in the deep time kandi clause is a pop outfit been following them on and off since 2009 when i heard their debut full-length in the dream of the sea life a very low phi and psychedelic album otherwise known as NZ dream ozc life this is the second full-length album now that they have dropped since the release of that debut and it is really catching my ear a lot more than the last full length they put out in 2010 hidden lands an album where essentially the the group cleaned up their sound quite a bit really made the production a lot more spic and span than their low fights and worked out a lot more precise melodies this LP was a lot more engaging musically but sort of threw away all of these surreal fuzziness and it is now on this new full-length album where I really feel like kandi clauses kind of reconciled the two sides of their musical persona here and have created an LP that is instrumentally and melodically dense with all of these sweet candied melodies that feel compressed and layered one on top of another in this Phil Spector esque wall of sound style there are moments production and arrangement wise where it feels like kandi Claus is pulling from the Beach Boys and the Beatles as well so there is sort of a vintage retro throwback element to some of the songwriting album however there is a very strong dream pop element as well on this LP which genre wise is nothing new dream pop has been around a while but with these genres resurgence as of late it does keep this album feeling kind of modern especially with how dense this album is with sound instrumentally this LP is as thick as a triple decker club at a truck stop diner with really distorted rough bass guitars over modulated guitar chords some really shimmering leads and keyboards and some pretty whispery sedate boy/girl vocals as well and while all of these pieces of instrumentation all of these sounds don't seem incredibly impressive on paper it's really how candy cos arranges all this stuff that kind of Wow's me because even though the the slow pace and the very breezy vocals on their tracks give a very dreamy sleep-like feel to this album it's the melodies and the arrangements that feel very awake alert nimble agile at some points it's almost as if candy Claus is sort of like a mini psych pop pit orchestra on some of these tracks especially on the track transitional girl which actually has all these beautiful Beatles esque vocal harmonies soaring after the choruses there are also some other spots on this LP where they're really heavy guitars and bass sort of buzz and drone and pound along with the drums and this sort of My Bloody Valentine like fashion the sound is really heavy and it's warped however don't expect candy Claus to take a similar songwriting fashion on this LP a lot of the band's melodic influences come far from outside of shoegaze whether it's the song charade which is a very moody waltz or the song fallen tree bridge which has all these sassy Latin guitar leads playing over the intro or even the track birth of the flower which is so tropical in its melodies and its instrumentation that it feels like it would go over pretty well at a luau even though aesthetically Candi Claus does stay in roughly the same dream pop psych state throughout this entire LP when it comes to the kind of music that influences them melodically their ears really to the wind and this breeze sort of takes them in a lot of different directions while I think that there is a lot of instrumental talent on this record it almost seems like to me that candy Klaus is a little too reliant on this whispery vocal dream pop aesthetic to sort of make this record work occasionally candy Claus can feel kind of OneNote in the same way that black moth super rainbow can which is especially the case if I don't end up liking the song or the melody that the band has worked out for a particular track like on the song illusion which has all these downs stroked very moody dark guitar chords all over the song that actually feel like they could have worked against the melody from the opening theme to Tales from the Crypt I do appreciate the band's ambition to try out different musical styles throughout this album but as I listen to especially in the second half with all the instrumentation in the vocals feeling uniformly packed together in this vacuum-sealed psychedelic sausage-making all of the instrumental elements feel really mushy it gets a little stale honestly most of the time I do dig this album a lot candy Claus instrumental backdrop is so impressive at points on this LP it's like being dropped right into the middle of a hallucination inspired fairy tale if only the the sort of ambitious concept and narrative that I know the band's strung together for this album came through in a very sharp way through this dream pop aesthetic it's a bit of a double-edged sword that I feel like candy Claus is yet to wield in a really impressive way on this album still with the amount of production and instrumental talent that I'm hearing on this LP I feel like candy Claus but this album is one step closer to coming out with a project that is conceptually impressive intelligible but still for the time being this album is very blissful melodic fun and enjoyable I'm feeling a light two decent seven on this thing if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it this review is my opinion if you don't like it here's a straw I want to give a shout-out to dead end hip hop who did a great video talking about sort of hip hop's response or involvement or effect on the whole Trayvon Martin case also Zack D honky Fan Tan chip and happy birthday Eric only the strong subscribe all mistakes are intentional or were intentional you Anthony Fantana candy Klaus forever you

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new EP from Sam this guy is a singer-songwriter multi-instrumentalist hailing from the UK if you paid close attention to what was going on in electronic music in 2011 you may already be familiar with him due to his many appearances on the debut self-titled subtract album and the most utilized singer and easily them the most standout singer out of the entire Bunch Sam feh and I say standout because of his incredibly soul full voice which is executed with this very tight nimble vibrato uh he's got a wonderful range to his voice as well this very youthful tone to it that runs a little nasally I think it's all of these qualities that come together and make people instantaneously compare this guy to a singer like James Blake I think once you get deeper into each artist stylistically listening to their music more and more and more where they're heading sort of seems to make it apparent that the comparison is is only legitimate on a vocal level now with this solo effort that Santa has just put out dual this neo-soul EP of his which is six tracks long two interludes on it for meteor tracks all kind of adding up together to about 18 minutes some tracks seem to head in a slightly more electronic direction others more natural with piano kind of leading the way but either/or it's really the vocals that kind of take the spotlight his vocals are especially impressive on the closing track here can't get close which sort of sees santhu vocalizing over this one musical refrain over and over and over for about three minutes and then the song kind of ends not really a fully formed song but Sam does singing on this track has range from his very sad emotive low-end to his very painful Seto's our beautiful I just wished the songwriting and the instrumentation were a little bit more hammered out or a little bit more substantive on this track and honestly even though it's not as bad on other songs here for me that sort of seems to be the recurring theme on this short collection of tracks even on the most fully realized track on this EP indecision which is a song where Sampha delivers that's really passionate fiery piano ballad the instrumentation backing up Santa's piano playing and singing feels so faint so weak that I just wish it was him singing and playing piano and that's it it's like there's no confidence in some of the backup instrumentation on this EP now tracks like without and beneath the tree songs that take a slightly more electronic approach I wish they were a little more vivid and and lush instrumentally - but maybe I find a bit more appeal in songs like this because of their electro acoustic blend of instrumentation I'm loving just how serene and seductive and calming and smooth all the sounds are added up together especially on the song without which has these layers upon layers of rhythms that progress pretty nicely as the song moves forward and I'm loving the addition of guitar on this track - it sparkles and it shimmers in the same way that the sense do they just melt together in this really nice way and just sound very one overall it's it's not a bad ap I did enjoy it however I wouldn't say that it stopped me in my tracks or anything like that if there's anything that I came away from this EP with it was you know a few catchy refrains like the one on indecision but mostly I'm just kind of feeling yeah sanfur could come out with something a lot more interesting in the future I mean that that ultimately was my reaction to this thing when it concluded it's just a matter of either him getting a little bit more ambitious with his instrumentation or hooking up with another great producer like subtract to come out with another series of songs and that's it if you've given the sepia listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it thank you for watching you're the best Sampha dual ep you

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and going to do a little question comment thing about a question that people throw my way quite a bit where i dosed out scores scores reviews numbers etc putting scores at the end of my reviews via a zero to ten number scale is something that many people have asked me about since I started the needle drop it's something that I've reflected on quite a bit since starting the needle drop and I know the reasons why people don't like it or sort of the negative aspects of it which I guess I can't present because the world of art is so subjective how could you put something as concrete as a number or a grade on it I know from the outside looking in it may seem like a very cold and callous practice and part of the reason that is because I don't really explain it in every single video and God why should it be but for me personally the the numbers that I put at the end of my reviews and I assume that's the case for most reviewers even though they don't really discuss it a great length either is just a reflection of my personal opinion or preference there is some kind of magical criteria checklist that I'm sort of oh this is worth this many points and this is worth that many points really all that's going on is from zero to four we're talking about an album that I dislike whether it be a four which I dislike a little or it's a zero which is like an atom bomb of sadness going on in my brain then we have a five which is pretty much me on the fence and then from six to ten that's stuff I like whether I like a little bit as a six or a ten which is an atom bomb of happiness going off in my head I know there are people out there that tend to react strongly to these numbers whether it be with love or extreme hate but to me those people are individuals that give in to the idea of getting hung up on such a thing if those people were not getting hung up on numbers then they would get hung up on me simply saying you know what I hate this or I love this I guess at the end of the day all I really want is for you to be able to comprehend what I'm saying understand the opinion that I'm trying to give my like or dislike of the album and I guess sort of just throwing a number on the end of it helps in the understanding of that and I think at this point you could definitely say I don't rely on that too much especially since I sort of don't score and my quicker reviews and in my more long-form reviews you definitely get a ton of opinion and context before that score is really delivered but still they're going to be people that just think about the number and and you know what that's their thing that's their loss there going to be people who lose respect for me over a score there going to be people who compare the score of one album to another album and are like oh my god how could they do that people are going to enjoy people are going to watch people are going to listen to what they want to enjoy watch and listen to for the reasons that they feel like I can't make you watch or understand or enjoy my videos the way I want you to understand watch or enjoy them especially as the viewer base of the YouTube channel grows the more it grows the less control over that I have people could be watching my reviews because they think Cal is really funny five-stage which by the way he's not he's never actually been funny but some people seem to like him more than me for whatever reason what shapes so for whatever reason you watch I have decided that it's probably the smartest thing to let you watch the way you want to watch and let you enjoy the way you want to enjoy and understand the way you feel like understanding sure if you ask me a question in a comment and I don't miss it or if it's on Twitter or something like that or in an email I'm happy to answer but I mean you're gonna think what you think and I'm not gonna try to correct every single person who I may disagree with just because that seems like a futile pursuit and that's it so in nutshell I guess that's kind of why I put numbers at the end of my videos what do you guys think what do you think of scores at the end of reviews of anything really I mean does it make things convenient does it make things easier or is it the greatest artistic travesty to ever happen in modern times that we are giving one stars to restaurants or d-minuses to movies or 4.32 new albums let me know Anthony Fantana scores forever

hi how you doing Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd and gonna do a review right now the new alunageorge album body music these guys are London pop duo who had been dropping some pretty hot singles for the past few years in 2011 it was the song you know you like it and in 2012 your drums your love and this year earlier this year my personal favorite so far in the line of singles they've been dropping track attracting flies and all these tracks were a pretty nice fusion of contemporary R&B dance pop electro pop some of the hotter electronic music styles to come out of the UK right now like future garage as well as UK bass and even though these songs they were great however not really the most inventive pop songs on the planet there was still reason to believe that this album would be solid for one George Reed is a pretty talented and versatile producer plus you've got this guy making the beats the instrumentals for the album track for track for track so there is going to be some kind of quality control and consistency across the instrumentals and as far as Aluna Francis goes she's an incredibly capable singer with a distinctly high-pitched voice which is very tiny but subtly rough like it's it's got a little bit of sandpapery quality to it it's like I'm listening to her whisper but even when she's singing loudly and the songs on this album have a sense of structure they have melody they have explosive memorable choruses however I would stop short of saying that it's really a a ambitious album really to me this album is just kind of a mixed bag of contemporary pop tracks even if a lot of them are well written a lot of the same love and relationship tropes that you've heard in pop music a million times before are sung here again but alunageorge can come off pretty clever about it sometimes like on the track attracting flies where you have this emotional argument going on with a lot of Lies being thrown around and what is being sung is that this person everything the exhale is attracting flies kind of polite way of saying that it's and I really like the hook lyrics on the track lost-and-found - if you wanted a lost-and-found you should have caught me on the rebound there are moments like this where alunageorge can present a pretty interesting turn of phrase and that it really seems like they're putting effort into the lyrics but then again there are spots that come off a little obvious with the rhyme scheme like on the opener which which tosses together the rhyme sad glad bad the times we had okay so the cat had a bat and it was fat on a mat even though I wish there was a little more effort put into the rhyming here and there overall I wouldn't really say the lyrics are an issue for me even though many of the tracks here focus on this very young love or heartbreak it feels like it's being executed with a pretty mature focus because at the end of the day it's the it's the genuinely catchy melodies and courses that make these song so good now the previously released singles which are all great are dumped pretty early on in the tracklist on this LP although I will say that I have to mention the track your drums your love I love the melody on this track especially right before the chorus pops in and you get these jazzy or piano chords playing into the song it's musical flourishes like this that gives some of these songs character and make them feel a little bit more layered than your average pop tune and alunageorge outside of these singles which they've been riding for years they do manage to bring some at least some other highlights like the track kaleidoscope love I love the vocal melodies on the verses on this track has a really old school 90s R&B flavor but the beat and and this happens on track after track after track that brings this more 90s R&B vibe the beat feels very new feels very current especially with the weirdly manipulated bass on this track I would say the same thing goes for the track best be believen again we're getting kind of an R&B flavor but the vocal samples which are pitch shifted and played throughout the song like an instrument I mean that just feels so new and really catchy I like that Aluna Francis is bringing tons of things with her vocals whether it be a vocal melody or whether it be her lyrics that makes these songs memorable but George read as well some of the tight little flashy additional melodies that he'll throw into tracks make the songs memorable as well now like I mentioned earlier other genres do come through on this LP like the electro pop and the dance pop and the UK bass especially on a song like Lost and Found I do like the variety but part of me ends up favoring tracks like the title track on here which are slower a little more sensual over songs like super star which I just see his kind of being very blandish pop they're actually a handful of songs toward the second half of this album that don't really add much to the LP for me that includes super star as well as Lost and Found just to touch as well part of that has to do with I don't really feel like George Reed is bringing an incredibly new idea or concept to these tracks that he didn't bring on previous tracks in my opinion but these songs are also kind of running to an issue for me that I think is the biggest consistent issue on this album and that's really Luna Francis and and again I said earlier she's a capable singer I still believe that and I think she has a lot of pitch I think she has more range than a lot of girls that are trying to sing this kind of music she definitely has an ear catching voice as well which makes the singles off of the cell P so great but I feel like she's a little limited in the style that she sings with George Reed is much more of a versatile producer than Aluna is a singer a lot of the tracks on this LP have the same vocal phrasing and if it's not that it's it's pretty much every song here singing with that same kind of cute sexy dynamic even on the slower and more sensual songs where I actually would like to hear something a bit more soulful or toned down I actually think the title track is one of the few moments here where Aluna felt legitimately vulnerable or kind of lovely even though I did like this album it does feel a little limited on the diversity side they do kind of tend to run a little one-dimensional on this album but the songs that are good on this here are great if only they could kind of veer out of their comfort zone and write some other songs feel just as good as some of the hey everyone Anthony Fantino here Internet's busiest music nerd yep that's me you know that already and it's time for a quick review of the new all pigs must die album nothing violates this nature these guys are a massachusetts band this is their second full-length LP and it's been a handful of years now since I first heard of them and they initially impressed me with their Curt blue of converge produced debut self-titled EP their sound and their style tends to run on the hardcore punk side of things with a kind of sludgy loud heavy aesthetic and since they put out this EP and even before they put out this EP and I'm sure long after I make this video this is not really the only release out there right now kind of dabbling in this fusion of metal and hardcore stylings you know just taking a more metallic approach to playing just fast aggressive Punk style music and this EP that I'm talking about and the debut album they dropped shortly after showcased power energy speed ferocity but when it came to writing and just kind of having a distinct sound or style all pigs must die I was really kind of coming up short however I do like this new album of there's a little bit more even though it's in roughly the same style I'm finding that the riffs and the chord progressions do have a bit more personality to them some of the melodic guitar leads or harmonious chords laid into tracks on this album like of suffering and bloodlines and the really slow sludgy closer do hint to all pigs must die showcasing a little bit more finesse but I think another change all pigs must die has made to this album is that it's a little more ferocious than their last two and maybe a little less kind of generic hardcore sounding some of their fastest and most aggressive songs yet have made it onto this LP songs like Hakeem siege and and sacred noting the speed and the power of these songs is just to me completely undeniable and I would say in terms of sound and production this record is definitely heavier and all pigs must dies laughs tell Pete to however even though I do like the force and I like the power of this album those things are nothing if not memorable for me because while all pigs must die is heavier and louder on this album it's not like they're as aggressive as other groups that are fusing some of these same styles together and are on the same label all pigs must die is on to southern lord groups like the secret and nails too are just much more but still sometimes actually to a fault because I'm not really a huge fan of the secrets last LP even though that is is unquestionably aggressive but the thing is it's so fierce non-stop that nothing much on the LP sticks out and I kind of feel like this all pigs must die album isn't like that throughout but there are quite a few songs on here that sort of breeze by me because of the sort of generic hardcore vocal stylings that that do run through some of these songs and the kind of unambitious guitar work again while it's fast and it's loud the fact that melodies that are interesting don't really stick out where chord progressions or grooves that are unique or creative don't stick out this to me sort of feels like hardcore wallpaper sometimes I would say with this new album of there's all pigs must die is not as one-dimensional as they sort of came off on their last full-length LP but I still can't say that I'm any more than lukewarm toward their latest material even if this album is really infectious sometimes with with how aggressive it is if you've given this all pigs must die album a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why did you not really care about the writing or the guitar work or anything like that and it's just really hi everyone Anthony Fantana here intranets busiest music nerd and it's time for a review the new self-titled record from Edward Sharpe and the Magnetic Zeros these guys were a California indie rock and indie folk band who in my opinion have had one of the more shocking falls from grace since their debut full-length album release in 2009 and and when I say shocking I mean sort of more in in recent memory back in 2009 when they put out their first full-length up from below it was an album that did not necessarily turn a ton of heads upon its initial release but it had a few nice sleeper hits on it that got people into the band sort of after the fact songs like home really fantastic hit off of this LP a song that is catchy very joyful just jubilant instrumentation that is a mix of folk and rock sounds and the band's really huge instrumental lineup showed with just how gargantuan monstrous their sound was it was like listening to some kind of giant folky Arcade Fire and when I think about that theory or the idea of that in my head I I'm into that but I don't think Edward Sharpe and the Magnetic Zeros really carried forward into their later releases to to really kind of capitalize on that potential really reach their full potential actually up from below was far from a perfect album but listening to the band's next full-length here was like watching a director try to put out the sequel to what essentially was a cult film with no budget and half of the original cast everything sounded really rickety on this album from the instrumentation to the performances there just were not a lot of good takes on this LP and I would say the songwriting was just not as concise or succinct or just really straightforward and memorable I just think it's odd that Edward Sharpe and the Magnetic Zeros would give up their pop appeal so easily especially considering that their pop appeal was the best thing they had going for them on up from below because when it came to the worlds of indie and indie pop they certainly weren't trailblazing or creating any new sounds or anything like that now with this new self-titled full-length of theirs Edward sharps pop appeal is still out to lunch except this time I feel like the band is is emphasizing that indie folk vibe a little bit less and instead they're they're going for something that feels way more vintage with some extremely tacked on soul and previously Edward sharps music has tipped its hat to the psychedelic 60s but this time around on this LP we're getting acid so guitar solos really thumpy Paul McCartney s bass lines and drums that have a really kind of hollow atmospheric thud to them as if they were being recorded decades upon decades ago instead of sounding authentically vintage I think this self-titled LP sounds more messy and thrown together than here case in point the song in the lion quite possibly the worst mix song you'll hear this year the horns the lead vocals the horribly performed falsetto background vocals and the drums all just completely out of whack and some of these problems aren't even specific to this track consistently I would say the worst thing about this album is Ed sharps voice while his sing was good and and pretty tolerable on previous LPS I would say much of the time on this album when Ed sharp isn't really screaming to reach notes that he doesn't really have he's using this really forced vibrato that gets annoying after a while as I'm listening to this album even though Ed Sharpe and the Magnetic Zeros may have some real passion for the folk rock and the pop and the rock of the 60s on this album I feel like them trying to recreate it here is is the equivalent to just watching a Broadway rendition of the 60s the musical 60s versus some bad street performance of it I would say this record is essentially in default answer to a Prairie Home Companion which is incredibly dorky and incredibly hokey show on NPR that dabbles in country folk music a little bit of bluegrass as well but the thing with a home companion is that it's kind of self-aware tongue-in-cheek a lot of the time and I don't really feel that vibe from Edward Sharpe and the Magnetic Zeros even though ed sharp can get silly at times on this album like on the song let's get high when he's singing ain't we all just Japanese when we're high I still can't help but feel like this album is is a little serious at points like this I mean if this song was put out in 1963 at best today would be like a novelty song but now it just sounds ridiculous then there's all these references to love needing someone's love giving your love we all have love for one another again trying to recapture this emotional philosophical sort of social sentiment of young people from this era of music that Edward Sharpe and the Magnetic Zeros are trying to recreate on this record and this is just one more thing on this album that falls horribly short of sounding like something I can take seriously or really kind of believe in I have to be completely honest and say that this album there isn't much about it I can say that I liked I mean the production was really bad and you know just technically weak the instrumentation again sounded really flat and just bodyless a lot of the time just for some kind of cheap attempt to recreate some dead sonic palette really there were only flashes on this album that that appealed to me like oh this melody here sounds pretty good or this vocal take sounds okay or I like this guitar part here the only emotion that this album really stirred up in me is that it made me want to go listen to Frank Zappa and the mothers were only in it for the money I think after listening to this album maybe I came at least a little close to gaining a quarter of the anger or annoyance that Frank Zappa had for hippies and their social circle when he wrote this LP I'm essentially feeling the light too decent three on this thing if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it this review is my opinion if you don't like it here's a straw I want to give a shout out to you you're the best only the strong subscribe all mistakes were intentional Anthony Fantino ed sharp forever you

whoo hi everyone Anthony Fantino here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a little quick review of the new arca mixtape and-and-and-and this guy has been producing under another name previously but still overall when you count the production he created under that name as well as this name arca he has a pretty short discography however I guess his talent his connections his really forward-thinking production style landed him on the short list of co-producers on the new Kanye West album yeezus now I first heard this guy last year when he prolifically released stretch 1 and stretched - and even though hip hop and wonky and beat music were clearly staple influences for arca it doesn't really seem like on stretch 1 and stretch 2 he enjoys playing by the established rules of the beat production of that genre or really anybody's established rules because a lot of the beats a lot of the rhythms that back up his productions are kind of disjointed they're sputtering their grooves tend to be very angular and kind of all over the place and as far as some of the more melodic samples and the synthesizers on his tracks they come together in a way that that does not really feel harmonious either much of the time his his since and his samples can come off as being more like a jumbled glitchy sound collage and as far as vocals go which which do occasionally appear on his albums it feels like they're thrown into the mix more for a druggie trippy effect than any kind of coherence or meaning or understanding now this new collection of tracks from ARCA has essentially been assembled into this non-stop 25-minute mix it's really hard to explain it's like I'm listening to someone smash an abstract sculpture with a blindfold on and then you're taking the blindfold off of them and you're forcing them to reassemble the structure as like the intro track on this mix not which has these swirling quickly ascending high-pitched lead melodies that are sort of dizzying I love the odd vocal samples that that are cycling over and over and over on the track harness ARCA does really love to take just little vocal snippets and kind of pitch shift them layer them out repeat them over and over step them up and step them down and there are moments on this mix where ARCA comes through with some beets that have a bit of a trap flavor to them with the groove of the bass drum and the twittering high hats though even when he goes for a trap banger style track or a little snippet because these songs do run a little short he still does not play it straightforward he's still really just sort of really messes things up just twists things turns things and make sure that a lot of the high is the samples and the melodies just stay whacked out as hell outside of these trap moments there's spots where it feels like ARCA is observing some cloud wrap aesthetics too there are some electronic sounds that hit me on the 8 minute mark of this mix that feel as if I'm listening to something Autechre had produced even though there is a huge hip-hop influence in Arcas music just like there is a nought ecers music at times he can get really experimental and really cold there's even a moment with some of the weird vocal layering and chorus effects around the 20 minute mark of this mix that hit me as being kind of Shabazz Palaces influenced even though ARCA is clearly influenced by a lot of the more alternative sounds in hip-hop and electronic music today he drives his creative process out into this weird lone desert to the point where it feels like he's not really connected to much of any of it but as I guess sort of one long holistic piece I do think it's really great it's fun it's creative it's challenging and and it's really thought-provoking too as well as just being kind of visceral when it does come through with with with a moment that does feel like it's a banger if you've given this listen and there's a link down there in the description box there's no reason not to listen to it give me a love give me a hate why you know just let me know what you're thinking and that's it Anthony Fantan Oh ARCA [Music] you

hi everyone Anthony Han Tan oh here the Internet's busy busiest music nerd and it's time for your review of the new fuck buttons album focus these guys are an experimental music duo whose aesthetic is really really electronic synthetic but their earlier stuff dealt much more and just the noisier more abrasive kind of droney side of things but on their 2009 album tarot sport an album that a lot of people consider to be their breakout LP the duo was bringing in all of these techno influences with these straightforward driving kind of repetitive beats and on top of that the slow-moving chords the slow building nature of all the instrumentation that they were using led to some really epic vibes as well and even though I appreciate this side of fuck buttons music I appreciate that they try to create that sensation with their music ultimately it's their writing and it's sort of the the pace or rather the stillness of their music that kind of kills me melodically just compositionally I find a lot of the tracks to be really dull just cycling through the same chords and and melodic phrases again and again and again really with with not enough variation to make the songs interesting from front to back because for sure the songs that they write do catch my ear at the start of the track for me most of the time it seems like the only changes that they're interested in are making things louder making things softer or just adding more melodic elements to this sonic pig pile and it's it's just confusing to me that fuck buttons would take this structural and melodic approach with their songs time and time and time again because they're so great and meticulous when it comes to finding sounds and just finding interesting textures if you would work this hard to grab the most interesting sounds that you could find sounds that a lot of people are not toying with why would your music writing approach be so obvious really is obvious as a bad post rock song I will say the slow focus does bring a little more are detailed to the table though than Tarot sport did fuck buttons does layer their tracks a little bit more the drones feel a bit more massive there are a few shorter tracks on here that I like quite a bit that feature these really fast arpeggios they feel like they could have been in some kind of 80s sci-fi progressive synth soundtrack even though there are elements of this album that add more character to fuck button style I still can't help but feel like progression of their songs is is still not a strong point and slow focus does try to imply this progression by just piling one looping snippet of sound on top of another looping snippet of sound to a higher degree than they did on their last album but I feel like all this has done is just dull the pain of the monotony that typically comes through on their tracks I would say the worst offender in this sense is the last track on the album hidden excess the longest song on slow focus opts for what are probably the blandest chords on the entire LP and this set of chords which which aren't even interesting at the start of the song just continue again and again and again and again from beginning to end on this track getting louder and louder and louder in this sort of boring melodic lead that's that's descending again I just feel like there's very little personality to the melodies and the chords that fuck buttons writes into their songs and and when I listen to a song like this I feel like no wonder there's not that much significant change to the music over the course of a 10 minute song when this is your main theme for sure on this track and others energy is their sound is their groove is their but the melody just seems like this incredibly neglected afterthought and I know that melody isn't really a strong point on on numerous albums that I may enjoy or in different styles of music but it seems like the melody is something that is being showcased on these tracks or is at least trying to play a pivotal role in what makes these songs what they are while fuck buttons does deal in a lot of noise and a lot of drones they do take the time to write chord progressions and the chord Russians they do use are really clear and in your face and very audible the court progression on the opening track your brain freeze feels just as uninspired in a lot of ways but fuck buttons does manage to work in some kind of bee and melodic change up on the second half of the song which which does keep it kind of interesting maybe the tracks the Red Wing and sentient SAR my favorites on this LP though they do tend to be as repetitive as some of the other tracks on this album they do work with some really out there sounds Red Wing has some really interview I just love the character of some of the synth sounds and just the the groove on this track and and sentient has a bit of an industrial vibe to it I would say really metallic really sort of nocturnal dark there's something about these tracks that kind of makes me feel like I'm listening to a coherent Black Dice song but in the case of the Red Wing you have all these high-pitched ethereal just ringing droning out synthesizer notes that that have a bit of a thinness to them that makes me feel like I'm listening to some just tremolo picked post-rock guitars I wish it changed up more but it still does have a bit of an epic feel to it and beyond that there's not much more I can say about this LP the things that are really likable about this album are blatantly obvious I mean you've got the great grooves their tracks but consistently I'm just really unimpressed with the way that they progress their sounds I'm feeling a decent too strong sex on this LP if you've given it a listen what did you think of hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here Internet's busiest the zik nerd and it's time for a review of the new stone Titan album scratch-and-sniff this is the debut full-length LP of the Connecticut rock display of sludge metal that I'm surprised any of it is coherent it's like stone Titan is just going sludge metal Super Saiyan on numerous tracks here with if if it's risks that are just so distorted of hate out there in the world I like that there's a metal band that is leaving room for statements that are incredibly spiteful and borderline absurd with their over-the-top aggression and gross Ness I mean look at the freaking cover it's a guy cutting his wrists and rainbows are coming out and all sorts of weird disgusting figures hanging inside of the rainbows it's not exactly like you could say the band takes itself too seriously when one of its song titles is Alaskan Thunder  this absurd side of their character is is something I would love to see emphasized in the future now not only are the tracks on this LP fast and tense and heavy but they have a tendency to run kind of psychedelic to just shoving some really weird and abrasive details into the bassy muck that is displayed on a majority of the songs here and some of these details can come through the way of de tar embellishments or drum fills some feedback weird vocalizations and these can be expressed in in a kind pretty and melodic and blissful way like on the song Alaskan Thunder or in an incredibly harsh and aggressive way like the track can of worms and even though the structure does help the songs along and makes hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new let live album the blackest beautiful let live California rock band who for a few albums now have been bringing together elements of punk music metal music post hardcore on top of that maybe some modern pop punk flavors as well which did play a pretty notable role on their previous LP through some of the vocal harmonies the really hooky choruses but still with a lot of very just uh aggressive riff j-- just shut the up kind of riffs there was an undeniable ferocity to this LP let live is a really energetic band that I think asks a lot of energy from its listeners and and there are a few things in their sound that display that more than the vocals which for the most part are screamed and are really high volume relentless impassioned put those together with really fast and tight playing with the guitars and the drums and somebody listening to this is bound to get hyped up now personally I do find let lives sound in just the way that they deliver their songs to be a little too clean for me a little too clean in comparison with some of my favorite post hardcore records out there however I wouldn't really say that they're up there with some of the more melodramatic poppy and kind of spic and span bands in the genre I don't know asking alexandria and even though that's not the case I got to say I feel like let live is moving a little bit further in that direction with the black is beautiful oddly enough though I don't really feel like the band has gotten any less aggressive on this LP their frontman Jason Butler feels just as intense as he did on the band's last full-length he's spazzing out on nearly every track here his shouts and his screams feel really throaty and when he goes for more of a tone down spoken word kind of vibe he feels really emotive kind of eccentric over-the-top I think he has a ton of personality as a frontman even if sometimes lyrics don't really move me or anything like that even if I may agree with them to a slight degree the American got him in his second de Dix of cooperations despite statements like that I can't help but feel like the sound that let live presents at times feels a tad bit corporate for one the really clean and robotic and pristine vocal harmonies that are used on almost every track on this LP feel more than ever as if they're being used just for accessibility purposes because they certainly don't sound that great for anybody that wants to just hear a raw natural real human voice it feels really fake and obnoxious it's like the kind of studio trickery that a really bad glam metal band would use or even a new metal band their spots were butler's vocalizations make me imagine him as like a tiny David Draiman I'm just torn on his performances because for the most part I feel like he is the most interesting thing this album has to offer because of his energy and because of his passion aside from Anthony Rivera on drums who actually has a fantastic drum break on the track the fear fever but consistently throughout the album his grooves his his tightness his speed and his detail are all really impressive even though Butler seems like an incredibly capable singer obviously that's the case from let Liv's previous LP every time he tries to do something that seems to stick out on here it just makes me cringe a little bit like the start of the track white America soda Mack Vince or the the really sort of overacted and whimpering vocals on the closer especially as he's kind of talking about taking his own life and kind of laughing to himself for the very back end of the track as if this is like some kind of display of psychosis or maybe he's being maniacal I'm I'm not sure I just feel ambivalent toward most of the emotions that let live just throws up in the lyrics to be completely honest and and I don't think the band is necessarily over emotive I get that post-hardcore is music that has a lot of links to emo music and other very expressive forms of punk my issue is that I just really can't say there's much of anything about let lives approach that feels fresh for sure their intensity makes it adequate the performances on this record are really tight the production of post-production I feel I've essentially given us a record that is really heavy and technically flawless the band plays well and in some of their more sporadic moments they remind me of groups like blood brothers or the refused and as much as I like the spots on this album that remind me of those groups the more that I think about it and the more that I listen to this the more this album feels like just an unapologetically poppy bastardization of the sounds the influences and I don't really have anything against perfection or accessibility for sure everything on the new Queens of the Stone Age record shows up on time so to speak but that album even though it's catchy it's it's somewhat subversive in its in its really moody emotions on the blackest beautiful let live definitely comes off as fast and abrasive but it's almost kind of misleading because once you dig past that I feel like I'm listening to these kind of basic but sped up rock ballads which lyrically a lot of the time I feel like are just trying to plug into these really vague appeals to emotional emptiness or some kind of discontent with the world at large truth be told even though there wasn't much on this record that offended me or that I really disliked aside from just the really cold sounding background vocals a lot of it was just kind of dull for me again I like the sound I think the production is is top-notch but the songwriting just really didn't do much of anything for me I'm feeling a strong four to a light five on this album if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it this review is my opinion if you don't like it here's a straw I want to give a shout out to my dog nori get better you're literally my dog only the strongest subscribe all mistakes were intentional Anthony Fantana let live forever [Music] [Music]

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a chilled-out review of the new Lycus album tempest these guys were metal outfit from the west coast they've been around for several years but this is their first big studio recorded commercial full-length release the band actually features an ex member of the group death heaven for those of you who are huge into the records sunbather you might want to check this album out as well but it's not as if Lycus or tempest have that much bearing in the experimental black metal or progressive black metal black gaze world still I would say this record is a a forward-thinking and very melodic and engaging approach to the style of metal that this band does play very slow dirge like funeral doom metal metal songs in this style feature tempos that that move like the seasons monolithic riffs that have an epic sound and melodies that are incredibly mournful and just have the strong sense of sadness pretty much the styles defining characteristics since the 90s when it was molded by bands like thier gathon and funeral as well as esoteric a recent ban to catch a lot of attention playing in this style has been a hab if you count about 6 years ago as being recent like it seems really conscious of this genres past but they want to keep things interesting and modern as well as slow as this band songs are they add a lot of detail and progressions into the mix really justifying the long lengths of the three tracks here that are 9 11 and 20 minutes there's endlessly flowing melodies throughout this LP a lot of them executed by guitar leads sometimes they're layered and harmonized in a beautiful way tons of dramatic drum fills and expressive guitar chords that remind me of chord progressions that I've heard on records like wolves and the throne rooms to hunters or even that new pallbearer record plus there are plenty of peaks and valleys as these songs go from beginning to end I take the vocals on the selfie too I wish it was more variety to them but just these monstrous growls front pretty much every track here that combined together with the melody and just the sloth-like pace of these songs I feel like I'm listening to slowed down death metal power ballads it's skulls and rock horns and corpses and lighters in a way the music on this LP is is just reflective of the Paulo Girardi oil painting that is slapped on the cover it's just a really gruesome display but it's the very melodic coloring that gives these grim edges flavor and depth and emotion there isn't much on tempest that I would say is catchy you're not really gonna commit much of this album to memory if you're just giving it a cursory listen I would say that's because this is more of an album to just get lost in and that's easy to do with just how huge this sound Lycus presents is on top of the fact that the melodies on this LP on these songs are constantly shifting but they occur and just sort of blossom at this very slow pace that keeps them engaging but also makes them sort of easy to take in even though these songs are just constantly winding there's details and and I guess variety on these tracks but but not so much it's dizzying even as the band layers on more guitars throws in more background vocals or even put strings which they do at several phases in these songs the opening track on this LP coma Byrne opens up with these minor toned harmonious chords that are just loud distorted blaring they just have this massive sound there's a ton of bass in this mix and then even though it's incredibly heavy it's not like this pummeling or overwhelming heaviness really it's more of an enveloping heaviness it's just vast it's open the more I listen to this record the more it feels like I'm sinking down into a swamp and the deeper down I go the more layers sort of pile on top of me one guitar on top of another guitar more vocals more bass the strings and what's so awesome is that this record is so freaking loud and yet all of these things are balanced really nicely in the mix later into the song coma burn you get these double bass drums and these harsher vocals it's really a visceral point on this track a blood pumping point especially with the tremolo pick Qatar's on this spot in the song thunderous riffs come later after this and the way that some of the chords resolved that the band is playing here at the end of the track it almost feels kind of uplifting or even positive as varied as some of these songs are when you listen to them closely that's one thing that I wish these tracks have a little bit more of not only that just positive beauty but those more just adrenaline fed moments most of this record shoots for an epically dreary vibe and that's fine because the band does incredibly well I just wish there were more visceral spots because it definitely would have given this LP a bit more of a flow because while I do enjoy the three tracks here a lot I don't really feel like I'm on a journey from beginning to end with the album but for sure each track in itself feels like a trip even the slower and more melodically layered track engravings the second song here even though it is a bit shorter than the opener and and it doesn't really have a hard hitting spot and it's nine minute runtime I think it may be my favourite track here just because of how beautiful some of the guitar phrasing is and the clothes are on here while it does end with with a seven minute drone which which I guess in a sense is giving this album some kind of closure it is really hypnotic spot on the LP and it does kind of provide some cool down time to make me feel like okay this is done but I I wouldn't necessarily say that the song is is any more epic or climactic than the two previous tracks I still think the heavy riffs and a lot of the guitar phrasing in the middle of the track are great and I do love the intro which feels very Grails like with its echo drenched guitars which are just shimmering and have a bit of a desert vibe to them I just wish the band did something a little bit more radical to it I do think in a sense they were conscious of the the either the limitations are just the very few elements that they were working with on these songs and they didn't want to overdo it or anything like that and only offered really just 40 minutes of music which if you're talking about metal of the style it's not really like Lycus is asking that much from the listener I guess aside from the playing and the melody writing the thing that can commend this album foremost is taking these ideas that that would normally require a listener to be really really patient and in a way sort of condense them down into a very succinct funeral doom metal record I'm feeling ad sense of strong seven on this thing if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it this review is my opinion if you don't like it here's a straw I want to give a shout out to Austin young lean and Milady's bread only the strong subscribe all mistakes were intentional Anthony Fantana tempest Lycus forever
