Miriam the believer hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new LP blood donation for miriam the believer you and me both Mary I wish you would bleed to death Miriam the believer or Miriam well Anton is a singer-songwriter guitarist star vocalist and one half of the eccentric Swedish musical duo wild birds and peace drums a project that she's been in for quite a while now with her husband Andrea swirl in wild birds and peace drums have put out handful of LPS and EPS since they started putting out studio material in 2007 a lot of the track songs and releases being sort of stripped back instrumentally featuring for the most part and Riis's drums as well as Merriam's vocals which I understand sort of sounds boring on paper but the thing is these two are actually really really skilled musicians with enough chops to keep these instrumentally stripped-back songs really interesting Miriam and her husband play with with quite a bit of intensity on some of these wild birds and peace drums songs and even though that is sort of a thrill to hear a thrill to experience it doesn't really add up much into sort of traditional coherent songwriting mostly because that's not what they're going for a lot of the time even as they work to incorporate more musical instrumentation and layers into their subsequent albums this new record of Merriam's though is a move toward the accessible maybe not a pop album sometimes an art pop album but overall just much smoother in terms of delivering accessible melodies and and just straightforward chord progressions Merriam's vocals are still rife with with personality and some really bold vocalizations and her husband's drumming is on this album as well but both of them feel relatively reserved in comparison to the wild birds and piece drums material probably in an effort to deliver some songs that are easier on the ears and allow the other instrumentation the guitar the synthesizers the bass to make it into the mix and sort of effectively play the roles that they have to play yes Miriam and her husband are sounding less bombastic but I'm still catching a lot of the stylistic influences that that you would catch on a wild birds project the soul music is here the jazz the rock but it's all sort of delivered with this more easygoing slightly eerie and in dark tinge rather than wild and free Miriam comes off feeling very alluring and moody on these tracks Merriam's vocals and the rest of the instrumentation are recorded and and produced to sound a little cavernous reverb II kind of distant but still there's an intimacy there on these tracks and everything comes in really clear especially Merriam's vocals and there are moments where Marian's voice sort of reminds me of the vocals of other artists maybe Victoria LeGrande from beach house on the track the string of everything one of the slower more dream pop influenced tracks on this album really jangly shimmering guitars on this song and Miriam seems to be reaching into these just low bellowing notes that remind me of Victoria's singing but of course throughout this track and many others Miriam proves herself to be much more of a nimble vocalist when she reaches into her upper register I hear slight flashes of Kate Bush there are moments where the the very mysterious vibe of this album remind me of Chelsea Wolf's last full-length LP but Merriam's volume her very commanding cadence and her jazzy phrasing with her vocals really sort of put her on a pedestal of her own now as far as the songwriting goes on this LP it is varied it's memorable and it's emotionally moving in about every direction Miriam tries to go in the opening track on your blood donation shimmering guitars marching drums and an anon chorus serve as a really theatrical backdrop for Merriam's fantastic vocal improv that track and others on here have some really smooth easy transitions between the verses and the choruses like the song the string of everything or the track first haiku one of the longer songs on here in Dubuque moving ballad really sweet slow pace and melody on this track and a wonderfully gorgeous sack solo to finish it all off there are several interlude tracks on the selfie as well and on the flip side of these more easygoing songs there are tracks that are still accessible but seem to work more in phases songs like dead meat which slows down speeds up changes groove over the course of shifting from a verse to a chorus and what also feels like a second chorus we have one course where Miriam is just reaching at the top of her vocal range and and shouting dead the other phases is more toned down but just as moving where Miriam is singing that everything she knows and feels is stuck and spiderweb I love the chord progression on this track - and the song invisible giving the longest track on this LP is maybe the most multi-phased on the entire LP it is a dark epic which kicks off with this incredibly fast and rhythmic drumming and guitar strumming the beginning also starts off with this murky bass line and with all this sort of subtle instrumentation Merriam's voices like this huge lightning bolt crashing down and the middle smack dab in the middle of the black black skyline and it's this boldness and it's this contrast that makes the song so engaging from beginning to end as it's changing from one idea to the next now for the wild birds and peace drums fan there are a few tracks on here that do sort of harken back to that stuff but do also blend into the tracklist of this album pretty nicely songs like somewhere else where Miriam is singing leave but also during her background vocals if you can call them that it's like she's recorded her lead vocals then recorded these just high-pitched howls and shouts with this sort of low five fuzzy clipping recording and it's like these vocals are placed or even sampled and just sort of played throughout the track as she's singing against them I'm loving the hard fast flamenco style groove on this track - as well as the swirling synth arpeggios and the song above the world has one of the kookiest sort of percussion sections on this entire album something I could totally see in the background of a birdsong now there are a few downsides on this I mean for one the interlude songs don't exactly wow me but they don't exactly tease me either making me feel like oh this needed to be longer and there are a few songs that I wish were a little more eventful like the track to belong or to let go one of the jazzier songs on the album with its groove and it's bass line which are very slow very smoky Merriam's vocalizations over the track are pretty the song does meet an abrupt end but still it's it's not like it really reaches a climax over the course of the song and the closure is somewhat anticlimactic as well even though miriam does do well on some of these more linear flowing songs these just for me are not two of the best still on this record I got to say overall Miriam has essentially proven herself to be a really captivating worthwhile and incapable songwriter and on top of that what what has already been known about her from previous musical efforts is that she's a fantastic singer with a voice that is a ton of personality as well as melodic sensibility and emotion considering how exuberant wild birds and piece drums records are it's not surprising that blood donation is exuberant as well just in a slightly darker way I'm feeling a decent strong eight on this album if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it this review has been my opinion if you don't hey everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd hairs growing in and it's time for a review of the new ghost poet album Samus o so as some say I so I say light this is the sophomore full-length LP from this uk-based rapper I first heard of him back in 2011 through the album peanut butter blues and melancholy Jam I wasn't huge on the LP but nonetheless I did kind of see it as this recent rise where I saw it as a part of this recent rise in alternative forms of hip hop artist alternative flavors and new faces in hip hop people like Danny Brown Shabazz Palaces Kendrick Lamar Milo Death Grips ASAP Rocky in Action Bronson 2 Action Bronson didn't start that you're a lot of the people who I just listed didn't start that year but they did come out with notable records that year that did manage to catch a lot of attention and for sure ghost poet had his own sort of approach that made him worth noting he had a lot of atmospheric beats on this LP a really sort of slow understated somewhat whispered flow vocal delivery to be honest ghost poet felt a lot more like a ghost than he did a poet considering just how obscured he was and and how hard it was to make out some of what he was saying in these tracks his really understated flow and his voice which was kind of smudged by effects and then some really low mixing for me personally made him come off much less than gripping I still admired his will to experiment though I was hoping that his next album would catch my ears a little bit more and I I guess I could say in a way that this sophomore album has though I'm not really in love with it for one ghost poet does diversify his sound his his vocal style his instrumentals with some beats on here that do feel hip-hop influenced but are much more electronic tracks on here have a pretty huge future Garage influences well with the instrumental a few moments here I would actually say our reminiscent of and furthermore some tracks like plastic bag brain the instrumental there it's it's essentially just a rock song instrumental a subtle Rock instrumental but still a rock instrumental now as far as ghost poets voice he's much more front-and-center much more audible his lyrics intelligible his emotions sort of tangible however after giving this LP a listen I can't really say maybe better production and just clearer vocals were what ghost poet needed if anything this album is is lacking a captivating vocal performance and and lyrics to back that up one track after another ghost poet delivers these haphazard sort of boring vocalizations he they just sound sort of silly at times and and for many tracks here as well he seems to be singing with this forcefully lethargic attitude it's like he's really too tired to put the emotion necessary to captivate an audience into his singing and it's not like he tries to hide his listless attitude for sure it's it's decidedly this way with some track titles on here like sloth trot or comatose however there's nothing on this LP musically lyrically or emotionally that makes me feel some kind of emotion in reaction to his sluggishness at the end of the day when I give a listen to this LP I just feel like I am a spectator to somebody else's rainy day or spilled milk I feel like a little bit I'm listening to the hip-hop equivalent to the new national record or something the prettiest thing on this record has got to be the instrumentals and there are some good instrumental choices on here these string sections at the end of comatose are great some of the more future garage influenced beats have nice grooves to them especially the opener and the synthesizer melody the very sort of simple synthesizer melody which has a driving groove to it on the song them waters it's it's very moody it's very electrified it's very nocturnal again I I like a lot of the instrumentals here but none of them are so redeeming that I'm really able to get into this new ghost poet and enjoy the songs as they currently are truth be told the this album really truly underwhelmed me and and there's not much more to it than that really if you've given the cell peal listen what did you think of it did you love band's first full-length LP since the 90s a lot of people who have been fans of them since then did seem to take to it even though the group did have their low points before they disbanded in the mid 90s they did manage to put out two of Death metals biggest classics albums loaded with memorable heavy and catchy ass riffs riffs that were on the heavier side of the death metal spectrum really bringing more of a doom metal flavor into the picture of course Chris reverts fantastic drumming and lead vocals make these albums death metal classics because the fact that he has one of the gruff estranged future and most unique vocals in death metal period but I think this new LP offers a little bit of a change of pace maybe not so much that people who are unimpressed by eternal would want to gravitate to this album instead the band is still kind of stuck in their old school death metal ways which is completely fine considering how good they are at that but I will say that Chris's vocals seem a little bit more under control or maybe rather in balance with the guitars the bass and the drums behind him I think the drumming actually has a much better recording on it this time around way less ambient noise on the snare the drums feel heavier be seer thicker and really the mix overall feels thicker the guitars on this thing are massive and I think they take advantage of that massiveness by emphasizing the slower side of the Bands style the more doom oriented side of the band style yes there are still faster moments on this LP you or autopsy he gives the listener these spiraling guitar leads and shredding against these really brutal blast beats but there are quite a few moments on this album where autopsy does all of a sudden out of nowhere just slow down bring these really do me do me spaced out riffs that because of this thicker mix are just rumbling they're just like the song slaughter at the beasts house which has a really fast introduction but two minutes in the song goes totally black sabbath totally tony iommi influenced Rivage then the band harmonizes it with some extra guitars then they strip it back to the bass and Chris gives this really chilling chilling vocal performance he's just putting his blood and his guts all over this track while I do like it when autopsy does go fast I love it even more when they contrast these faster moments with some slower more passionate and memorable moments maybe this memorability in this just emotional intensity is at its highest on the song she is a funeral it's the longest song on this LP spanning past seven minutes and Chris legitimately goes nuts on this song I was transfixed and the thing is behind his voice these very slow dreary guitar riffs in the background they bring a legitimately sad and and kind of tortured feeling to the song obviously the the title already makes me think that that it's about some sort of relationship heartbreak and whether it is or it isn't Chris really feels like he's in some kind of emotional pain on this track and it's not really just the the song subject that makes me think this it's also the bridge as well with these mid-paced chords that have these huge deep bellowing background vocals hanging behind it oh there's some harder highlights on this LP like running from the goat head which I think has some of the fastest shredding as' intro riffs on this entire LP and the song when hammer meets bone - as the sort of old-school heavy metal vibe to it but of course Chris with his vocals and the down-tuned guitars bring that death metal vibe even though I could pick out songs that I really really like they're just way too many I guess sort of shortcomings for this LP for me to really love it for one the album is shorter and and that doesn't necessarily make it a bad thing it is longer than some of the Bands classics but I feel almost as if they're kind of cutting and running on some of these songs without completely developing them or fleshing them out especially when you consider some of the longer tracks on this LP are fantastic with their multiple parts and that the band was writing some incredibly long songs on their last full-length LP the song coffin crawlers strangely enough enters with these really neatly medially moodily guitar leads just layered on top of one another and this really awesomely eerie tense way and I do think this is a great way to start the track but when the track finishes they just fade down all the instrumentation and then just mysteriously fade up these guitar leads once again only to fade them down only seconds later it felt like a really lazy way to end the song the song thorns and ashes I'm not really sure what to think of this track it feels like 1 minute and 46 seconds of of what could have been a song but the band just decided not to really make it a song and the closing track on this thing I feel the exact same way even though it does breach over the two-minute mark it is really only two interchanging riffs and and not really much of a song idea a few other tracks on here that I really enjoy fade out around the four three-minute mark which isn't necessarily a bad time to end a song it's just that I don't really feel like the band has developed these tracks in a way where they feel as if they should end and these points I mean for example the song arch cadaver that song just sort of melts away as it feels like it's getting its most psychotic energy together between Chris's vocals and the guitars it feels like there are moments where autopsy still has a few tricks up their sleeves but maybe they didn't want to take it that far on this record with every track and instead just kind of give something that would be easy to digest but unfortunately that's made these songs in my opinion a little less memorable and a lot less striking flawless thrilling really I'm feeling a decent strong six on this LP again if you highlight songs that I really like but other tracks that I wish took it further and really that's it if you've given this album a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and and that's it this review is my opinion if you don't like it here's a straw I'm gonna give a shout out to people only the strong subscribe all mistakes for intentional Anthony Fanta no autopsy forever you

Shannon hi everyone Anthony van tan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for your review of the new James Holden album the inheritors James Holden is an electronic music producer and DJ as well as the founder of border community records an electronic and experimental music label that has released dozens of LPS and EPS since it started in 2003 and essentially James is celebrating the 10-year long life of his label as well as his much longer career with a new sophomore album just sophomore album when it comes to material James is really more of a prolific remixer he has quite a few big names under his belt as far as people whose songs he has rearranged people like Madonna Mogwai Four Tet Britney Spears New Order Depeche Mode Radiohead he's obviously more of a quality over quantity kind of guy and if you are a fan who has been waiting for this new full-length LP you can't really say he held back in any way delivering over an hour of music across 15 tracks now like James last full-length LP this album is beautifully textured some really rough percussion pretty somewhat vintage synthesizers although maybe that vintage flavors turned up a little bit to the point where this record reminds me a little bit of another border community Records released Luke Abbott's Holcomb drones on my favorite electronic music LPS of 2010 there's quite a bit of variety on this LP wah-wah some tracks on here do get a little tedious even if they are very colourful songs like the Illuminations with all of these swirling synthesizer arpeggios caught within this very aged recording it feels like a little bit of Boards of Canada worship it's alright that Boards of Canada worship actually continues on other tracks here like summer spite as well as circle of fifths while it is very steeped in this influence what he's doing on these songs it is kind of noisy it is sharp it is sort of shrill and there are other tracks on here that sort of take a more ambient approach that lose me a little bit because of how disconnected they feel from any sort of real tangible feeling still the more that I listen to this album and the more I sort of look at the artwork another thing that I'm not really crazy about on this LP there is sort of a theme a concept that runs throughout most of this album and for me it kind of starts with the album cover where we have a rock carving something that we typically associate with the idea of primitive life something that's a rudimentary but what's actually carved into the rock if you observe it closely is very clean it's straight it's not some kind of crudely drawn Buffalo or anything like that the symbols on this rock seem almost as if they're beyond human comprehension like they're futuristic or maybe even alien and that's sort of the dichotomy that this album explores you have something that feels in a lot of ways technologically advanced but kind of has a very old soul to it you've essentially got a lot of these simple basic visceral primeval musical ideas being executed through electronics through new technology it kind of reminds me of the balance that was struck on that Africa hi-tech album that I enjoyed so much a few years ago except James approaches it with different musical influences and styles on the inheritors James performs a lot of IDM micro house techno a little bit of progressive synthesizer an ambient music and James doesn't really blend all of these ideas together into cohesive tracks really he genre hops from song to song to song like the songs Ranade or the title track from the cell P which are really amazingly produced progressive and riveting techno songs very noisy dirty rough kind of simple and they're very linear grooves and each of these tracks also are colored with really intense and complex synthesizers Ranade has these tremolo very fast waves of sense just pulsating quickly and on the title track the synths are really sharp they're blaring there screeching across the track making it even more hot and heavy than Ranade that ambient route comes up again on songs like self playing schmaltz or sky burial but some of the chords and some of the melodies on these tracks feel really sinister and dark I don't really feel like I'm listening to something that is pre civilization like I think the theme on this album is but rather post civilization the songs feel like the the very desolate aftermath of some kind of great tragedy but maybe the best tracks on this LP in my opinion are the ones where we get those primeval and acoustic instrumentation elements mixed in with the electronics songs like caterpillars intervention where the plucks strings and the blaring saxophones and the really hard constant hypnotic again primal beat makes the song feel like a dance around a campfire with a drum circle other songs on here like circle inside a circle the opener and gone feral as well take these electronic elements and mix them with percussion that feels like it was played with hands or at least just sounds like sampled hand percussion while it is electronic it has a very natural kind of rootsy feel to it in a way and I really like that I think these tracks are some of the most unique moments that this album has to offer if this album was going to try to go forward with this theme I would love to hear more tracks to sort of take it at this angle because these songs to me are among the most memorable on this album but really for me the odd man out on this LP is the song 7 stars which has kind of these gothic piano chords and melodic flourishes throughout the track it's in 3 4 it's very moody waltz and while it is very electronic and it is very noisy and has a nice huge climactic finish I'm not really seeing where this song fits and with the rudimentary vibes that I get from the other melodies and and the other grooves on this LP rather the song feels very civilized very refined overall I did really really enjoy this LP it had a lot of songs that I enjoyed it just came down to being a mixed bag of tracks with a very loose too loose of a concept really a lot of tracks stuck out to me as being great very bold mixtures of old ideas and new sounds some tracks are really unique pieces of techno a few are very underwhelming a few more kind of drown in their influences but if you're into electronic music and you something really textured and you want something that's colorful and and something that is above all things just tense will kind of keep you on the edge of your seat do give the inheritors a listen I'm feeling a light a decent seven on this thing if you've given it a listen did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it this review is my opinion if you don't like it here's a straw I want to give a shout out to Pyrex Agustin CGT Esperanza it's a - Billy woods and Vincent only the strong subscribe all mistakes were intentional Anthony Fantana bulette forever you

jay-z had his new baby talking about that for sure he was going to roll out all these really corny daddy lines making fun of him putting out lyrics that were that were fake saying things like he's audience than he does the relationship with his baby not to get caught up in one song though because there are tracks on this LP that I like I do dig the opener on this album a lot of you may remember to be with me you know I got it with Rick Ross where jay-z just really throws his flow in the toilet really into the toilet to the point where I'm not even interested in what he's delivering lyrically Billy woods hi everyone Anthony Fantino here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Billy woods album Billy woods is a mysterious DC based rapper who kind of jump-started his long-running solo career with an incredibly dark topical lyrical and moody hip-hop album last year history will absolve me and as far as woods rap style goes he has this flow that sort of blurs lines between rapping and spoken word sort of ranting and the way Billy delivers these lyrics comes off really forceful convincing the meaning of what Billy is saying for the most part hits at least me very instantaneously because he tries his best to be a very vivid storyteller a communicator and emotion conveyor and the guy makes some really great production choices as well which brings me to why door candy is sort of a unique moment for Billy in his career he's got all the production handled by one single person a pretty popular underground hip hop producer blockhead who of course is most famous for his work with Aesop Rock when I first heard of Billy working with a producer for the length of an entire album on this new project I was pretty excited about the concept potential behind door candy and I gotta say after numerous listens to this album there is a significant theme at least if not a story running through this album and it's a theme that really delivers on the title here you have the word door which isn't an often used word but means things like gloomy severe and candy which i think is sort of a piece of symbolism for drugs which are often mentioned throughout this LP and not just really doing them or getting addicted to them having them ruin your life mostly selling them it's really a story of someone who was living really small time while selling drugs and just kind of the life that this person is leading and and this story may be more personal than Billy lets on and on top of this blockhead lends some really good production to this LP not incredibly layered or flashy or anything like that there are a few moments that get really melodic and and sort of progressive like his old Aesop Rock production but for the most part the instrumentals on the cell P feel eerie they feel rough they set the stage for something that feels like some crimes are going to be committed some harsh realities are going to be exposed it's one grimy sample after another in kick drums and snares that don't so much boom or bang but really just sort of thud still the roughness of these beats doesn't stop blockhead from getting really creative with what he samples or the pace of his rhythms or the the detail in his rhythms like the song Manteca which has these really odd old like old man vocals singing against these very weird synthesizer leads or the depressing chords and descending bass guitar on the track Gilgamesh which has these birds sampled throughout the chorus too for a hip-hop beat it really sounds like a funeral march and the track poachers which has a strong desert vibe to it the song tinseltown one of my favorite tracks on here does have more of an old-school blockhead vibe to it and while I love the sad soulful horns on the track 1,001 nights I wish this song got developed a little bit more into something with maybe a little bit more structure because it feels like this same horn sample is just being repeated over and over I don't know they're just some songs where I wish they hit a little harder made a bit more impact like the the potentially great posse track on here fool's gold with open mike eagle mocha only lucid and billy woods on the track to the beat in my opinion really sort of meanders and when it does change the things that adds to the equation are not really that interesting like the very weak synth melodies that that occur under the second and fourth verses on this track as far as Billy's rap style I'm not really seeing a whole lot of change between this LP and history will absolve me he sounds just as passionate and focused as he did last year maybe what he's saying comes off a little more coded but the more I listen to it the more vivid this image becomes and the more I feel like this is what Billy had been doing with his life maybe up until the point when he kind of started his rap career because he does throw in images of cops extortion DA's busting through the wall like the kool-aid guy paranoia dim prospects girlfriends and old flames all while throwing some moral undertones under all of it like forgetting about the golden rule for a few pieces of silver I could be wrong about how non-fictional this story is but Billy doesn't really seem unafraid to toss in a reference here and there to his rapping or his rap career which he does on the song hack he does on the song Central Park where he reminisces a little bit about helping kids out with their fractions in measuring product out but this is one of the few moments where Billy goes into the technical and descriptive side of selling drugs really for the most part he's painting a picture of this person's life while this career move is kind of going on like on the song poachers where he seems to be getting involved with the family of someone that he knows who got arrested and taken away by the police for what I assume is what Billy has been rapping about there are a lot of great spots like this on this LP my issue is that toward the end I really sort of feel like this picture this image this story whatever you want to call it falls apart a little bit and he doesn't consistently deliver more imagery or just develop more curves or more corners in this shape that he's trying to create and I don't necessarily feel like the features on this album either add to the story that door candy tells overall I did enjoy this album a lot but I do feel like Woods's portrait could have come in clear the production could have been a little bit more memorable at some points but still I do feel like in a way door candy is a more ambitious move for Billy woods and if he continues to work with the kind of storytelling that that attempts to reach from the first track of an album to the last track of an album I could see an even greater project coming from him in the future I'm feeling a decent strong seven on this thing if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it this review is my opinion if you don't like it here's a straw I want to give a shout out to Egypt as well as feeding to records all mistakes were intentional only the strong subscribe Billy woods the needle drop blockhead forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Jarren Benton album my grandmother's basement this guy is Georgia MC this is basically his his first big commercial project it's out now on funk volume which is a label you may already know thanks to artists like dizzy Wright as well as Hopson and with the height building behind him now it looks like Jaron might become one of their next big artists as well because on this new group of tracks he definitely has flow personality and some good instrumental picks as well a lot of the beats actually come from a producer who goes by the name of Cato who brings quite a few impressive and very heavy trap style bangers to these 19 songs there are a few other beats here that go for different styles as well a few boom BAPS some more ethereal tracks that have more melody to them basically kind of setting a foundation for Jaron to say something a little more meaningful the variety across these songs is is okay at best it's not fantastic it doesn't bring a whole lot of versatility to the table if anything the 19 songs here lay a little too heavy on those trap style beats with jarran going absolutely nuts on the mic which is actually pretty fun at first and led to some really great singles on this LP especially the songs on the first half of this album but it does get a little stale by the second half even though Jaron is really great I mean it is one of his strengths to be kind of cartoony and and ridiculous with his punchlines Jaron really is a great a talker he strikes me as a guy who growing up might have had something clever or smart or foul to say to just about anybody who got in his face to kind of give you a picture of the sort of dude Jaron is the guy steps right on the throat of Tyler the Creator comparisons right at the start of one of the tracks on this LP but he does sort of welcome Eminem comparisons and even compares himself a little bit to Andre 3000 down the road I guess in sense due to his very fast flow and southern slant though I do think the mmm comparison is a little more legitimate especially since gerund tends to be very in-your-face sort of violent wild he also has Vinny paths as well as RA the rugged man on this album doing features and it really does sort of take a certain kind of MC to want to invite guys like that onto your tracks plus the flow Jaron works with on the track razor blades and steak knives it sounds like something right from the Slim Shady LP and I would say there are some moments on this album where Jaron is just as creative with some of his weird-ass punchlines like off-the-wall like up drywall he's also rapping quite a bit on this LP about quadriplegics being a male chauvinist who hits his girl with a bowl of grits at times Jaron can be a little much and and some of the things he says it really kind of feels like wow he's really trying to get attention here isn't me there are quite a few tracks on on this LP that fit that bill songs like don't act or Cadillacs and Chevys which is actually one of the catchy er songs on this LP but right at the start of the song he says hey I'm gonna say on the verses and we'll just do a hook whatever I get this sense from Jaron mentioning this on his album and from some of the better tracks on this LP that on my grandmother's basement maybe in a way Jaron isn't really trying as hard as he possibly could because the descriptions of his life growing up and sort of the bad decisions that he's made on the song life in the jungle which has a chorus on it that reminds me a lot of some production from the cruel summer compilation it's actually a fantastic track Jaron actually gets deeper on song dreams as well not only about his personal life but the plight of sort of growing up poor growing up uneducated again he tries to go into a deeper shade of storytelling on the song heart attack something that I think a lot of people will think of Eminem when you listen to this track considering that he's vexed over his girlfriend leaving him he basically goes psychotic over the whole ordeal sadly enough they're they're not enough songs like this on this LP even those songs like smells like and and bully with Vinnie Paz are great cuts toward the back end of this LP I do think the second half of the album does sort of get a little stale because Jaron doesn't continue to deliver this deeper shade of storytelling and introduce some new ideas because there are a lot of hooks on the second half of this LP that remind me of hooks from the first half Jaron does sort of throw a lot of his feature tracks on the latter half of this LP to maybe it was sort of an attempt to kind of keep things fresh and keep things engaging break things up a little bit and not keep the album feeling Sammy Sammy but I mean at least that that didn't happen for me anyway overall I did like this project I thought it was pretty good I think Jaron has a lot of personality and potential as an MC is it fully realized on this album I wouldn't say so I mean if anything this album feels like just a mixed bag of tracks some of which are deeper some of which hardcore fans are really going to like but a lot of songs I think we're put together just for the sake of getting another popular MC on the track getting some kind of cross promotion thing there and just putting together a lot of bangers that have sort of single potential if you've given this LP listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana Jarren Benton forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for you review of the new Kyary Pamyu Pamyu album nonde collection Kyary Pamyu Pamyu is a japanese blogger singer model pop star one of the biggest pop stars over there right now thanks to her his singles her quirky aesthetic that is so eye and ear catching that she's caught quite a bit of attention over here in the West as well now if you're really going to talk about key Ahri's music seriously you can't really go without mentioning Yasutaka Nakata a multi project songwriter producer and DJ who has been working in the Japanese music industry for years and even though he is well known for working with Kyary this is not the first time he's produced music for a female Japanese pop star it just so happens that Kyary is one of the more bold faces in Japanese pop music that he's worked with so far and I don't just mean in terms of her clothing and the individual aesthetics that come in her music videos I mean that is an entirely different video review in itself thank you I actually think Harry's music by his self qualifies as being pretty eccentric within that Japanese pop music realm now Japanese pop music is is typically characterized as being pretty upbeat bouncy very bright as well these are typically the things that people notice first about aside from the language barrier and the very youthful voices of the singers in this genre and all of those characteristics definitely show up on nonde collection except I would say that Yasutaka and Kyary up the ante with some very creative colorful and and sometimes zany sounds an instrumentation some of the keyboard sounds and since I'm not a collection are so silly that at times it kind of feels like Jay pops answer to pee-wee's Playhouse what I just want to say to you is that when you listen to this LP don't quick to assume that what's going on here is just normal for the genre and that it's just sort of run-of-the-mill that sort of conclusion is easy to jump to when one there is a language barrier and two you're really disconnected from the culture that the music comes from which is so far outside of the context that you're currently living in when you give a listen to this record and you're asking yourself why does it sound so hyper and colourful and fun well I mean it sounds like all those things because it actually is all those things it's not like there's any kind of secret code or anything going on here as far as I can tell another assumption I would be pretty hesitant to make is that Kyary is essentially Japan's answer to Lady gaga for one Kyary is not the first eccentrically dressed person from Japan and even though Lady Gaga has been known to wear some pretty weird outfits I personally though I do enjoy some of her older stuff don't really see a lot of that eccentricity bleed into her music I actually see many of the tracks on nonde collection as being even more experimental than the songs from kyary's previous album which really helped her break into the Japanese musical mainstream the song invader invader one of the bigger singles off of this LP and one of my favorite tracks - feels like a song that was composed by j-pop robots from another planet presenting these really wonky synthesizer melodies this one portion in the song that feels like a dubstep drop it happens for like five seconds although it's not really heavy and abrasive and overwhelming like most dubstep drops it's actually kind of small and cute and tiny and farty I actually see it as more of a self-aware playful reference to dubstep music than it is an attempt to try to cross over to dubstep fans outside of that I'm loving the zany vocal melodies all over this chat and the song me is incredibly fun and playful and just ridiculous with its vocal melody Mee Mee Mee Mee Mee Mee Mee Mee Mee for some reason like when I hear this song I imagine some kind of dance going on that involves this again we've got another melody that feels very oriental feels much older than the record that it's it's being presented on but the sounds the groove and all the instrumentation it feels very modern it feels hyper colorful this song feels like nighttime people out in the streets having a fun time eating laughing talking it's just a party and and that's what I love about a lot of tracks on this LP even as some of the moments on here get even more eccentric with some odd piano melodies and in one track toward the end of this thing that that feels kind of polka inspired my one letdown on this LP is that there are a handful of songs that feel maybe a little too straightforward a little too toeing that Jpop line to feel special or even memorable the beats and the melodies on tracks like saigo no ice cream as well as kamini 100% maybe these songs to me are some of the least distinct on the LP there's actually a capsule cover on here as well capsule being a musical project that Yasutaka was involved with before he was involved with Kyary which is a hell of a tune it's it's really melodic and it's really fun but again not one of the more interesting tracks for me sonically or instrumentally especially with the very cheesy slightly jazzy synth trumpet playing throughout this song to still even though I'm not head over heels for the sounds that these songs are presenting for the most part I still enjoyed them to an extent I'm not really disliking much of anything on this LP to be completely honest track four track four track we're talking about really sharp melody writing that is so sticky is just so infectious that I think it really transcends the the language barrier thing for me at least personally tons of incredibly vibrant sounds and and since fermentation in a variety of tracks that present different modes of playfulness and and and weirdness I would not say it all that this record is for ironic enjoyment or should be enjoyed from the perspective of oh this is just different because it's not from my country and so on and so forth personally I see this record is kind of being like a gigantic layer-cake that is taller than me maybe clearing my head by five feet and I have been given permission to just literally dive in and eat as much of it as I want maybe after eating a few slices conservatively on a plate I would just stick my face in Ingo even if there are a handful of songs on here that I'm just a little on the fence with I'm feeling a strong seven to a light eight on this thing if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why and that's it this review is my opinion if you don't like it here's a straw I want to give a shout out to vic mensa chuck strangers Dave Reynolds Dominique and is Elia banks Azealia you forgot your tweet where did this go where did this go I guess that tweet got deleted I guess that tweet got deleted only the strong subscribe all mistakes were intentional Anthony Fantana Kyary Pamyu Pamyu forever [Music]

hi everyone Anthony fan tano here the Internet's busiest means the data and it's time for a quick review of the new death side album random access memories memories Daft side or dark side is the musical project the musical collaborative project between dave harrington and music producer electronic music producer nicolas jar so oddly enough these guys have gotten together and they have done a song for song remix of the new Daft Punk album random access memories one of this year's most hyped and polarizing music releases for sure the record did get quite a bit of critical acclaim but there were a lot of fans that were really split on this album considering how disjointed it was considering that they didn't really go down their usual house-music route or anything like that and even though Dave and and Nicholas are remix in this new Daft Punk album it's almost as if there is a slight very small noticeable voice of dissent in this remix album they obviously enjoy quite a few cuts from random access memories or they enjoy ideas from it but I don't know if this album feels celebratory or anything like that for one there are some songs on here like game of love and beyond that really do maintain a lot of the musical characteristics of the tracks that are being remixed maybe they adjust the speed of the songs a little bit but the bass lines and the rhythm guitars throughout these tracks are pretty as is in terms of how they feel how they sound the grooves that they're playing not to say that the songs are untouched or anything like that Dave and and Nicholas really transform these songs which were very disco influenced and not overtly electronic at all into tracks that are just skeletal straightforward very effective micro house tunes on the other hand songs like get lucky and give life back to music especially the latter of those to undergo some serious transformations give life back to music has an incredibly noisy rickety drum beat that is sharp with the the equalization of the drum sounds just really there's a lot of treble there's all these metallic clangs and tones inside of the beat as well and the guitars and the vocals are just hanging very murky like behind all of these noisy percussive sounds the song get lucky though is is much darker than its original the pop of this song the pop element of the song is sucked right out of the equation and instead some weirder some weirder just odder guitars are thrown into the mix and when the groove of the song finally reveals itself even then it's still a pretty moody track this song is not up all night to get lucky then there are other tracks like fragments of time and touch tracks that I also enjoy but outside of the the very hefty use of samples of the vocal cuts from those songs the tracks are nearly unrecognizable I enjoy the majority of the songs on this remix album but I can't say I was head-over-heels for the whole thing it does take a little bit to start you know does take its time with beginning songs like contact and within one because they split the song within into two parts throughout the album they start the LP off and they're really more ambient noisy spacious not really bringing a groove or anything like that then once give life back to music kicks in then it really feels like the album starts these song lose yourself to dance while I do think Nick and Dave are making a pretty funny statement by making their remix of this track just two seconds long I do feel like there was a pretty I don't know a missed opportunity on this track because they could have turned it into something fun I think because while that song I think is one of the weaker cuts off of random access memories so is instant crush with Julian Casablanca sand they managed to remix that track really well the song doing it right which is one of my favorites off of random access memories with the way that Nicholas and Dave do the vocal sample on this track the way they manipulate it pitch shift it and then repeat it uh-uh it gets borderline annoying and on the song Giorgio I feel like the string section is that they sample on that don't exactly sync up entirely with the beat that they're putting behind it and and with the way that they equalized and mix the beat in the way that they sort of thinned out the strings maybe to kind of cancel out all the other instrumentation just kind of keep those chords keep those melodies and and musical phrases there's definitely some kind of distance there's a real lack of connection between the strings that they're trying to sample and the beat overall I I thought this was a fun listen it's something that I see myself returning to definitely yeah because I am a Nicholas jar fan I love The Dude's production I love his approach to creating electronic music and and for sure that shows up in a really big way on this album but maybe this LP too even if you're not a Nicholas jar fan might appeal to you a bit more than what Daft Punk actually did considering how split some fans were on on this album even if it is micro house and it's not hard hitting it's not banging it's not really poppy and catchy and just burning it is more house oriented than random access memories is give it a listen let me know what you think do you love this thing hate it why what should i review next and that's it random access memories memories deft side

Locrian hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's been a bit of a and it's time for a review of the new low korean album return to annihilation these guys were a Chicago band a three-piece and for about ten years now they've been toiling under the radar making all kinds of experimental rock music turning out numerous records sometimes a few within the span of one year and the music on these records is usually a twisted cauldron of black metal post Rock drone noise dark ambient music as well the band really emphasizes texture sound dynamics and intensity to over everything else you know things like a strong melody or accessibility and the band makes this pretty mountainous music on their new album as well on what at times feels like a shoestring budget there is definitely a slightly low fight quality to the music on this album there's a lot of ambient noise room noise surrounding some of the instruments like the drums the recording is a little rickety it's a little loose a little noisy but the sounds are still very heavy rich and vivid it's just a recording that's got a some character to it I would say you know it's got a lot of blemishes on I suppose but the performances are there the sounds are there now similar to artists like Tim Hecker or Boards of Canada for example the music that Locrian makes is incredibly visual its cinematic it's very thematic there are actually some pretty strong themes on this album I would say of Apocalypse vastness desolation and they embrace these feelings with some really raw drums some tattered distorted keyboards some heavy bass and some very bouncy echo drenched guitars even though the elements that look Korean works with on this record are very simple they do create some very strong moods with them using a lot of repetition throughout these tracks to really create a place in in my mind that I can sort of freely wander through as I'm listening to it some of the tracks on this record it's not like the songs really have a a beginning point and an end point per se it's not like they have a strong progression it's like they just are they're static they stay there's a lot of stillness in these tracks like the track exiting the Hall of vapor and light which has these distorted keyboards some wandering guitars in a very patient beat it is a very repetitive song but it feels like the more the band repeats these ideas over and over and over the more real and and the more vivid this soundscape they're creating becomes the more I feel as if I'm in it it's almost as if I kind of want that repetition I'm looking for it because what Locrian is creating in this song it's so evocative however sometimes the repetition sort of works against locrians favor because the sounds that they're working with or the music that they're playing it's it's really not that evocative it's not that moving like these stumbling guitar leads throughout the track to moons which I'm really sort of cold toward or the song of visitation from the wrath of heaven which has this huge monstrous ending which breaks in suddenly reminds me of something Mogwai used to do on their older stuff and I love the finish the instrumentation is really thick it's heavy there's so much texture flying at me at once it's overwhelming but the span of six minutes in between this point and the intro where the band is really repeating on this primal drumbeat these weird reverse melodies that are cycling over and over and over I I guess I'm not then thrall dwith this interlude the end is amazing but the journey on the way there is just not that stellar I just wish it were a little more engaging like the second half of this LP actually like the title track on here which is actually pretty multifaceted it starts off with these just rich twangy hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here Internet's busiest music nerd and we're gonna do a quick review of the new Black Sabbath album thirteen Black Sabbath from the UK Godfather's of doom metal legendary metal band a band that I constantly recommend if if people ever say to me Anthony how do you get into metal listen too early Black Sabbath albums not only can you just not go wrong with any of the band's initial LPS the self-titled paranoid master of reality the hits go on and and what's cool is that great records from this band continued to come out even after they switched lead singers from Ozzy Osbourne to Ronnie James Dio but now with 13 we're dealing with with basically the first Black Sabbath album to have Ozzy on it since like the 70s and we're working with an original lineup on this LP - except for drummer Bill Ward unfortunately actually Brad Wilk of Rage Against the Machine have replaced him on this LP for all the studio sessions and as much as I love Rage Against the Machine and I know Brad Wilk to be an incredibly capable drummer still just all the changes all the time just all the weak solo projects it all just maybe very skeptical to listen to this album the the the Frank Zappa and the mothers of invention album title were only in it for the money comes to mind when I gave this album a listen I I did get the sense that Ozzy Iommi and geezer are just really not messing around for one osses vocals on the rest of this album outside of the goddess dead track are way more on point and at times sounding pretty sinister even though Ozzy hasn't always been with Sabbath he's never really stopped singing throughout his career so it's not like he needs to kind of get back in gear with that or anything there have been critics of how Ozzy has performed in the live setting as of late but in regards to putting together the performances for this album I mean Ozzy's vocals came out good maybe he's not coming as extreme as he used to but for sure I mean he sounds captivating he sounds like his signature self and not to mention the really awesome harmonica solo on the track damaged soul it really feels like Black Sabbath is taking us back to the old days with Ozzy doing that and Tony Iommi's riffs they're heavy they're slow they're just dark but there is a little bit of a lack of momentum to them a lack of groove to them there isn't this vast chilling creepy openness to them that made a lot of the band's previous work just so eerie and for the most part the reason that is is because of the the very bad production choices that happen on this album there's just way too much volume and compression on this LP I just don't know what was up with Rick Rubin producing this album Black Sabbath they come from a time when there wasn't an extreme amount of compression being laid upon every single track in modern metal music because let's face it metal music more than most genres abuses distortion and compression because everybody's got to be the hardest the heaviest and the loudest and I feel like Black Sabbath felt some kind of pressure to compete in that lane unfortunately instead of just kind of letting the natural and fantastic tones and sounds of the guitars and bass shine through and that's another thing the extreme use of compression on this album really buries geezers bass to the point where you can't even really make out what it's doing half of the time I know that there are modern records that make use of this that do sound good and you know I I'm not taking anything away from them but Black Sabbath they play in a style that sounds better when it's not choked off with compression as good as some of the songwriting is on this album I can't help but feel like the sound could be so much better I actually think even Brad Wilkes drums suffer a little bit at the hands of just Tony Iommi's guitars being fattened and turned up all the way and in terms of just really structuring these songs Ozzy and company are not screwing around either they're not writing really short tracks with cutting out and just and leaving and turning in the other direction I mean they have delivered over ten songs here that a lot of them land in the seven eight-minute mark Black Sabbath is coming off pretty ambitious with their songwriting and their padding these songs out justifying these lengths with multiple parts moments where things speed up really awesome solos to be completely honest the solos are really the most riveting thing on this album aside from some of the vocal performances and the harmonica the solos are really where Tony lets loose and and and makes this record feel kind of wild and free which is really necessary given how much the compression and and everything else kind of locks it flattens it and makes it feel slightly lifeless no way this thing is going to be one of my favorite Black Sabbath records ever but I actually am am pretty surprised that it did not come out as horrible as I thought it would I actually did come out of this thing liking a lot of the tracks I just wish the sound was better you know even though I think the songs are good and I think technically the performances were all on point I I just think the sound should have been reconsidered you know I mean if Black Sabbath was gonna go all the way back and try to really recapture the magic of their older stuff by writing songs in a similar vein and believe me there are even riffs on this album that sounds similar to riffs from their first four records if they were gonna go back and try to recapture that magic playing wise technically they could have at least attempted to recapture that as well through just the sound of the instrumentation the sound of the production that's pretty much my take on this LP if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana Black Sabbath [Music] you

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new smith westerns record soft will this is the third full-length LP from the chicago illinois pop rock act i first heard of them back in 2011 through their second full-length LP daya blonde and album that i enjoyed quite a few songs from with this LP sketchy songwriting and really bubbly mood it was easily some of the most blissed-out indie pop of 2011 and it wasn't blissed-out because of too much reverb or anything like that mostly it was Kandi Koated melodies kaleidoscopic choruses that bursts like fireworks but even with all of this melodic beauty and just really strong pop sensibilities throughout these tracks there was a small very tiny element of sadness in the band's music like white like as I was listening to these tracks I was imagining every member of the band apathetically playing the songs with a single tear streaming down every one of their faces for sure there is a really sentimental element to their take on on very jangly pop rock there were quite a few tracks from from their last record in this new record - that actually reminds me a bit of girls debut LP however this was not an album that I was totally head-over-heels for that I was completely in love with I felt that the vocals were sort of obscured and then some of the songs more ambitious beautiful moments were really choked off by the sort of low five recording quality however better recording quality comes through on soft will and sort of rides in and saves the day like a knight in shining armor making soft will I think my favorite Smith westerns record well is Langa's were sharing favorites the wild wild west is my favorite Will Smith Western I hate Cal Church esta but seriously soft will is is a pretty big improvement on the band's last record I think with the very boyish vocals the slightly jangly guitar chords the very sharp guitar leads all coming in loud and clear in HD 1080p the band does bring a good mix to their sound this time around you could really swim through there really heavenly approach to rock music and I think this clarity makes their mix of influences really obvious this time around too and in a good way pop rock psychedelic pop piano rock and I think a little bit of progressive rock too with the song 23 the only instrumental on this album sounding exactly like something Pink Floyd would have done with some really epic guitar soloing and some slow drumming ethereal piano keys the only real downside to this track is that it doesn't really fit in with the flow of the rest of the album which is pretty much just a very nice mixed bag of pop rock songs and even though pop music at least today is stereotyped a lot to be very light and very breezy at least I can tell that Smith westerns really labored over these tracks put them together and really took a particular approach to writing these guitar melodies whether it be lead one the lead on top of that lead the bass line underneath it all the vocal melody all of it really winding and intertwining weaving bing-bing-bing-bing together and complementing one another at every turn in the song structure hell of a sparkling synth melody is all over the track the opening track 3 a.m. spiritual as well as the huge chorus vocals wow yeah the bass feels really warm in the mix the drums have a nice punch to them the vocals are right up front and center in the spotlight and the synthesizers add this indescribable thickness to this to this track and others too that really makes me feel like I'm listening to the band live and I'm seeing this fog roll in from a fog machine or maybe some laser lights it's just this really beautiful extra piece of ambience and the piano changed toward the end of the track that leads into a really great guitar solo the band really switches things up suddenly in a very sort of let it be Abbey Road type fashion it's a great climactic ending with the vocals growing larger and larger and larger and this is one of many tracks on this LP that actually has a pretty nice ending to it with the band adding an extra guitar lead or totally changing the flow of the song the groove of it up like the song idle which introduces a totally different part of the song with a new vocal against these downstroke guitar chords or full-proof which has one of the best guitar leads on this entire album the band's ballads get incredibly slow and sort of dramatic too with tracks like white oath which is one of the moments on this album where the lyrics really stand out singing about chain-smoking you're days away writing poetry that no one ever really reads and even though the lyrics here are pretty nice the vocals do feel like the weakest link in the chain where they're straining to reach a certain note or maybe they're not really controlling the pitch that they're singing all that well there's a really strong element of why ninis of wimpiness to the vocals that sort of reminds me of a very early of montreal records but no matter what shortcomings soft will does deliver up from time to time it's really the instrumentation the production and just the songwriting that that shines through immensely because even on songs like cheer up and best friend where I'm not totally in love with the vocals I'm still completely enthralled with the melodies I thought pretty much all of these songs were solid and an incredibly enjoyable at its worst this album is a really good summer record for 2013 I'm feeling a strong 7 - a light 8 on this thing if you've given it a listen what did you think of it what did I review next and that's it this review is my opinion if you don't like it here's a straw I want to give a shout out to people who have dreams about me and Cal Church esta Mike C town zombie and 160k thank you only the strong subscribe all mistakes were intentional Anthony Fantana Smith westerns forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for your review of the new havoc album unnatural selection havoc is a Denver Colorado thrash metal outfit this is their third full-length LP if you remember I loved their previous full-length album time's up one of my favorite metal albums of 2011 on that LP they took a ton of influence from bands such as Megadeth who I think they sort of borrow from the most overkill and anthrax too and they really took to copying these these very old-school thrash metal vibes with a lot of passion and gusto and making them translate pretty well to this very modern beefy production sound now the production quality from their debut LP two times up I mean it was a pretty nice transition enough to make times up a worthwhile change in sort of a peak in their career however there is just not as much daylight between a natural selection and times up sonically or stylistically I mean the production is roughly the same the gang vocals are still there the solos are in roughly the same style the riffs as well maybe the drum sounds have changed a little bit going for more of that kind of very punchy plastic e sound that a lot of modern metal bands really enjoy having in their songs the vocals are definitely a little more over the top which can be a bit of a double-edged sword I think it can make this album more memorable for some people but it's to the point where they can become a little too much maybe corny some of the singing that the vocals attempt can be somewhat off as opposed to the gruff somewhat high-pitched shouting that goes into a havoc album that is very early Dave Mustaine esque and the lyrics definitely take a much more political tone on this record too government is spying on us don't tread on me kind of thing which is actually pretty relevant for this time there were socially aware lyrics on their last full length but they had more of an apocalyptic theme on them a lot of war imagery too and there are some other topics covered as well like on the song waste of life honestly natural selection really does feel in a big way like a sequel a direct sequel to time is up except maybe a little less catchy I do think that there are songs on here that havoc is not writing them with as much pomp but I I think shot-for-shot this album is every bit as good as time's up the issue for me personally though is just that it's a little stale to me what havoc is trying to do on this record which essentially is just a Xerox of their previous record and you know I do realize that they are kind of chasing after a style that's kind of their thing but the very meat and potatoes approach that they took to playing thrash metal was sort of made up for by how catchy their last LP was with this one just not being up to snuff in that regard and the band kind of hammering through this blueprint as opposed to sort of building on it or trying some new things with it it makes a natural selection kind of a forgettable listen even if some of the grooves that the riffs pump out are pretty good basically that's my take on the album overall if you've given this thing a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and and that's it Anthony Fantana havoc you

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a question comment thing that have been kind of wondering about something we've had quite a few examples of over the past few years something we've been really hyped over as of late and that is comebacks what the heck is a comeback especially in the Internet age back in the day when bands would break up and then reform after an extended period of time it would seem that that would be a comeback but now with the internet and social media and just the idea of the hype cycle being the central force when it comes to album sales and buzz building not only do labels like to sell the idea of a comeback but audiences really like to buy into it - oh my god this artist hasn't put out an album in a long time it's come back question do you necessarily need to break up as a band in order to have a comeback like let's say it took you 20 years to come out with your next album but you never formally broke the band up or really even stopped hanging out or writing music it just took you a long time to come out with the new album or what if the band broke up or was put on hiatus for just about a year or two years and then came out with a new album immediately after the Reformation is the album that took a few years for the band to release more of a comeback album than the album that took 20 years to be released just because the band formerly broke up and what happens if you're a single person and not a group of people did the same rules still apply what about Justin Timberlake it took him a while in order to come through and actually put out a new full-length album which of course he did this year but before he actually put out the 20/20 experience it's not really like he left the public eye in fact Justin's stayed pretty popular through regular appearances in Saturday Night Live and some pretty popular movies or what about groups like Boards of Canada who had a very large gap of time in between their latest album and their previous album and in the midst of this time period it's not like they made heavy heavy heavy use of social media interacting with their fans at every waking moment though they did engage their audience and building up some buzz once they had a new album to present there are some artists out there who really feel like in between album releases kind of drop off the face of the planet which is absolutely fine I just think in the instance that the artist is actually popular and has some previous successes in their back catalogue their return to putting out more music and maybe using some social media to in the process makes them being back even more exciting because a lot of newer artists out there who are up-and-coming and really trying to make a living in the music industry it seems that their success is incredibly dependent on them not only putting out as much music as they possibly can but interacting with their fans as much as they possibly can to through Twitter and Facebook Tumblr YouTube as well so at this point now has the internet sort of changed the nature of the comeback are people getting excited for new albums coming out as if their comeback albums when they're really not let's even take the new Daft Punk album for example while Daft Punk was never that far away from the limelight I mean they just put out that Tron soundtrack too before the release of random access memories when they put out random access memories it was almost as if they had been gone for a pretty long time sometimes not hearing a new studio album from a particular artist and maybe only hearing a piece from them soundtracks stuff other various projects can be kind of frustrating so at this point your thoughts what does it come back for all the bands out there with breaking up and reforming for the release of every new album be a good marketing move what are the rules regulations and must-haves for comeback does the internet love and obsess over comebacks a little bit too much expect a bit too much from comeback records what do you think let me know thanks Anthony fan tanto comebacks forever

Miller aka Easy Mac with the cheesy raps is a Pittsburgh rapper this is his latest full-length album I believe his second commercial release and Mac Miller has become one of hip-hop's most polarizing figures over the past few years now Mac caught a lot of hype off of his earlier mixtapes singles and videos a lot of which I liked not because they were deep and conscious and and pushing the envelope or anything like that but because they were just like yeah light-hearted then sometimes a little introspective and Matt continued to gain popularity but he was dropping more and more projects that I didn't really care for and putting himself in these lanes in hip hop that I felt where maybe I don't know a little uninspired either being just a very boring weed rapper or a bubblegum pop rapper his flows were becoming more underwhelming and and it was getting harder and harder to take him seriously when he would go into this more deep and introspective side of his personality this was at its worst on albums like blue slide park and the incredibly nauseating jazz EP that he put out under a completely different name and I am happy to say that watching movies with the sound off while it's not going to be one of my favorite hip hop albums of this year it is improvements on pretty much all fronts for Mac Miller with flow with lyrics production and features with the feature list on this thing with schoolboy q action bronson ab-soul a really awesome verse from loaded luxe sort of talking about the change in Mac Miller's personality over the course of his career an event of course Earl Sweatshirt shirt shirt and don't forget M cjp like tracks with the features on here he's really keeping his ear to the underground and just really keeping it kind of gritty and and picking those artists who have their own dark styles and Mac Miller pretty much does that with the production on this thing too blue slide park was definitely an album where you could hear him getting a little a bit more groomed and cleaner but watching movies with the sound off is is a step in the more underground direction bringing more beats from clamps casino on here one of which is on the track bird colin is not in his usual cloud wrap style it's actually a banger and Chuck Inglish is on this LP as well bringing some beats Flying Lotus is on here The Alchemist Earl as well Pharrell and there are a handful of songs on here that Mac Miller actually produces himself under the name Larry fisherman tracks like Starr room which is a beat from Earl Sweatshirt actually one of the best instrumentals smoky blunted it's very colourful and the instrumentals continue to be colorful on this thing with tracks like avian which has these really interesting plinky piano samples playing over and over and over and when the hook comes through these champagne rooms strings start soaring over the instrumental of course the beat hits hard on this track as well as the song somebody do something which a lot of people freaked out about initially when it got put out as a single because fly low handled the production on this hearing Mac Miller and Flying Lotus on the same track kind of a surprise but I the name Flying Lotus carries way more weight on this instrumental than the instrumental itself tracks like watching movies has a really strong trap flavor to it there's a handful of songs toward the back end of the cell P that go more for that cloud wrap vibe and the song matches is maybe the most bubblegum poppy song on here with this really sweet psychedelic synth lead that was sampled straight from a black moth super rainbow track what I really admire about watching movies with the sound off the most is how consistent and then Mac is in picking beats whether they're trap cloud rap whatever it's all really just textured colorful kind of psychedelic and even Mac Miller's beats hold their own against some of the other instrumentals on this LP as far as instrument oh I really can't complain about not a single song on here now as far as flows go on some of his more recent projects Mac has really been putting me to sleep with how understated and and basic some of his verses can be and in triplets speeding up and slowing down and a lot of interesting ways and the song birdcall is is another track on here where Mac does the kind of monotone understated thing but because the beat is where the tempo really slows down and it forces Mac to slow down as well and as he is rapping so much slower on this track he slips a little bit in that of tempo and it's like going this pace forces
