zombi hi everyone Anthony van Thanh ho here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new zombie album with love zombie is a uk-based electronic music producer this is his third full-length album with love it is his longest effort yet 33 tracks spanning two disks over an hour of music which I guess a lot of people have been up in arms about but I however have been a really looking forward to listening to this thing I don't really mind long albums obviously but I haven't really fallen head over heels for zombies earlier stuff either his falling Staib you where were you in 92 was a pretty decent tribute to break B electronics you can really tell the dude has an attentive ear with how well he was able to recreate this style of music and his next full-length album dedication was a big change of pace but much more abstract spacious bear I mean really so uneventful that I really couldn't connect with it in any way whatsoever emotionally despite all the genre hopping from future garage to UK bass a little bit of dubstep break beats and now on this LP trap zombie is actually pretty consistent emotionally he really likes to keep his sound sort of on the darker more shadowy side of things and it's not really because of a use of heavier distorted sounds anything like that he really prefers to keep things atmospheric lots of reverb and tons of space in the sense and the drum sequencing his beet production tends to be very minimal sort of skeletal but still a very very moody and evocative that is definitely I think the strongest characteristic that with love has going for it even though zombies productions are still very subtle I I do find this collection of tracks to be a little more enjoyable than dedication especially on some of the better trap flavored tracks on this album with the incredibly resonant bass kicks and the twittering high hats the staccato bleeping and blooping synthesizers all of these elements together do have a particular charmed to them and zombie definitely can write a groove but just like dedication with love really feels like a mixed bag of tracks with songs of various lengths some end pretty abruptly maybe the whole mixed bag thing was a bit more manageable on dedication which was much shorter but now we're talking about spanning two discs with it which again I guess isn't a bad thing if the songs themselves stand up but the extreme similarity of a lot of the tracks on this LP makes with love a slight bore at times there are a handful of notable artists over the past year or so who have worked two nocturnal eyes the trap music sound my favorite of them being Shlomo with his recent EP and zombie is a part of that trend too and then he approaches this trend again with that very minimal style that I mentioned and that's got its pros and it's cons one of the cons being that there are very bold or interesting differences between the songs on this 33 track album to the point where when a song ends it's like oh BAM another track really begun Wow there are some songs that just crash in or fade out into the next song and stylistically sometimes they're so similar that they might as well be the same track like the tracks Digital smoke or entropy sketch on the second disc here they literally sound like slightly different versions of the same exact song however I guess a pro is that this very seamless flow and in similar emotion going into every single track does create a very uniform and chilled out listening experience there are moments where this album comes off as being slightly creepy but for the most part it's relaxing with its ethereal synthesizers and really thick bass kicks there are a few standouts to me on this album the track if I will for example which has all these breathy vocal samples and this thumb piano melody which is really sweet catchy kind of angular it really jumps out at me and the song overdose is one of the better pieces of break beat on this album really one of the darkest pieces of break beat zombie has ever pulled together I love how he takes the really busy drum sample and brings it together with some weird atmospheric sound effects that are just twisted and littered all over the mix and the left and the right it's it's really an interesting experience on head but the thing is with this album every time I find a track that I think I really like a little further down the road I I find another track that has a somewhat uncanny resemblance even though there are good songs on here that I feel that I can totally extract out of with love's tracklist and listen to by themselves over the course of this hour-long album zombies really plain untreated 808 sand generically eerie synthesizer tones and phrasing really lose their appeal and it's not that I don't like the styles of music the zombie is playing with or think that there isn't potential in what he's doing there most definitely is I just think much of the time in these songs zombies sequencing and songwriting beat writing it's also overly simplified and shallow that it becomes pretty homogeneous and not in a way that makes all the tracks feel like they're linked together for some kind of greater purpose the seldom just feels like a fat pocket full of loose change for sure it has value but who wants to carry around $40 worth of pennies what really would have made this album interesting across its hour-long runtime is if zombie through some diversity into this thing I feel that over the hour-long runtime of this LP he doesn't really take a risk I can't even say that the length of this LP is a risk considering all of the miscellaneous lay assembled beat tapes that are floating around band camp now some of which I would recommend much more highly than with love I do like to zombies sounds on this LP it's just that they wear thin and they lose novelty because there's just not that many of them in my opinion I do think though this albums throughout does have a very strong consistent and in potent mood but if you're planning on doing any incredibly intent listening to with love you might end up slightly under well I'm feeling a strong 5 to a 6 on this thing if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it this review is my opinion if you don't like it here's a straw I want to give a shout out to graduates everything bites and people who think I have too many catchphrases at the end of my videos hey listen you don't have to watch

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for your review of the new Seguros album vinkor quicker if Seguros is an Icelandic rock band this is their seventh full-length LP and they play rock music with this very elegant refined and climactic character to it a lot of people label it as post rock and while Seguros has a lot in common with other post rock bands they've never really hesitated to incorporate other genres of music into their stuff - including ambient music experimental rock now after putting out some of their best records in the late 90s early in mid 2000s their music these days is really sort of in this state of change on their past few records they've been really evolving their sound taking some risks bringing in some elements of art pop or taking things in a very very ambient direction on their 2012 album vault re which i think is a record that is a little underrated yeah it's it's not as busy or as engaging as some of their older records but I actually think the band took to this softer gentler vibe really well now their latest record here is really a relative one eighteen eighteen eighty it's not the heaviest or darkest album that you're gonna run across this year definitely but it is heavier and darker for this band not only is this album kind of a change for the band musically but it is a change for lineup - their longtime keyboardist Kerry is no longer with them either now there were some tracks dropped before the release of this album and and they were pretty dark and and I feel that that led a lot of people to expect a very very dark release from Seguros tracks that had really heavy distorted bass like the opener and the title track - which is actually so thick with instrumentation that the song becomes a hellish whirlwind there are all these weird percussive metallic clangs throughout the track it is it is very climactic as well as just sort of tortured Plus it's one of the few moments I've ever really heard yawns his voice come off as sort of sinister on a track because typically his singing feels in my opinion very warm friendly sort of inviting really adding to this feel and the band's music typically that that comes off as as being sort of like I'm listening to something that is being written within a magical mystical land like a fairy tale and if that's the case Quaker is essentially hearing a very dark cloud of evil roll in on this magical mystical land now aside from these incredibly dark tracks there are a few moments like stormer where you're hearing the band deliver their usual blend of instrumentation their usual atmosphere but there's a touch of gloominess to it and the closing piano piece on this album as well when you compare it to the closing piano piece on Sega roses last LP it's kind of like night and day which might be an intentional thing after all vault re was one of cigarettes heavenly albums this new LP is definitely one of the Bands darker albums may be their sister albums in a way however I don't want to take it too far and assume too much especially since I feel like this new record from the band only feels dark comparatively I don't really feel that the dark vibe permeates every single track on this album even the songs where I feel like the band is really trying to get it to translate there are some tracks on here that feature some building drums and strings some joyous horns and sonically it doesn't really feel that far off from what the band has done in the past to me they're actually quite a few tracks on here that feel that way to me although I guess I can't fault sigur rs for making an album that sounds like a cigarette it's been just about a year since vault re came out it doesn't feel like the band is putting any less effort into this record if there's anything that's less on this record it is less climactic and and I feel that is partially because the band is writing shorter songs on this thing with structures that are way more straightforward they're not really trying to create this sense of vastness that some of their best songs do they're not really wandering out or creating something that feels a little directionless before they really kind of deliver a hard or very beautiful climax I just wish there were more tracks on this album that felt as dark as the title track in order to make this new chain and the band sound really worth it I feel that a lot of songs on here sort of dulled down the bands very lavish and and pretty sound in order to make an album that feels like a change of pace only part of the time for sure I do like this album I think it will translate well with fans maybe even better than Baltar II did because people were really looking for something more eventful than what the band had brought on that record you will have people that listen to this record after being disappointed by vault re and think to themselves wow this is just much more engaging this is better I'm with this but personally I prefer vault re to this if you've given this LP listen what did you think of it did you loved it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana sigur rs [Music]

evil who I mean is really just like a group of metallica worshippers or havoc which is really just a group of Megadeth worshippers and powertrip is definitely in that revivalist camp as well essentially power trip is to crossover thrash metal what the exploding hearts are to power pop you have this group that is living today but sound exactly like they came out with this record like 30 or it's good you gotta practice a little bit more I think we're almost there hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new melt yourself down album melt yourself down these guys are a uk-based septet this is their full-length debut out on the leaf label an album that I just had to review after hearing a few tracks from it especially the lead single off of the selfie fix my life a track that was an electronic funky groove heavy and kind of psychedelic presentation of sounds ranging from rock music to jazz a little bit of punk Middle Eastern music African music this record is an incredibly energetic blend of all of these sounds blaring saxophones that that play melodies that are a little kitschy here and there the rhythm section of this thing with the drum kit and all the hand percussion it's really polyrhythmic many of these tracks features swirling weird very noisy electronic sounds and the band also has an extremely energetic over-the-top frontman who not only has some a powerful voice and some nice range but a lot of the tracks on this album feature him doing these really weird out-of-the-box vocalizations all of these elements combine in a weird way actually makes me want to compare this group to artists like ponytail or man man the Bhutto's band holy fuck and go except I would say that mell yourself down has a stronger international vibe to their music much spicier more exotic even though there is sort of this Western Drive in the band I feel to be sort of straightened to the point kind of accessible now as far as the band's performances on these tracks they're thrilling to listen to there are some serious energy just interplay to how these guys perform on these songs hearing a band play in a way that is this lively it's just like oh my that I am alive I can taste and see and smell and feel in here it just feels so wrong I'm just so in the moment especially with the song release the title of the track actually has an exclamation point at the end which is well deserved considering all of the very sputtering electronics the bass line with rides of minor scale all of the shouts and demonic horns this song a lot more than fix my life and some other tracks on here is really a jam the band really lets loose on this groove and builds the song into something that is just really kakuka cacophonous and sort of trippy very visceral and the song we are enough it's a track that is loaded with distorted electronics it's one of the few moments where the vocals are clearly singing in a definable language English not to say that other languages are difficult to understand but it's pretty clear that there are moments on this album where the band's lead singer is is really just sort of making up gibberish and with him singing against this very thumpy bassline this track easily is the most punk doubt on the entire album it is the first moment on this LP though where I feel like the band borders on being obnoxious slightly or maybe even a little one-dimensional even though the first half of this album is really energetic still the first four tracks on this LP they sort of blend together but mellow yourself down does work to diversify the second half of this release like the song free walk which is incredibly slow and relaxed other tracks on this album feel like a non-stop half-naked dance party underneath a hundred degrees Sun meanwhile this track is like an after-hours party and a tent people are dancing but it's a little chilled out drinks are being served their lanterns maybe there's a campfire the song is really sort of romantic and and sweet in a way I love that the band after playing so hard can just sort of do this 180 totally change their tone shoe for a different vibe and achieve it in a lot of ways I think the only shortcoming on this track is the band singer who is so bold and just so in-your-face that when they tone down a little bit on this track it's not like he really reaches down to that level and does something as sweet however he does sound fine on the track mouth-to-mouth which is a slower track but definitely a more sinister one with all of the primal drums and drones on this track it's maybe the darkest on the entire LP the band really goes from this sunset Twilight situation to just pure musical voodoo in a matter of minutes the track feels even crazier when the drummer is playing tons and tons of fills for the back end of this track which actually feel very heavy metal inspired overall I have to say this self-titled LP from L yourself down is a very fun and mostly solid release it has an incredibly impressive blend of ideas great playing production and energy I just feel that it being so short and just in this short amount of time a very small variety of ideas being presented kind of keeps it from being interesting from beginning to end because there is sort of a Sammy Sammy feel to a few of the tracks on here because of how straightforward the band's playing is from beginning to end on this thing really the most surprising thing consistently are the very strange and just noisy electronics I'm feeling a light a decent seven on this thing if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and and that's it hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for your review of the new kanye album yeezus Kanye West's a Chicago rapper and producer who has been one of the biggest names in hip hop music for the past decade or so he was a guy who I've admired for quite a while now because of his forward-thinking production when it comes to making beats very few people out there in the mainstream are as lavish creative or as eclectic as Kanye and it's also impressive that over the course of his career he's been able to challenge his fan base with a few different sounds and directions even if it's meant some disappointments like the LP 808s and heartbreak but still this risk-taking has paid off in the album My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy back in 2010 one of Kanye's most successful albums to date critically acclaimed across the board except maybe not so much with me but recently and I mean like since 2008 I think a lot of Kanye's songs revolve around just this really boring portrayal of egoism and of course this is coupled with some really weak hooks some terrible singing and auto-tune still even though there were some characteristics that I didn't really like on this album I didn't hate it I liked it a little bit but the way that people reacted to my review I might as well have hated it and I feel like this partially has to do with how much Kanye's fans buy into the idea that he is so shocking and and does offend so many people but honestly from my perspective I feel like ever since Kanye has gotten more indulgent with his music and this is since 808 he's been stretching his talents really thin and Kanye admits that he's not a great singer but he still puts it onto his records under the assumption that it brings his album's character and for sure it does but I feel that his voice and the auto-tune just really the quaintness of it wears thin not only this but I am just not that invested in Kanye airing out his dirty laundry and I know that some people are and and he makes music like that for his fans and partially he does it because he's egotistical as well which honestly I don't necessarily see as a bad thing a lot of successful artists are egotistical and I don't really begrudge them that I think the fact that Kanye is a great producer and has had a very long shelf life in hip-hop music has earned him for sure some pretension but I personally feel that Kanye's first three records the production was classier the topics that were tackled were a bit wider nowadays many of his songs just feel like they're consumed by his place in the music industry his place in the public eye and even though Kanye does come off egotistical it's not like lie to ourselves here we know that you know kind of underneath all of this overacting Kanye is insecure why else would he feel the need to respond at just about every jab at his public persona and just how much Kanye pumps himself up in his own songs it feels kind of like an act which of course it is for many rappers out there by feel the way Kanye does it it's not exactly flattering in a lot of ways I feel like he's evolved into a grown-up Tyler the Creator where he's really just being over-the-top to get a rise out of people but at least Tyler can kind of come down from that and diss his audience straight to their faces for their glowing fanaticism instead Kanye just continues to fan these flames whether it be in his songs or in music videos or in interviews and I mean honestly I feel the eat rolls however I can't really say that that's changed on this new LP maybe it's actually gotten a little bit worse even though sonically this album is unlike anything Kanye has done before I'm enjoying the creative forward-thinking production but I'm pretty mad on the lyrics the hooks now don't get me wrong here I'm not saying Kanye is a bad lyricist period Kanye can actually be pretty introspective thrilling nuanced when he wants to be for example with what is one my favorite songs on this LP new slaves and album that starts off with a few chilling lines about an era in which his mother grew up the racism that was around then then he sort of brings it to the races and that is there now that he feels that he is currently dealing with he throws out all of these black stereotypes and puts them on display very vividly as if they had all been said straight to his face by the people that he rubbed shoulders with and even though Kanye is incredibly passionate he's screaming nearly screaming a lot of his lyrics on this track and other tracks here I still can't feel like as he's saying you can't control me it still feels like just a pastel commercialized revolution the same materialism that Kanye spits all over on this track is the same materialism he embraces on other songs on this very album and other songs that he has put out in the past still this track and another song off of this LP black skin had really put Kanye in an interesting position new slaves being a track where I feel like he as a black person is revolting against racism that he is facing down finneus turning around on black skinhead and some other lines on this album and facing down stereotypes that are thrown onto him by other black people there are moments on the cell P where Kanye talks about getting flack for wearing polos and backpacks there's actually a line on Jon hop again hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new John Hopkins album immunity John Hopkins is a london-based electronic music producer this is his second full-length solo LP for Domino Records I first heard of his music after he signed to Domino Records and put out his first full-length for them insides back in 2009 and album I liked a lot of tracks from especially songs like the very heavy crushing and kind of distorted title track and a lot of the other songs on this thing - which had very eerie beautiful and kind of cinematic synth playing throughout at the end of the day I just felt like the album was okay though because it really felt like a mixed bag of ideas from IDM downtempo glitch even though I did like a lot of tracks off of insides I I didn't think John Hopkins would come back around and put out an LP I enjoy this much the mmunity pulls together a lot of tracks that are various blends of house and techno styles occasionally John will come through with his very cinematic ear which will lead him to introduce some very spacious beautiful piano chords it's almost as if he's doing a modern minimal neoclassical thing against some of these electronic sounds and I have to say as far as tech house goes John's blends of these styles are really good on this thing of course you've got a lot of driving quarter-note kick drums as far as the grooves go this album is is not very robotic cold or chilly but I wouldn't exactly say this LP is bouncy or lively either rather what John is pulling together with these tracks is something that is very textured kind of glitchy really dramatic and there's a very strong melodic element to these tracks too even if it is a very soft and spacious once-once one John's beats can be really thick and just dense with different sounds but he keeps it rather simple when it comes to the melody writing which is okay he does sort of do a quality over quantity kind of thing doesn't really busy up a lot of these leads and and still even though they aren't really in your face and they do take their time to grow and progress they are very pretty gripping even though a lot of what you'll hear on this album if you try it out are repetitive beats repetitive loops that progress very subtly John with the way he arranges piano and sense and just other sounds around these grooves it makes them feel so purposeful and lofty and kind of poignant without him even really saying anything on these songs this loftiness and sense of purpose really progresses to the point where the last track on this LP with these really faint vocals and these beautiful spacious pianos they sound like they're from a cut from the last cigarette it's not a bad track but it is one of the few moments on this LP that to me feel kind of just out of place really come in at a left-field still the more electronically driven tracks that John pulls together on this thing are high-quality the opening track on here has this amazing beat that is just dark it's subtle but very dense it's simultaneously noisy and quiet it's just so friggin textured I love it the murky bass line on this thing is fantastic the atmospheric synthesizers on this thing and I love that this song the way it ends it almost feels like I'm just gliding into the next track there's not some breaking point like okay this is a totally different thing than this job really holistically conceives this album after this you've got tracks like open high signal as well as Collider songs that in my opinion take a stronger techno approach the hard beats on these tracks feel mechanical calculated but both of these songs are still incredibly detailed and Atmospheric the track open I signal with its constant beat change ups and it's bass line which I cannot even explain I mean not melodically melodically it's actually pretty simple but what he does with it texturally it feels like he wrote this really smooth bouncy bass line and he's just like choking it and shaking it just there are moments where it's really deep and resonant and thick and then there are other spots where it feels like he's just crushing and squeezing it to get these very strange melodic undertones and the song Collider takes a little bit of a different approach with its beat it's not always changing up it's actually pretty hypnotic and very very repetitive but the sounds that John arranges around this track especially the really atmospheric sense it's almost deafening how thick this track gets the more piano driven pieces are beautiful beauty-full and had a fantastic counterpoint to the more electronic tracks on this LP I think the only song that I didn't really care for was the track formed by firelight with this really slow kind of distorted shuffling beat that didn't really appeal to me all that much a lot of John's piano playing around this beat is is very pretty as it is on previous tracks but with the relief arty-farty bass line on this thing that just felt really flat and just kind of bodyless there were a lot of reasons I just wasn't digging the sounds on this thing because of that track and and the closer like I said whose sound really kind of comes out of nowhere for me this LP does fall apart a little bit at the end but a majority of this album I'm telling you it's it's it's very long stretch out tech house tracks that lasts 7 9 12 minutes and these lengthy giants as well as these smaller piano driven pieces around them I'm loving them I'm feeling a light decent 8 on this LP if you've yes he's not always there in terms of pitch but I feel like when he dips in out of it it's because he's sort of really overacting and just really bringing something that's ah it's in me right here however the vocals that mount Kimi brings to the table on numerous tracks from this LP not as gripping a lot of the vocals that mount can be offers are very faint they're obscured a little bit too much by reverb and and in my opinion somewhat passionless and the vocals really are a consistent issue for me on this LP there's not really one single track on this album where I like them however that's not really the only thing keeping me back from enjoying this release for one I think the recording on this album is a little too low by really and that could possibly be the case due to the title of the opening track on this thing the home recording reference and you know for sure there are some great lo-fi records out there fantastic lo-fi records really but I I think that this recording quality bites this record in the but it really bites the duo in the but on here mostly because of the fact that the sounds really are not that vivid they're they're not that unique or interesting and the the melodies aren't really vivid enough to cut through the extreme amount of reverb and again just how faint some of these sounds are I know Mount can be from their from their synthesizer idea or just kind of a motif like thing and then it cuts out and while some songs are short others seem to kind of drag on a little bit the song blood in form is one of the most obtuse tracks on this album it has the oddest most off-kilter beat and a lot of the sounds throughout this tracker just so sour and kind of unrewarding it's it's really a jumble a kind of unrewarding jumble i think as far as some of the instrumental pieces like toward the back end of this LP where I'm hearing what feels like more live instrumentation I mean the performances are fine mount kimby is most certainly tight nothing feels incredibly out of place but it's just all too breezy there's just not a lot for me to I feel like latch onto with this album the music just wasn't really moving to me hi everyone Anthony Fantino here internet's busiest music nerd and yeah just a little quick question here for you something I've been wondering a boat I'm curious as to whether or not location where you are geographically is going to continue to be a very relevant factor into the future when it comes to making it in the music business and getting your music out there getting people to listen to your music I am someone who comes from a place that is not exactly well-known for its music scene internationally or nationally you know really even locally a lot of people from Connecticut don't even really know that there is a music scene but those of us who have taken part in it do enjoy what little of it there is but it has been growing over the past few years and I do think that is do a lot to actually the Internet the fact that a wider array of people out there right now have more access to alternative forms of music whether it be rock pop electronic hip-hop metal what-have-you they don't get me wrong there are artists who are from Connecticut whose music I appreciate greatly rappers like apathy or Dan Barrett Giles Corey have a nice life specifically there are other artists in my review roster whose albums I have touched down on and praised as well I will link to some Connecticut music scene relevant stuff down in the description box okay now being from Connecticut but also being somebody who covers a lot of musicians every single week that are not from Connecticut at all that are really from all around the world I can't help but feel like you have artists who come from really the middle of nowhere put together a hot track that ends up getting a ton of buzz on the Internet if it can happen there why can't it happen here the truth is that it could happen here it really could happen just about anywhere which is why I can't help but feel that when it comes to having a music career getting your music noticed location doesn't necessarily become a factor for sure it can become a factor because if you're a band and you're just starting out you're in a big city maybe there are some in our people some Scouts in the area or you've got a healthy buzz locally and these people are kind of able to elevate your music because you have a ton of people condensed into one area who are huge fans of your music the general consensus is that if you're an artist whether it be in a band or solo and you are participating in a huge big healthy vibrant music scene your chances of being noticed have increased maybe the probability is a little bit higher but I think it's getting to a point where not only is the probability just as high if not higher participating in putting your music onto the Internet just making a really good album release and just putting it out there or just a quality single maybe a music video whatever the content is and wherever it comes from the potential for you to take off is is there even if it's with a small subgroup of people who are into a particular niche genre and the thing is not only can this happen in just some kind of random small town in America or just a place that's not really well-known for its music scene whether it be a city or whatever but Americans are seeing songs from other countries becoming huge hits on the Internet and then all of a sudden they're being played on the radio over here which isn't a bad thing at all I actually think it's interesting that in the next few years maybe the internet will do us a lot of good in terms of breaking down a lot of the barriers and separations that we have between the music scene of Americans the music scene that the UK has going on music scenes going on in Asia music scenes going on in Eastern Europe music scenes going on in Africa and South America and not only will we be more conscious of music being made in these places but hopefully they will be conscious of what we're doing over here as well actually I think that's probably already the case thanks to huge internationally known record labels but I'm thinking more from the perspective of underground music because often when I go out trying to seek out music from other countries on the internet I am sort of bombarded with what is the most popular and that's in because I don't really speak any other language other than English flu the language barrier keeps me from really diving in and finding what might be really groundbreaking however with people out there starting new music sites and blogs and and musical sharing platforms every day I see these boundaries kind of fading away so into the future will location still impact whether or not you can make music and successfully get it out there and get people to listen to it will you be better off as a rapper in New York City or as a rapper in Portland Maine let me know what you think Anthony Fantana location music River you

young others hi everyone Anthony Fantino here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new young father's album EP project mixtape tape - these guys were Scottish hip hop past that point putting out music videos touring internationally landing a record label deal with ant icon one of the leading record labels when it comes to experimental and adventurous hip hop and of influences that these guys brought on tape one was really impressive not only that but how they brought them together the songwriting was impressive the energy and the production were impressive the only thing that I didn't really love about tape 1 was just how short it was it only 20 minutes now well young fathers have put out a new release tape 2 and unfortunately it is just as short as tape 1 not 20 minutes but 23 creating this very short blast of unique and creative hip-hop that's essentially the goal again on this sequel to tape 1 hit them with something new and then leave them wanting more the only thing really different sonically about this new project is that maybe it is a little less lo-fi a little less grimy and for sure they do incorporate some different sounds and understated rapper inside I'm kind of dirty inside I'm feeling a day I'm really loving the understa stop okay stop don't don't do it again the understated rappers on this track really good the song come to life hits really hard it's one of my favorite tracks on this LP the instrumental to this song and a lot of ways reminds me of one of my other favorite young father songs from their previous project rumbling the kick drums had this really thick thud quality to them and the synthesizers which are very warm just Pig pile on top of one another in a crazy way and this track might have one of the best group vocal parts of any song and this pretty short release the group vocals captivate again on the song only child even though the song has a slightly different vibe to it with some very ham-fisted piano chords that are just hit as hard as possible with a very lumbering beat the beat actually feels like it's it's recorded foot stomping onto wooden floors or something and with the piano chords and the opening rap verses laughs it's a boy the song is really one of the more fun moments on this entire project it's a sin that it's only two minutes though I will say that even though young fathers does and their tracks abruptly they do pack quite a bit of structure into these very short songs tape 2 takes a darker turn with tracks like ebony sky and mr. martyr mr. martyr actually has one of the more eerie vocal melodies on the entire thing and ebony sky has a pretty dark or frein about a woman looking for love in all the wrong places and both of these tracks have bass in them that's it's very rough it's very hearty the production is so consistently creative and textured throughout this entire thing the song way down in the hole starts off very fun very soulful kind of light-hearted but then all of a sudden it kicks in is very dark piece of percussion with these clicking clacking paradiddles and this rising bass where and this just goes on constantly again and again and again it's like being spun around in a circle violently and the song queen is dead probably young fathers loudest song yet there is this blaring chorus with not only just bright ear piercing synthesizers but the three of them going simultaneously wah wah look really this track and way down in the hole two of the most unique pieces of production I've heard this year period overall tape 2 hey everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new primal scream album more light these guys are a Glasgow rock band they've been releasing material since the late 80s late mid 80s and this new record of theirs is another addition to their ever-growing discography in which there are a few major highlights like Screamadelica and 91 exterminator in 2000 and this band's career has really been defined by almost always being in some sort of state of flux Primal Scream's albums can be mixed bags from time to time but their best and and some of their longest releases are undeniably cohesive and for sure this new album of there's more light is one of their more cohesive ones as of late I think it's one of their better records as of late it's one of their longer ones - if not the longest album period and Primal Scream's records that break that 60-minute mark do tend to be some of their better ones now for one the band is getting back to their more psychedelic side the more psychedelic side of their sound with numerous songs on here being really thick noisy heavy with instrumentation very repetitive with riffs that that are just grooved out to the point of being a little hypnotic and I think this is one of their more consistent records - with how much the band sticks to some of these more psychedelic and just trippy sounds this LP is just overwhelming with sound and momentum and and rock-and-roll swagger and it can be pretty impressive instrumentally as well bringing together rock instrumentation blending it with strings with horns of course this is not the only vibe that the band channels on this record you've got the buzzing walls of guitar and the blaring sax riffs on the opening track 2013 you've got acoustics on here backed with some sitar hard distorted riffs against some very sharp drumbeats song hit void brings a really shoegaze evite to these very just wavy wavy warped guitars their tracks on here the features some very strange see echoes and The Closer on here features Bobby Gillespie singing over what what feels like some kind of long-lost gospel chorus backed Rolling Stones instrumental it's a little hokey but it is fun it's a really big change of pace from the urgent opening track on this LP that talks about just the media propaganda rock and roll the only other track that sticks out to me is not being incredibly psychedelic but still is another favorite of mine on this thing is the track invisible City with its very just hard grooving bassline that that to me feels like the band is really getting back to their more alternative dance side of course there are some very peppy horns throughout this track too and it's got one of the sharper choruses on this thing even though it is short it's very catchy if there is one thing though that that I didn't really care for throughout this LP it to get a little old to me it is Bobby's vocals at times there are moments when I wish he was as passionate as he was on the closer the sort of breathy approach that he makes to a lot of the songs on this album can get a little stale and makes these songs feel say me say me at times the only other issue that I have is that is that some of these songs with this album being very long can feel overly long elimination blues tenement kid I think the vocal melodies on these tracks are a little too repetitive as are the lyrics they feel a little too surface level for me the track goodbye Johnny - suffers from this issue and on top of it just the the vocal delivery and the lyrics feels a little corny compared this track this slower track with another slow track on here walking with the beast which is very pretty beautiful guitar melody on this track it's a little Velvet Underground esque and and to me one of the more moving songs on this album I can really tell lyrically Bobby Gillespie is is struggling with something in in what he is saying and at least while he is putting down into words yeah he's breathy again on this track but with what he is saying it feels like a very personally painful track overall I did think a few of the tracks on this LP were underwhelming sure but Boards of Canada it is hot is hot right now hi everyone Anthony Fantana here intranets busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Boards of Canada album tomorrow's harvest Boards of Canada electronic music duo whose musical style tends to run a little nostalgic you've got a lot of analog since in their recordings against some subtly IDM influenced beats and even though the analog cents do carry a certain era of music with them it's really the quality the sound quality of the recording that Boards of Canada works with that really lends their tracks some real magic retro magic recording that Boards of Canada typically works with is so grainy it's so smudgy in quality it sounds like I'm listening to a reel-to-reel tape or watching a VHS tape or watching a 9 millimeter film reel and even though on the surface this does sound a little bit like a gimmick the sound play and the music that Boards of Canada brings to the table on their most critically acclaimed LPS is really worthwhile it's not only incredibly melodic and memorable but very vivid with its imagery listening to an album like write to children is like listening to the soundtrack to an old documentary film or a sci-fi movie and when I say documentaries I mean documentaries about deserts Tundras space or under the sea just the most desolate places on the earth it's like the duo is really making up music for some kind of film that is going on in their heads especially with many of the shorter songs on these releases of theirs that last maybe 1 to 2 minutes it really feels like they're pulling together some incidental music for something and even though tracks like the smallest weird number do come and go pretty quickly they are strikingly beautiful in the synthesizer phrases and how the duo manipulates them while I'm sure the duo does have a certain picture or something in mind when their career getting a track the the way that they form their songs it really encourages the listener to sort of come up with their own narrative as well which has really made their music very engaging this is roughly the style that Boards of Canada have come through with on the more successful side of their career on work record since the late 90s of course with some variations in concept and sound from album to album but on this new LP of theirs tomorrow's harvest their first full-length in eight years I can't really say that Boards of Canada have spent that time reinventing themselves or coming through with an entirely different sound or mood I can't even really say they continued experimenting with some of the more natural and acoustic sounds that they introduced in a big way on the LP campfire head phase their last full-length there are some samples used on this album whether they be vocal snippets or something a little more musical however they're not really any more prevalent here than they are on any other LP I feel and like usual the beats skitter about they're sort of repetitive they are cold they're robotic but there is somewhat of a natural vibe to them because of the very splotchy sound of the recording in a lot of ways on tomorrow's harvest I actually think the duo is trying to relive what a lot of people consider to be their best full-length album really their mission statement music has the right to children and while yes this album is ambient it's not like that's an angle that the duo hasn't worked with before and in addition to the more apocalyptic vibe of this record certainly the lead single from this LP sells that angle but I think that desolation that comes through on many tracks here that is a feel that many of the duo's older tracks have have toyed with in one way or another it's not like these themes haven't come up before with Boards of Canada but I will say maybe they are at their most potent on this new LP maybe this is Boards of Canada's most sad and remote record now there have been a lot of triumphant comeback Sauveur the past few years that we have observed My Bloody Valentine Godspeed You black emperor Daft Punk of course this year Fiona Apple Justin Timberlake - yeah I wasn't crazy about the record but a lot of people were so indeed there is more than one way to have a successful return to music and I think Boards of Canada is in in regards to buzz and and possibly record sales in some ways I actually think Boards of Canada's aesthetic is is more relevant than ever in this current cultural landscape that we sit in that is obsessed over things like Polaroids and as David's and as their technology and in musical expressions from 30 40 years ago we are post chillwave people and I understand the appeal of this angle I too love a nice revised piece of musical nostalgia but Boards of Canada's sound is is incredibly well established at this point they're not some trendy newcomer or even an old face trying out something completely new so even though nostalgia may be a key feature in boards of Canada's music is is this new record as good as their previous efforts is it just a good listen in general I personally feel that tomorrow's harvest is is a slightly uninteresting come back for Boards of Canada because essentially on this record in my opinion they have come back to do exactly what they have done before but with less detail less adventure less extravagance less memorable moments now for one I've never really been huge on LPS that bring together a smattering of short motif like tracks this is part of the reason I don't really review soundtracks on this channel because I truly feel that in order to enjoy the soundtrack to its fullest extent that the images need to be there as well the soundtrack was made to marry with the movie now I know that Boards of Canada's previous albums are all like that however on many of their old tracks especially the short ones the sound play and the melody writing was so vivid and was so out there it was striking it felt inspired it brought this sense of wonderment tracks like the color of the fire or triangles and rhombuses these were tracks that had a strong retro vibe to them yes but we're also experimental very psychedelic kind of trippy to the point where it felt like these sounds even though yeah we're familiar with them being from a different era of music hearing on this record it's like they're coming from a completely different world entirely I can't really say that's the case for tomorrow's harvest like the very short track on this record telepath we're really the only interesting thing about the song are the manipulations of the vocal sample and the very murky buzz and the bumbling melody on the track you ritual this song the sounds that it delivers feel so effortless for Boards of Canada in comparison with some of the busier tracks in their back catalogue it's it's really borderline offensive and the song collapse where I'm really hearing a bunch of synth arpeggios brought together with the sounds of wind it really feels like Boards of Canada are truly recreating the soundtrack music sounds the progressive synthesizer soundtrack music sounds that inspire them as opposed to building on them experimenting with them even the longer tracks on this LP don't have the amount of meat on them that Boards of Canada used to lay into them like the track Whiteside Klose with some droning sense some pulsating chords and a very eerie melody it sets an apocalyptic mood but it is not engaging for the full three minutes that it lasts there are songs on this LP that I like but I still end up sort of having my reservations about them like the song reach for the dead the lead single off of this LP which I do enjoy the song has a really strong mood to it it feels like doomsday with how lurches and just pulsates forward very coldly but I feel like how strong that mood is on this track has more to do with decades and decades of synth music and that kind of being an institution that we are familiar with as opposed to anything that Boards of Canada specifically does with this particular song I do like the way that the beat creeps in toward the end of the track but I have to say in terms of progressive synth music progressive electronic music out there what Boards of Canada are doing on this record just feels a little sort of elementary still the song jacquard cosway's is is pretty refreshing with it's very off-kilter beat and these swirling synthesizer phrases that that are really dizzying sort of hypnotic and they move I would I would say very warmly as the song progresses forward it's really sort of inviting in a way one more inviting tracks on this entire LP the track sick times has a very ominous feel to it but it brings that downtempo sound that Boards of Canada toys with once in a while and the song Palace Posey is is maybe when I favorite tracks on here has some great vocal samples very musical and I'm loving the the more natural feel of the drums on this track they almost sound like live drums and again with the vocal samples I love how strange and scattered and distorted and manipulated they are and when these local samples come in they introduce a really awesome chord change and the chord progression on the song nothing is real is really uplifting again another warm track in this collection as I said there are highlights on this album but they are as prevalent as gas stations greasy spoons and convenience stores on on an abandoned stretch of desert road because a lot of the cell P does feel like driving by tumbleweeds rocks sand and coyote corpses I really do think a lot of this album is pretty uneventful and the only way that the songs truly work together is to create a slightly forgettable experience which I understand is a bit of the point to create this vast sense of nothingness but I think there are different ways to go about that other than to just incorporate less elements less experimentation less melody still overall I have to praise this record for the songs on here that I did like and even the tracks that I didn't care for too much they were still immaculately produced the sounds were great and at least Boards of Canada were able to bring a consistent mood a consistent emotion to this record I'm feeling a light two decent six on this record if you given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and and that's it this review is my opinion if you don't like it here's a straw I want to give a shout out to clipping who recently got signed to Sub Pop Records yeah Gavin Pia and Gerry Jen jr. st. Junior the third only the strong subscribe all mistakes were intentional Anthony Fantana Boards of Canada tomorrow's harvest forever [Music] [Music]
