hi everyone Anthony Fantino here Internet's busiest music nerd like my new curtain pretty depressing basically I hope you don't mind me doing a short little review over here of the new pharmacon album abandoned pharmacon is the experimental music project of Margaret whose last name I imagine is pronounced char da if her last name is as French as I imagined it to be she's been involved with the fringe side of music since she was about 17 and this new LP of her seems to be her first kind of big commercial full-length effort it's out now on sacred bones records now considering the genres that Margaret toys with on this record noise music little bit of ambient music power electronics some people will say I'm actually surprised that she doesn't have more music in her discography I'm talking like hundreds upon hundreds of just home recorded CD ours and cassettes of semi-improvised noise pieces but actually that's not the case in fact her discography is is somewhat sparse and from why I read about her she doesn't really improvise her pieces whatsoever they're all very methodical they're all very planned out they have clear cohesive patterns to them and for sure abandon is an album though it is noisy it is pretty organized it is pretty detailed though still very over-the-top as you can imagine with plenty of blood-curdling shrieks coming out of Margaret's mouth on some of these tracks especially the opener on here which which really to me feels like Margaret's mouth is just Pandora's box she just opens it and pretty much every sound you can imagine being in hell comes out it's a no surprise to me that she describes her music in a way to be kind of an exorcism for sure it feels that way now as far as lyrical content what she is saying if in fact she is saying anything is is pretty into sight durable though that doesn't necessarily ruin the tracks for me really her vocals are just for added sound added effect if you will as far as other sounds on this album Margaret is is pretty great when it comes to sound craft whether it be some very murky vocals that might be performed live might be pretty recorded and kind of looped and layered on top of one another to make this kind of psychedelic theory wall of vocals which happens on the second half of the track ache it's a really dreary atmosphere this creates or whether it be just very droning sharp high-pitched ear piercing electronics like on the track pitted and of course on top of these very sharp electronics Margaret is bringing these vocals that are just very stony very cold very deadpan the song is backed up with this industrially flavored Bank Lang percussion and the drone at the end of this track gets so sharp it gets so sharp as the song finishes it's like dentist drills going straight into my skull even though this album can be pretty abrasive at times it is somewhat hypnotic and kind of alluring with its eeriness its ominous 'no sand it's it's repetition one of the tracks on here crawling on bruised knees might be my favorite on this album for one there are these repetitious samples happening throughout the track that feels like margaret was pointing a microphone at a low-flying plane it does effectively create a very weird vibe for this tune I like the very minimal repetitive beat on this track the very treated vocals it's like a robot just screaming for the end of its life suffering and pain or something the issue for me with this track and many other tracks really just this album as a whole is that there is ear grabbing sound play and ferocity throughout this thing but the songs and the sounds and ideas really lose their luster over these six or seven minute song lengths that really don't feature that much progression in my opinion a lot of the tracks on here just close out with me feeling they didn't really do much outside of just repeat the original idea that it introduced which which of course was interesting when it was first introduced but by the time the album is over the song is over rather I'm just on the fence the songs on your only end up to me being memorable for their elements not really how they assembled them and of course the very disjointed 27 minute long closing track on here which I suspect was kind of added as an album only track on the high tunes to get people to buy the whole LP as opposed to just a few songs off of it that track really just didn't do anything for me and sort of epitomizes my issue with this album at times it's that it can be intense but the intensity doesn't really progress or go much of anywhere a lot of ideas on here are pretty good but very disjointed and don't build on one another really for sure I'm looking forward to future music coming out of this project there is a lot of potential here I think Margaret like I said is great when it comes to intensity and when it comes to mood and when it comes to sounds it's just building these songs out to something that feels engaging for six or seven minutes that I think needs to to happen Plus that there's just a handful of songs on this LP just four tracks outside with a very long closing track of course on a future pharmacon release I would want to see some more material as well yeah I'm just sort of on the fence with this LP if you've given them to listen what did you think of it love it hate it why and that's it pharmacon anthony Fantana you

baby baby baby baby baby baby bbbbbb beep hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Thundercat album apocalypse Thundercat is a virtuoso bass player and a songwriter from LA who went from suicidal tendencies band member to flagship artist on the brain feeder Records label in the matter of a few years through some really nice contributions to the music of Flying Lotus and a pretty well-received debut full-length LP the Golden Age of Apocalypse an album that did feature production from Flying Lotus on it and brought together his love of wonky and just Spacey experimental electronics and hip hop together with Thundercats love of new jazz jazz fusion jazz funk some of the songs were kinda brief and the vocals were not the best but the album still had incredible aura about it and and was one of my favorite LPS the year got dropped mostly because of the very flashy bass lines and melody writing the very progressive kind of futuristic production however in my opinion I don't feel that Apocalypse brings a lot of what made the Golden Age of Apocalypse so charming to begin with even though Thundercat does take a lot of influence from jazz and jazz fusion this record is still pretty overwhelmingly electronic and and that's fine I mean his last record was electronic as well but that really progressive futuristic forward-thinking vibe of the sounds that are going into Thundercats music seems to have kind of disappeared and has left some of the more upbeat songs on this album feeling like mere demos of tracks that would have definitely come out in the era of music that Thundercat pulls from influentially they just feel as if I'm hearing sequence drums behind some very vocal and bass and since mixing and really what these songs are awaiting is is a real studio recording with a full live band songs like heartbeats and setbacks as well as the track oh it's X there quite a few passable songs you know verse chorus verse type songs on this record and there are other tracks on here that don't really feel like songs at all songs that are more motif like tracks that to me sound unengaging and kind of uninspired in just about every way that you could look at them like the very dark bass line and the hissing sounds on the track crack crack crack crack the life aquatic attract the sets a pretty ominous tone and really does nothing with it for a very repetitive two minutes I feel the same thing about the track seven and then there are the vocals which of course had never really been Thundercats strongest point on his records but he's easily overcome that issue with very forward-thinking beats and sounds and sound craft is great playing and his melodies which a lot of the time are very angular memorable kind of sweet jazzy but on a lot of tracks here his pitch is just is just barely there or it's hanging on to the note he's singing by a thread on top of it his vocals on many tracks here are touched with this reverb effect that is very very thinning making his voice feel even more weak than than it is when he reaches up into his falsetto not only that but Thundercats vocal delivery on these tracks is pretty flatlined as well to me it feels like I'm listening to a really nervous performer at a vocal recital there are definitely flashes of interesting moments on this record for me songs like special stage which has a very sweet pretty and contortionist melody on it that just does backflips all over the track even though it is very slow and kind of a motive though the lyrics are a little corny don't you know you rock my world the synth melodies that come through right at the beginning on the track oh it's X I mean they're really fun which is something this album is incredibly lacking in especially since a lot of the grooves that the beats on this record are supposed to be driving are so corpse-like aside from ocean it's X many of the songs on here are just stiff as hell the track the actually felt like it had live drumming in the mix the grooves that the drum were playing were very hard there was an improv there against the bass it felt like I was hearing some live-in-the-moment action on this particular track which excited me in a sense because I've caught Thundercat live before and him in his band that he performs with are amazing but the improvisations toward the end of the track weren't really all that memorable though they were really chaotic and kind of noisy and the recording on the drums on this track just sounds like crap I mean it's just a lot of noise and I can't really make out a lot of the details and just a lot of the finesse that was going into the drumming on this song because it's just really so rough around the edges and thrown together so with the weak songs on this album the boring melodies the pretty cringe-worthy vocal performances and the loss of just flavor and style and direction on this album I was incredibly disappointed with this release I think the only song on this LP that I liked was the six minute closer it was the most ambitious part of this LP and in my opinion the only moment that still had that futuristic flair to it that Thunder cast so fantastically brought to his debut the song starts off with some really sweet epic strings great piano the instrumentation builds and when Thundercat starts singing he's sort of forgoes the falsetto and is singing very nicely on this track and is delivering some beautifully commemorative lyrics for for a late friend easily this track was the most inspired moment on the album for me everything else was either something I didn't like at all or I was just sort of on the fence with and just really not feeling anything from whether it be something positive or negative unfortunately I mean I'm feeling decent two strong three on this record if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it this review is my opinion if you don't like it here's a straw I want to give a shout out to John Tucker tell Ilana and Rick only the strong subscribe all mistakes were intentional the needle drop thundercat apocalypse forever [Music] [Music]

I thought it was Chris Rock hi everyone Anthony Fantino here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Laura Marling record once I was an eagle Laura Marling is a UK singer-songwriter this is her fourth full-length LP up until this point she's always been a musician who I've never really been enthralled with enough to enjoy one of her full lengths from beginning to end but for sure I have enjoyed some of her singles like the song Sofia one of the bigger tracks from her last full-length LP a song that features some very tenderly finger picked acoustic guitar melodies that follow very shyly in Laura's vocal melody and Laura's vocal is a pretty impressive one she has a nice range especially when she's digging down into her lower and when her voice gets really husky sort of beautiful and very womanly which she does quite a bit on this new LP now as her albums have progressed Laura has been stripping things back more and more instrumentally and and I feel on this album she is really down to the acoustic bare essentials acoustic guitar upright bass piano hand percussion but some drum kit as well cello and this instrumental shift has made for a very very intimate album right here songs that are moodier to to me the direction she's been going in very slowly up to the point of this new album is is a very welcome change from her very early stuff which was way more indie folk much more full pop reminded me a little bit of Jenny Lewis or even Feist at times and now on this new album Laura is coming off way more influenced by artists like Joni Mitchell though I will say the differences between Laura's songwriting style and Joanie's are still very much apparent Laura is very direct with her melodies very direct with her emotions and storytelling even though her lyrics can be a little cryptic here and there now even though Laura is going a little quieter on this LP than she did with her previous and and that might seem a little scary especially since Laura's demeanor is so subtle to begin with on top of it we've got sixteen tracks on this thing in the hour of music and I will admit this thing is off to a sort of slow start with this triage of tracks that really segue into one another seamlessly if you're not paying close attention it feels like one continuous song songs like take the night off and I was an eagle and you know a lot of the instrumental performances on these tracks to me feel somewhat inoffensive really not all that moving or exciting though there are some things I like about these tracks like the building cello and guitar passages on the track I was an eagle or even Laura's vocal on the track you know where she is sitting on the edge between spoken word and singing and moments like this is when Laura comes off very very earnest and it really hooks me damn oh the hippies that step empty footed however I would say after these tracks this album really really does pick up with some standout songs still Laura does not come on strong or anything like that on this LP she is a gentle soul through and through getting a motion add to this album is a lot like getting light out of a very tiny candle you just gotta light it and sit back and let your eyes adjust to what is being offered sure it's not as efficient as a giant fluorescent light but a candle does bring a particular mood to it with its faint flickers of dark orange and red on the walls even though to some people on the surface this record maybe a little middle-of-the-road I think Laura is actually deceptively understated it is how cold and just how callous she feels on this record that obscures a little bit the interesting lyrics and melodies that this album does have to offer don't get me wrong I feel like the handful of forgettable tracks on this LP and Laura's voice and personality which are not that bold does work against this album in a sense but there are still plenty of songs on here that shine through plus I think this is Laura's best record yet and this is really the sound of a singer/songwriter coming into her own I love the song breathed with its winding and descending guitar and cello melodies that are beautifully crafted and the lyrics on this track deal with love and the two participants in a relationship being mutually cruel to one another and the song master hunter one of the to your tracks on this LP and maybe my favorite track on here has this really badass acoustic guitar if that just feels really desert really just dark and dusty and the lyrics that Laura lays on this track I'm a master hunter I've cured my skin nothing gets in it really paints Laura as this cold leathery sort of beaten down individual being down emotionally and her demeanor really reflects that laura has always been a singer/songwriter to me that that has been a little underwhelming because her voice doesn't have so much oomph to it and this album for one song after another almost reflects on on why she comes off that way the song little love caster is one of the quieter songs on this album but it has this very sharp teeny-tiny dreary melody being played on the guitar that to me feels very Spanish guitar inspired and the way that the cello just sombrely creeps in against the guitar and Laura's vocals it's the first point on this album where I was really chilled and I I just snapped I felt like wow I get it I get why Laura is this way or I sort of see the appeal as to why she is this way I'm sympathizing I'm being moved here because connecting with Laura's music emotionally can kind of be like catching a very faint dying and distant radio signal there are moments on the selkie where the devil tropes that pop up in the lyrics don't really read all too well for me it feels like Laura's really beating a dead horse and the schmaltzy organs on where can I go and once just feel a little too corny for my taste but still this album does finish with three of its best tracks love be brave little bird and saved these words songs that to me portray an interesting dynamic on this album there is an interlude around the middle point of this thing and it becomes very apparent by the back end of this thing that Laura is circling around a lot of the same lyrical themes some of these same chord progressions or guitar play like a little bird which is the second to last track as opposed to the second track once I was an eagle bird bird plus both tracks have this ascending guitar and cello phrase in it the song love be brave has this beautifully twang II guitar melody on it and the closer on this album save these words to me is really sort of the cherry on top for this album is the meaning of this album wrapped up in a nutshell I mean really the lyric where Laura very sort of tongue-in-cheek Lee says thank you naivety for failing me again that is really what this album boils down to I mean Laura is someone who is just down trodden by love and being naive not being able to see the red flags being able to live in bliss and that is a concept that Laura touches down on quite a bit on this LP really this lyric is is one of the most passionate points on this album for me throughout this LP Laura displays love is this thing that brings her great pain but obviously she's attracted to it she's infatuated with it to write this many songs in regards to it again there are some songs on here that are not incredibly memorable instrumentally and Laura still to me is not is not the most standout personality in the singer-songwriter world but I think she does have a very sharp sense of lyricism a sharp sense of melody great sense of song structure and she clearly went into this album trying to fine tune it as a whole piece with tons of songs that not only revolve around a lot of the same topics use similar lyrics reference one another this thing really did feel like an experience even if some points were a little underwhelming I'm feeling a decent too strong seven on this thing if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it I want to give a shout out to Cal who will not be reviewing the new Boards of Canada album Alex Jeremy who had a very passionate conversation with me about this new Laura Marling album and Eric Thomas who I actually mistook for Chris Rock in the vocal samples from that new disclosure album that I just reviewed ex NFL player and motivational speaker Eric Thomas I've actually been subscribed to him for a while on YouTube and I will link you guys down there in the description box this review is my opinion if you don't like it here's a straw only the strong subscribe all mistakes were intentional and mm-hmm Laura Marling once I was an Eagle get the knee Fantana forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internets busiest music nerd and it's time for a question comment thing something I wanted to kind of discuss with you guys um something that we deal with every day basically on this channel and that is genre what is the style that a piece of music sits within what is the category what are the defining characteristics how can we label this particular album or song piece I happen to be of the opinion that this sort of thing is is is very helpful in a way however I I do understand that genres and the labels can be somewhat of a double-edged sword and more often than not I feel like the more negative side of genres are are acknowledged and dragged out into the open more than the positive sides are I feel like the positive sides don't really ever get discussed or defended because the positive sides are just so inherent they're just so effective that they don't really need to be discussed you know whereas for the negative sides they definitely need to be talked about because people should try to lessen the damage that genres could potentially do for sure there are plenty of artists out there who don't necessarily get the listeners or the audience that they might deserve because of their hard work because they are in a particular genre of music this could be as basic as people deciding that they do not like rock music or they do not like hip-hop music that they listen to everything except country and dubstep however when they talk about those kinds of things maybe they don't really know their country artists out there that could really appeal to them that there are dubstep artists that don't sound like Skrillex that there are rock artists that don't necessarily have the kinds of qualities that typically annoy them in rock music and that there are rappers out there who don't rap about bitches and who and money so for sure people do use on rule Able's occasionally to push away tons of artists that they may enjoy and what's even worse is these days in in the Internet age where hype is a really big factor when it comes to trying to get underground records seen and listened to you have artists like let's say Neon Indian or even how to dress well who gets stuffed into these new hot micro genres like alternative R&B as well as chill wave and then their hype dies down because people are less interested in their little micro genre that they themselves didn't even really try to invent it was something that was tagged on to them by either passionate listeners who were talking about it online creating tags on last.fm or rate your music or something like that or by bloggers reviewers music journalists these are only a few of the potentially negative impacts that that genre can have also I imagine in a way it can kind of limit the creativity that that we may see as an audience because artists or people are trying to be artists may see a kind of limited potential in the amount of John Rizzo they can toy within however as I said earlier there are very positive things about genres the reason we have genres really because people as soon as they hear a piece of music that they love they want to hear more music just like it the song that you heard was so amazing just happen to be a Led Zeppelin song which caused you to dive more into Led Zeppelin which in turn made you want to get into classic rock or just hard rock blues rock you go from there to cream Blue Cheer and because you have these labels and categorizations that have been used for decades and decades and decades you have hundreds upon hundreds of bands in this one style of music that that you are free to kind of binge on to your heart's desire and obviously people feel that's a great thing or else John Rose wouldn't be so widely used and popular and acknowledged it's difficult to say whether or not the the bad outweighs the good and that's why I guess I'm coming to you guys and asking you this question I mean while there are artists out there who are being discovered because they fit very snugly into a very particular genre they're other artists out there who are being completely ignored or avoided because they fit into a genre as well on top of it they're artists who don't really fit snugly into much of any genre and numerous records out there maybe have six or seven or eight genres maybe even a different genre being approached with with every single track hell maybe even one single song that has six very clear different genre influences flowing throughout it so genres and labels do have their limits I feel like we're going to continue using genres and using labels it's important to acknowledge that not everything can be labeled easily and adequately efficiently accurately on the front page of the YouTube channel youtube.com slash the needle drop YouTube just brought a new channel design to the table and I started making use of the shelves feature where I can separate out now my reviews by genre I have rack reviews hip hop electronic music loud rock which I kind of throw a lot of extreme metal in there metal just in general punk music as well as others Avon's oddballs things like that and still you know I sit there and I have particular reviews that I have just done and I wonder where to put certain artists even though these genres that I have put together are very very umbrella like the CX kitronik review that I just did while CX kitronik does have elements of hip hop in his music maybe hip hop is the most prevalent influence in there I could see songs from that record that he just put out going in the rock category going the loud rock category go in the electronic category and even going in the others experimental and avant-garde [Music] is a concept of genre is an idea and ideas can be used positively and used negatively genres used negatively when someone uses it to avoid trying something new to them as onra is is used negatively when it's used to insult a particular artist so yeah let me know what you think about all this genre business anthony Fantana genres forever [Music]

disclosure settle Oh cat wins again blinking contest champion I can't even tell when you blink cow can blink right here cow blink not seeing it all right hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new disclosure album settled disclosure is a uk-based electronic music duo this is their full-length debut LP hmm these guys have had some of the hottest dance music singles of 2013 period tracks like white noise featuring alunageorge as well as you and me with Eliza Doolittle tracks that have a slightly aged electronic dance music vibe to them there's a lot of dance pop on this LP as well as bass music garage and future garage believe me when I say that this is not just some kind of trash Eaton's instance on the contrary disclosure brings quite a bit of class to the table when it comes to four to the floor dance music there's some very detailed production on this album that brings a very light bouncy playful mood now there is an issue with this LP it's not gonna be for everybody it's good it's very good just maybe not so good that it's gonna bring in people who aren't typically into this style of music people who are on the outside looking in on this album understandably may see it as no more than background music for a day of shopping at Urban Outfitters or forever 21 however that doesn't mean that there aren't worthwhile tracks on here this thing is straight-up dance music and dance music that is so sharp I could see tons of tracks on this LP being very much worthy of extended mixes that get laid out on white label 12 inches played by DJs and huge clubs to dancing whore of teenagers the 12 tracks on the selfie highlight light to different sides to disclosure style you have the very catchy dance-pop numbers with vocal guests and the more instrumentally driven tracks which have a lot of vocal samples on them where disclosure really gets down to business when it comes to groove craft and really taking a loop of music and progressing it changing it keeping it engaging from the beginning to the end of the track this is occurring on songs like one of the opening tracks on here when a fire starts to burn which features a pretty prominent Chris Rock sample the song stimulation the song grabbed her to a lesser extent the track f4u these tracks feature kick drums on pretty much every single quarter no kicks that are punchy but not all that resonant or very very bassy these kicks are just splashed with little baby hi-hats watery synthesizers and very very resonant synth bass lines that sometimes are very nimble jumping bouncing all over the place the phrasing of these bass lines at times reminds me of a lot of the bass lines that I would hear in acid house music from the from the tb-303 though I'm not exactly sure they're playing with that particular piece of hardware though the track stimulation there's a little bit of an exception with its bass lines line lines which really rings out hypnotically I guess my point here is that these tracks and many other on here are working with roughly the same sonic recipe you're getting a lot of the same drum Tambor's a lot of the same synth sounds hell a lot of the same rhythm patterns instant however disclosure still manages to bring quite a bit of variety to this LP with some bold samples and a gauntlet of vocal guests the track grab her has this really sort of goofy ascending and descending synth melody that plays almost throughout the entire track it's a really fun groove if there's anything about the song that sort of gets to me it's that this melody grows kind of stale as these song progresses sometimes what makes these tracks stick out or what makes them special disclosure repeats it a little bit too much like the Chris Rock sample on when a fire starts to burn I love the track I think it's got a nasty groove I'm loving the synth on it and I just think the sample is is pretty funny though I could see it really wearing its welcome with a lot of people as far as the more dance-pop tracks on here with vocal features these are the songs that are really pulling people to disclosure really turning heads and it's easy to understand why especially with tracks like white noise with alunageorge this song is dance-pop perfection explosive hook which they build up to with some spacey synthesizers I love that segue and the synth bass line on this thing is so freakin catch or it's just a synth lead either way it's very nicely manipulated to have a little bit of as far as lyrics go on on this song and really all the songs on this album they really have to do with love relationships lust nothing altogether new yeah disclosure isn't really reinventing the lyrical wheel here but I don't really think it's a hindrance to the album I love the song voices on here with Sascha cable her performance on this song really sticks out mostly because of how jazzy it feels in a sense with the melodies she's singing I love the way that she paced out her vocals so that she's singing a little bit disclosure brings in a very heavy bass line it's a nice trade-off I have to say even when I don't really care for a vocal guest on one of these tracks I still love what disclosure does with the song track for track I have to admire the level of detail just how meticulous they are with every single thing they put into their songs at times the grooves feel ultra simple you're just getting drums you're just getting a little bit of synth bass and then all of a sudden a rush of synthesizers and effects come in and thicken up the whole recipe completely changing the vibe of the song shifting from fast moving groove to atmospheric stillness now there are vocal guests on here that overwhelmed me others underwhelm in a sense like Edward MacFarlane his vocal melody on this track is just really repetitive and pretty boring as well nowhere near is dynamic or as interesting as the vocal performance alunageorge brings to the table for example or even I'm not a really huge fan of his voice again another vocal I couldn't pick out of a lineup but still he does try to bring more variety to the melodies he's sing this on the song overall settle is is a mixed bag of dance tracks but not a bad one at all I think the only song I really disliked on this entire thing was one of the bonus tracks with Jessie where with the really horrible vocal layering on the song feeling really dissonant and just unrewarding in every way possible some songs were a little much others were not enough but when this album was good and believe me most of the time it is it is great the best spots on this LP are excellent examples on how to modernize house musics oldest and most foundational ideas I'm feeling a strong seven on this LP if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it this review is my opinion if you don't like it here's a straw I want to give a shout out to James Derek Whitney Hunter and you all mistakes were intentional only the strong subscribe the needle drop disclosure settle forever [Music]

hi everyone Anthony Fantino here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new CX kitronik album crack attack - ah damn it CX kitronik is a brooklyn beast producer vocalist and recent addition to the lineup of the infamous atari Teenage Riot and with this new sophomore LP of his CX essentially brings to the table a series of tracks that have incredibly aggressive interpretations of music hailing from hip hop music electronic music rock music and the thing is he's been doing this for years the guy's full-length debut came out in 2006 this new LP of his on Stones Throw Records obviously it's taken him a little while to put it out but maybe that could be a kind of good thing we are in a spot now where we are post Death Grips we are post clipping we're post Blackie so yeah he's been doing it longer not only is that clear just from looking at his discography but it kind of sounds like that too with the influences that come up in his music the break beat drum patterns on here that feel like they're coming straight out of the 90s the quality of the noise and the distortion on this thing how saturated it feels how muffled it feels at times to bring crack attack - together CX invites a lot of emcees into the fold a lot like his full-length debut which had way more tracks on it in comparison to this which itself is pretty long 17 tracks 50 or so minutes at the end the day crack attack - really is like one of those producer curated albums where you have someone pulling together all the beats and they just deliver to you these instrumentals loaded with a gauntlet of different emcees typically I rail against albums like this and I don't really care for them because of how inconsistent they could be in terms of the quality of the verses the quality of the rappers most of the time I feel like some people are really great others are subpar and on the whole everyone is not really bringing their best stuff because they're just kind of coming in and leaving after a few bars however CX kitronik is is sort of a special producer he is an out-there dude not just any MC can rap on his music and and I don't think just any emcee would want to rap on his music his style is is not really for everybody's because for sure the people that he brings to the table do their best to match the very extreme energy the CX brings to the table on a lot of these songs I would actually say that crack attack 2 is actually a lot like listening to a compilation of hip-hop music and digital hardcore that was released on some underground label that folded in 1998 because even though a lot of the MCS on this LP do have their own sort of rapping style they have their own verses it's all filtered through the same grimy lo-fi distorted effects and recording quality now if there is a warning I want to give you with this LP not only is it just in the red for many tracks on here but CX kitronik does not take himself all that serious as if the shrine of butt cracks on the front cover of this thing didn't already tell you that there are some weird skits on this album whether they be about the surgical shortening of butt cracks or hunting for butt cracks in downtown Brooklyn or even the ends of some of these tracks have a barrage of samples on them about butt crack crack oh he's got crap I like toe toes ooh crack sometimes it's goofing but when it's not goofing it is delivering some incredibly high-energy music that demands a lot from its listeners it really needs you to just turn up the I don't give a and I know that's difficult for some people especially with this LP because you have some weird tracks on here like you're a dummy with metal style vocals growls alternating with just ear piercing and annoying shrieks the instrumental feels like nothing the thrashy sped up guitar chords and drum machines with lyrics about diarrhea chicken pox drugs and of course masturbation it feels like some mindless self-indulgence b-side from the band's earlier stuff and I would say consistently the more rock-oriented tracks on this thing are really too gaudy for words really too gaudy for me to handle period CX kitronik truthfully can be a little one-dimensional however when this album is good it's frickin good like the opening track on this thing with these sharp very bright synth horns amazingly heavy beat shouted group vocals on headphones it's like listening to a mushroom cloud sized explosion occur between my ears I love the song locked into with Billy days from mo P not only is his voice really beefy on this track and I love it the bass the kick drums on this thing are great too and the high hats are going so fast I can't even count up the song blackout brings a little bit of old-school breakbeat magic and the song let's go crazy with the tari teenage riot is just nothing but shouts noise screams it is just non-stop intensity I would say the only major dynamics that this LP brings to the table is that it can smooth out occasionally into a hip-hop s groove that feels a little more traditional like the song ladies crack with lady miss lady miss brings a great verse on this track she is a fantastic voice she really complements the song I'm loving the murky bass and the instrumental I liked the snappy snares and the rhythmic change ups that this song offers - I like that see X can just turn down the volume a bit but still not lose that lo-fi grimy gritty flavor beats like this as well as tracks like menace to society and and buddy crack these instrumentals remind me of like old school company flow style production although I will say tracks like buddy crank do highlight just a mayer issue that I have on this LP like I said earlier with these producer curated albums I do run across a lot of verses that I'm just like this one in particular with John Wayne where he is rapping about just one is he's he's like the Cookie Monster cookie binge I just was not feeling it I erased it from my memory it was so bad the song geezer got it as well has an Doom verse on it which is good but MOBOTIX coming right after him and again it's another very weak set of bars on this album there are so many guest emcees some of them are gonna fall on the backburner you're not really gonna notice them of course that's gonna be the case too with how noisy and distorted the production on this thing is and of course with how many people are spitting verses on this album you're gonna have a different opinion than I am as to whose verse is the worst still as I said earlier the whole inconsistent emcee problem isn't that big of an issue because really between doom MF grim Saul Williams CX does keep a pretty impressive guest list of underground heroes and pretty talented unknowns overall even though this album is loud as hell and that alone is gonna make it not for everybody that and the fact that it's sort of inconsistent stylistically and quality wise - it still just might be one of the most fun listens you have with an album this year just because of how out there and over the top it is I definitely recommend trying this thing out or at least a few tracks from and just seeing if you know maybe you get a little bit of a thrill a jolt out of it you know I'm feeling a strong 6 to LA 7 on this thing if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it I want to give a shout out to Maylene Andrew cakes - Killa thanks for following me on Twitter and prancercise all mistakes were intentional only the strong subscribe Anthony Fantana CX kitronik

hi everyone Anthony Fantino here intranets busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Queens of the Stone Age album like clockwork Queens of the Stone Age are a California based rock band who have proven to be one of the more worthwhile groups to come out of the more slightly more commercial side of alternative rock in the late 90s early 2000s the band really separated themselves from a lot of groups being played on the radio around this time with their hard distorted very memorable guitar riffs as well as their attitude and some very passionate vocals from frontman Josh Homme II and some very sharp songwriting the tone of the band's guitars was very thick very heavy occasionally they would slow things down a little bit to a somewhat stone a rock like tempo of course things like this called back to the ashes of Caius which is essentially even as Queens of the Stone Age went into kechi ER and slightly more radio-friendly territory those stoner rock roots never really left the equation those hard-ass tough hard as nails or things like that made the band stick out as they released LPS like rated R in 2000 or songs for the Deaf in 2002 LPS that were an excellent mix of ferocity and infectious riffs melodies and choruses it seemed like Queens of the Stone Age could just be hard as hell without really sacrificing their accessibility however this is a bit of a balancing act that the fourth and fifth LPS from Queens that the Stone Age didn't hit as perfectly and this new LP doesn't really hit that perfect balance either however I think like clockwork is bringing something different to the table it's not necessarily trying to shoo for that balance this is easily the dreariest album that Queens of the Stone Age has ever done I actually think instead of being aggressive and incredibly catchy Queens of the Stone Age are being moody and incredibly catchy Josh isn't exactly strumming on acoustic guitars throughout this LP he keeps it electric he keeps it distorted but there are some piano tunes some slower songs some softer intros more loud soft dynamics the vocals feel a little bit more pained a little bit more emotional there's a stronger element of melody there's a bit more instrumental refinement at times when josh gets dark or dramatic he reminds me a little bit of Bowie or even Marilyn Manson not in a bad way a lot of the courses on this LP just flourish for lack of a better word like with the track i sat by the ocean which not only has some great lyrics on the hook but I'm loving the harmonized guitars the piano playing as well as Josh's falsetto the chorus on this track is matched with a bunch of hard rock riffs on the verses bluesy s guitar leads a riff pattern that that feels very familiar for some reason and some building chords that segues one part of the track into the other then and there's sort of a little breadcrumb trail of I don't want to say generic but just very familiar rock music tropes being used throughout this album and it's something that I'm completely sure Josh is conscious of in terms of how obvious all of it is but the really great songwriting the incredible production just a really great heavy heavy sound that Queens of the Stone Age brings at the table it all just blends it together very seamlessly in a way where all of these ideas that might have been in separate places originally just feel so cohesive Josh is singing of course is very convincing as well now there is a sense of variety among these 10 tracks here there are tracks that are a little sadder than others the vocals the lyrics the instrumentation really come together into something that is slightly depressing like the track the vampire of time and memory which not only features some grace string work at the end Dave Grohl drumming - coming back into the fold on this one some weird grainy synthesizers and of course Josh singing against some very patient piano chords it's a dramatic move for Queens of the Stone Age the only thing on this LP that to me feels more dramatic is the closer the title track on here like clockwork another piano ballad with Josh singing for an even longer stretch of time with just the piano in his falsetto with a very memorable refrain not everything that goes around the explosion of guitar toward the end of the track those is invigorating the Weeping guitars on this track has a very desert-like tone to them this desert tone is very prevalent from many tracks on the LP the song IP are missing brings guitars that just way down evalee on the heart not a lot of distortion on there just sharp and they are a minor toned and they just shut oh it hit me right there and I love how on the vs. the bass and the kick drums just syncope in this really weird way where they're chopping up the rhythm it really adds some nice detail to the track the vocals are incredibly weary on this six minute track it's the longest track on the album and I love how we get this weird little interlude in the midst of this LP where of the Stone Age really derails the song a little bit and takes it off roading the tense drum work on here and the wailing guitars and the weird segues and bridges at this point in the song it was a surprise it was kind of exciting I wish the band took a lot of songs in this direction really changed them up a little bit but still it did make this song itself quite the standout other songs on this LP though are not as drawn-out they're more concise they're more hard-hitting and no less entertaining the song if I had a tail as a murderous hook Josh brings these dark lyrics painting pictures of licking tears off of someone's face swatting flies with his tail if he had one the lyrics just have a really devilish attitude to them again we have another very desert inspired guitar solo on this thing and even though the vocal melody on this track over the verse is kind of redundant maybe slightly uninspired the groove is totally badass and I'm loving the guitar tone on this track and really nearly every track on here the guitar tones really are a glory to behold throughout this LP when they're not heavy they're very gritty when they're not gritty they're really warm again we have another little reunion on this particular track with Mark Lanegan delivering vocals and some lyrics for this song and the track my god is the Sun one of the better guitar intros for a track I think this year and it feels just as sharp as it did the first time I heard it when they premiered it online but the song Fairweather friends huge group vocals on this track and sort of an all-star cast of guest singers Elton John singing on this track and bringing piano as well Trent Reznor as well as Nick one of the band's former bassists even though there are a handful of collaborators on this track and on this album in general they really blend in - like clockwork seamlessly if I have any issues with this LP it's that maybe a few parts on some of these songs just underwhelm me slightly like the very dreary bassline on the opening track here or even the guitar intro on smooth sailing which sounds like it should be basically the television theme song for a reality show about rednecks who owned gas stations by long stretches of highway in the desert of course desert desert desert however I do love the zany falsetto vocals that Josh brings to the table on this track that are somewhat soulful in a way and the detuned guitar solo harmonies on this thing it's so awesome it's borderline hilarious you know honestly I got to say overall I love the cell P I know Queens of the Stone Age isn't on the rock fringe or anything like that and you know they're they're not trying to be and that's completely fine I know sometimes we emphasize that sort of thing on this channel but you know we also emphasize great songwriting fantastic production songs with personality great guitar tones potent emotions and in my opinion these songs have those things and and and more this is an incredibly cohesive album with its sharp hard-hitting tracks as well as songs that really sort of stretch out and give Queens of the Stone Age a bit more in the way of dynamics the band really shows their more sad side and I think it pays off in a big way and a great record really I'm feeling a strong eight to a light nine on this thing if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it this review is my opinion if you don't like it here's a straw I want to give a shout out to Bryden tracks man who was recently robbed and shot there's a link in the description box to donate to a bit of a fundraising thing he's got going on you know to take care of him because he's been shot help the man out also I want to give a shout out to a guy who asked for a shout out his name began with a w-wayne and filthy Frank all mistakes were intentional only the strong subscribe the needle drop Queens of the Stone Age like clockwork forever

deafheaven sunbather keep it hurry up hi everyone Anthony fan tanto here Internet's sweatiest stickiest music nerd I mean look sticky and it's time for a review of the new death heaven album sunbather death heaven is a West Coast loud rock outfit this is their sophomore full-length LP death wish records it's titled sunbather I dug on this band's debut full-length a little bit back in 2011 roads to Judah it was really well produced playing was great but stylistically compositionally I think this album a little bit fell into line too much with just a lot of popular American centric black metal sounds at the time there are just a lot of groups working within the same blueprint that they were on that album and even though I did like parts of it I was hoping that on their next album whenever that would be now I guess they would expand their sound a little bit get a little bit more adventurous now simply because of the blend of influences on this LP I could see question after question after question coming up does this album even stick out in the greater scheme of atmospheric black metal out there right now is it even black metal to begin with for sure black metal purists are not going to let Sun bather slip by as if it's you know a piece of the Nordic old-school I mean Cowell would know he was pretty involved with the scene if it aint Burzum it's bull Puckey whether it's black metal or not sunbae there features plenty plenty of man wretch focal 's blastbeats tremolo picked guitar leads quickly strummed walls of distorted guitar chords that burn like herald fire it's a pretty familiar recipe that even you should be aware of if you've been paying attention to the more american side of black metal as of late bands like Crowley's liturgy Agalloch wolves in the throne room still I think sunbather does stick out even though it's not the most technical of releases and it's not even really the most novel when it comes to ideas what I think may end up biting this album in the butt is not what is on the album at all but how people will perceive this LP I actually think maybe the whole black metal side of deafheaven sound especially on this album is being oversold a little bit because while black metal does play a large role in the music on this album there's also huge influences coming from post rock as well as ambient music a little bit of noise screamo and emo even though deafheaven stylistic influences are really clear on this album I feel they still come out on top simply because of their great production their type performances on these tracks as well as they're really memorable and just invigorating compositions composition really is one of the biggest strengths that this album does have to offer it is clear from the opening track on this thing Dreamhouse which I talked about in an earlier video the nine minute monster still floors me with every listen and it is one of the most overtly black metal tracks on the LP even as the band builds up to plenty of post rock like crescendos but what really makes the song stand out to me and what makes deafheaven stand out stylistically in general is that they take these very rough harsh abrasive loud rock sounds and mix them with such harmonious melodious rich and uplifting chord progressions and guitar leads it's kind of like listening to angels and corpse paint plug their harps into distortion pedals and just wailing away on them and the thing is sunbae there isn't even the longest track on this LP there are three other monsters on this thing that go up to ten eleven and fourteen minutes but before I dive into those I would like to talk about the flow of this LP a little bit death heaven does put quite a bit of work into putting some downtime in between these very long and rough black metal inspired tracks they segue each long piece with a shorter song it's a kind of obvious pattern that they lay into on this album but still it does pay off like the song irresistable which is this really nice guitar and piano piece some beautiful harmonized leads on this thing and what's so great is that the beginning of this track flows very nicely with the end of the previous song on your dream house so it's really like I'm listening to an extension of the same song I'm really loving the twang of these very patient guitars on this song it sort of reminds me a bit of explosions in the sky in a sense but what I think is so interesting about this song is that it is so light it's so beautiful it really sort of reveals that the Bands intentions even though the previous song was so rough are not that dark the other interlude on here please remember is a six minute track it's a bit of a drone noise piece with a vocal snippet for the first half and then it goes into some acoustic guitar some electric guitar leads and the way the leads weep on the second half of the song it really reminds me of God speed you black Emperor of course the first half with the noise and the vocal snipah again reminds me of that - and the third segue on here Windows has a huge god speed vibe to it as well with the very ominous guitars hanging in the background they're looped they're wailing they're droning and over this there is a vocal snippet of a man ranting about religion it does get a little obnoxious at this point that it feels like they're they're drinking from the same fountain again and again with these interludes as far as the three remaining epics on this album go boom a lot of these tracks even though there are blast beats and there are wretches on here they feature slower moments as well where the post rock influences and I think even the screamo influences that deafheaven has really shined through like the slow heavy distorted chords on the title track from this thing actually reminds me of some of the more post rock leaning bands and screamo like envy for example which isn't actually a bad thing I'm really enjoying the cross-pollination of these genres on this LP even if it isn't just accurately one genre throughout who cares what I think is awesome as the deafheaven takes anthemic guitar leads and multifaceted song structures and uses these to bring together one characteristic that I feel black metal post rock and screamo all have in common and that is just this overwhelming sense of passion with screamo comes through on the melodies the extreme vocals sometimes the lyricism with black metal it's the speed it's the abrasion is ferocity and with post rockets the crescendos and the builds the track vertigo on here is another favorite of mine on this LP really sort of works in three parts a very slow-moving first third I love how dreary the introduction of this track is and when the black metal inspired chords finally break through they had this weird warp somewhat sour quality to them that really makes them stick out the song has a really speedy speedy middle and the end which is incredibly tortured has rushes of guitars in there it is just eargasm after eargasm uh the only point at which this album really let me down was on the last couple tracks like I said I wasn't crazy about window and as far as the closer on here the pecan tree the song to me didn't really bring many new ideas melodically or just performance wise either the track even has these crunchy downstroke syncopated chords that the song Dreamhouse used to stick out I do like the flow of the track the very weepy and melodic midpoint does flow nicely into the very crushing end but with the fade-out on here it really feels like I'm not closing to this LP honestly no matter what genre you toss this LP into it is a really engaging melodic and passionately intense loud rock album tons of quality guitar leads on here great production fast tight performances don't let what influences this album or what it's trying to be or whatever you think it's trying to be ruin your your listening experience just give it a listen if it appeals to you it does if it doesn't it doesn't you know and just just take it from there I'm feeling a light too decent eight on this thing if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it this review is my opinion if you don't like it here's a straw I'm going to give a shout out to saint pepsi drifts and mason only the strong subscribe all mistakes were intentional death heaven deaf heaven deaf heaven nothin sunbather forever [Music]

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new bib EO album silver Wilkinson video is the pseudonym of uk-based electronic music producer Steven Wilkinson an incredibly versatile producer and multi-instrumentalist whose last full-length LP mind Buckhead eye compared to a chameleon in a musical sense with how many different musical styles and sounds it accurately emulated from arena rock to glitch pop on this LP a lot of basses get covered and of course stretching yourself so thin stylistically there were some weak spots and there were influences from IDM ambient music folk music hip hop music pop music glitch music he has a deep appreciation for sound and I can appreciate that deeply oh yeah and even though I didn't really love his last full-length album because of that because of how much of a mess the album felt like slightly the music on the LP really sort of mimics the art in that you have a bunch of ideas over here and they're overlapping some are shining more brightly than others it was a little inconsistent but in comparison silver Wilkinson is incredibly consistent actually I'm not saying this LP is gonna hit you grab you by the neck and drag you aggressively through one hit after another just slamming you with hard ass courses that are gonna just burn in your mind no instead silver Wilkinson is actually a pretty beautiful slow moving and ethereal grower a dream within a dream it's like listening to faint musical echoes while floating on a cloud of cotton candy with a palette of subtle beats acoustic guitars lovely analog synthesizers and some Pleasant vocals this album the ears gently in a really lovely way there are some beats on here that are of the more visceral variety like with the the track though dream pop dream folk these really light sweet sounds and genres are spearheading this album vibius still manages to work in a variety of different genres hip hop still has a place on silver Wilkinson most notably with the song you attract that feels very very indebted to J Dilla a strong hip hop beat that is a bit cloudy because of all the reverb in a good way and the song chops and consistently serene manner like the acoustic guitar piece Sycamore silhouetting this track has finger picked guitar arpeggios galore against what sounds like some very beautiful string or synthesizer melodies it really has a vibe to it that feels retro very retro like it's some kind of overblown full chamber pop from the 60s or 70s however I mean that in the most positive way possible there are actually moments on here where the very speedily picked guitars and some a psychedelic vibe of the effects feels a little grizzly bear inspired a lot of people and and me included have used the word pleasant in the past to describe albums that that typically put bliss over reals musical substance but I think on this album you you a little bit of your cake and you get to eat that bit too because there are plenty of strikingly beautiful moments among these very quiet songs like the progressive synthesizer interlude in the midst of the song mirroring all which follows a very acoustic first half kind of passed by aren't instantly memorable like the two-minute ambient track on this LP wolf or the seven-minute song look at a Ryan which is very very house music influenced which actually blends very nicely into the vibe of the album but not much goes on on this track that that strikes me as being beautiful it's just got kind of a decent groove to it I suppose and doesn't quite justify its length which is much longer than a lot of songs on here if anything the closer should have been longer which is actually a strikingly beautiful ballad great vocal melody on this track and I'm just loving the tone of the acoustic guitars one track after another with these spinning winding finger picked patterns oh the song Business Park which is okay I'm not completely thrilled with it does bring some drum machines and electric guitars they have a bit of a surf like tone to them but they're not playing surf rock style melodies and when the synths fly in and start playing some very bold leads it reminds me a bit of something like Square pusher would do overall gotta say on this LP bibby Oh does bring his usual variety I think we all know by now album after album videos mind is is with a very dreamy and calming veil the Fulk the electronic music the hip hop it all sounds like it agrees it all sounds cohesive it all sounds like it makes sense on this album which is fitting given the dreamy vibe of this LP because all of these genres would only work on an album in all trims that was stupid very enjoyable LP wasn't in love with every but still very solid and recommended I'm quasimodo hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for your review of the new Quasimodo album yes sir whatever Lorde coifs Quasimodo aka Madlib a producer multi-instrumentalist DJ and rapper hey guy who was infamous incredibly prolific he's really got more LPS than most with projects like yesterday's new quintet as well as mad villain he's also released numerous tracks under a slew of other names - like the beat conductor loop Digga monk hughes and of course it's not enough that this man just makes his ton of music on his own he needs to come up with an alter-ego to release more music hence Quasimodo now this new release is kind of a collection an album a bit of a compilation it's 12 tracks which the creation of spans about 12 years dating back to the release of Quasimodo's first full-length LP the unseen an album that ton of people who are in the underground hip hop praise the hell out of and for good reason and even though there are some new cuts on this project there are also songs on here that were previously released on an EP as well as other singles so it's not like this new release is 100% fresh though the cuts that have been previously put out are kind of rarities you know you're not going to come across them just anywhere one track after another on this thing involves libs treid mrk gritty jazzy blunted hip hop production which is funky as well and of course all of these beats are graced with his verses which he's known for taking the pitch of them and shifting it up if you took mad live and Shrunk him down to the size of a gnome this is essentially the voice that you would imagine coming out of him rapping and it's a kind of funny thing to hear in an age where the chopped and screwed sound is so prevalent in a lot of the hip-hop you hear it's almost refreshing in a way to hear somebody shifting their vocals up in pitch now with 32 minutes long even though yes or whatever is not as varied or as epic or as expansive as the unseen it is still a really fun listen even though Madlib doesn't take a lot of risks between the songs on this the beats he brings to the table are colorful they're classy they got a snap to them like the song planned attack which has these watery guitar samples left and right the kicks on this thing are deep as hell the snares are really thin and crisp there's a touch of reverb on there Quasimodo is rapping on this track sort of trading places with mad libs lower not pitched vocal they're these really catchy DJ cuts flying in and out of the track to it is the perfect recipe for a head Bob I'm loving the song broad factor on here as well in terms of the rhythm hiding behind all of the samples it's a little similar to the track I just mentioned it's actually similar to a lot of tracks on this LP but Madlib is good at taking these very similar grooves and colouring them with very very different samples to the point where each song really has its own vibe now there are points on this album that are a little underwhelming or for whatever reason they just don't stick like be very obvious obvious and repetitive vocal sampling on the track seasons change or mad libs kind of underwhelming verses on tracks like brothers can't see me or specifically the front mad libs rap style really tends to be sort of monotone somewhat lifeless in a way and hearing his voice pitched down to its normal pitch it actually is a bit of a hindrance since his voice doesn't exactly read too well against the Basie production there's also the very short track on your Youngblood which I guess I'm not too enthralled with but I honestly do think if you were to take most of the tracks out of the context of this album and just listen to them on their own that they wouldn't be that impressive to your normal hip-hop fan still even though there isn't you know a hot hot track on this LP yes sir is is far from a boring album because it really gains power from how all of these short tracks work together as a listening experience there's a serious power to the odd analog crackle of these tracks as they weave together into this gogo dodo like hip hop scape this is essentially the rap games answer to wacky land with all the Warped samples and synthesizers and ear candy effects there is something that is truly psychedelic about yes or whatever as far as verses go there are definitely some lyrical nuggets on this thing the song catching the vibe has Madlib talking about his music career versus the music career of more mainstream hip hop artists who sort of seem to be overnight sensations and turn out to be duds a few years down the road Quasimodo also has shots fired other rappers on the song planned attack there are also flaky people touchdown on a verse in this thing the song spark dolla is a bit of an ode to marijuana and the track green power in a way is is actually kind of sad it's one of the few moments where Mad Libs voice to me carries a completely different tone to it there are a lot of rap albums and mixtapes out there that I have heard that deliver more monotone flow and it completely turns me off however this project really is sort of the exception to that rule in a sense because this weird monotone flow along with some of the vocal effects really plays into building up this sort of hypnotic textured alluring funny entertaining and seductive aesthetic that Madlib pulls together on yes or whatever even though this is an amazing release it really is a tribute to Mad Libs talents that he can grab a series of tracks I'm going for God hi everyone Anthony Fantan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new bats album obsidian bats is the pseudonym of will weeson Feld he is a songwriter singer producer and his music made a relatively big splash back in 2010 through the full-length LP cerulean out on anti Cohn records a very colourful album loaded with beats that are very compressed wonky as well as glitchy and take a ton of influence from pop music as well as hip hop music it was a sound that was really popular during that year but has waned a little bit in buzz since then they're actually quite a few records that year they had a pretty buzzy glitch hop vibe to them people like toki monsta Teebs as well as no such thing had notable releases however on this new LP bats does not go back to his old ways to his old sound on his last full-length debut instead this new LP goes in a direction that brings together indie electronic music glitch pop and occasionally will tones the electronics down and wraps these songs and piano and strings much more acoustic instrumentation and most importantly he really comes through on this album and flexes those singer-songwriter muscles writing songs that not only have a lot of lyrics and his vocals right up front and center but verses and choruses so without question on obsidian wills vocal delivery and vocal personality plays a much larger role while this album is not as psychedelic or as otherworldly or maybe even as strange or as novel as cerulean bats does keep the sound play and some of the experimentation up there are lots of odd speedy almost unpredictable and glitchy pieces of percussion that pop up in nearly unpredictable places throughout many of these beats however if there is a downside to some of the percussion right off the bat on this LP it is not as heavy bass or fefe as some of the percussion on cerulean it definitely pales in comparison in terms of just resonances still there is detail on these more subtle beats that bats pulls together like on the track incompatible which has a very very dense complex rhythm to it it is a difficult beat it's a difficult groove and with the piano the strings and the acoustic guitar leading to this track there's a serious sense of I guess you could say wonderment it's got a bit of an old-world feel to it in a way I'm thinking like trees streams rocks animals sort of dancing by medieval castles magic sorcery the dark arts whether a track on here seems to emphasize acoustic instrumentation over electronic or vice-versa the production chops that Baths showcased on cerulean are still there they just show up in different ways if there is an issue that's keeping me from loving this LP though that I have to admit it's that I'm not as thrilled with will as a songwriter or really a singer for one wills voice to my ears is effeminately sharp with its tone and it's it's so much so that feel sort of zany to me at times not only that but wills vocals are mixed so high above a lot of the other electronics on these songs that it really overpowers some of the beats on this thing making it difficult to appreciate these songs for the good production that's in the background and there are tracks on here where the instrumentals do get so simple and straightforward that there isn't much else to observe but the vocals and the songwriting that bat's is trying to pull together like the song no eyes which features a kind of slow kick snare pattern that kind of reminds me of Nine Inch Nails track closer and like that track this one has a particular obsession with sex sex is kind of a fix in this song I mean the chorus pretty much is common that me the track is pretty much a poppy observation of the seperation between love and physical relations which is a fine subject matter to write a song about I just find too ever so slightly obnoxious kind of annoying typically wills vocals appeared on his previous material as an additional sound or just something that was adding a little extra color in my opinion added an edge to a lot of his songs even though at the time they were kind of off-the-wall still I do appreciate that there's a little bit of a theatrical element going on here something that feels sort of Antony in the johnsons or even Bjork inspired at times when bats really loses me on this LP it's when there is really no wonderment or much of anything interesting in the instrumental whatsoever really it's bats not doing glitch hop or even doing glitch pop but instead just making middle-of-the-road in the electronic music that reminds me of like dental like the song miasma sky however there are some bright spots there are some moments there are some highlights that I do dig on this LP like we saw Iron Works which in my opinion is so beautifully arranged and covered in extra instrumentation most notably the strings it's so well arranged it's impossible to deny and the song Accio airy the vocals on this track are toned down a little bit to a point where I can really not only tolerate them but enjoy them and the slow pace of the beat on this thing with the driving bass line kind of reminds me of like a 90's trip-hop tune and surprisingly I really like the dark murky wall of instrumentation on the song no past and the throbbing beat on this thing it's a little tortured the interjecting piano phrases that totally break the vibe of the song and transition back into it quickly are pretty interesting as well you'd think they would stick out and sort of ruin the flow of the track but they sort of enhanced how eccentric bats can be when he puts his mind to it overall this is a pretty decent mixed bag of tracks paths has really used this album in my opinion as kind of a training ground of firing range test for his singing songwriting chops as opposed to what we already know he can do as a producer and there are some hits there are some misses and there are songs that really sort of breeze by me and don't stick with me in any way shape or form I feel delight to decent six on this thing if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it this review is my opinion if you don't like it here's a straw I want to give a shout out to Germaine Carrie Jackie vine and cuts on your thumb only the strong subscribe all mistakes were intentional Anthony Fantana batts obsidian forever [Music] [Music]
