guys are a rock band from Willimantic Connecticut and this is their debut full-length LP on top shelf records and the band style is a pretty slow moving and building version of indie rock music with a very very sad and somewhat sent to mental disposition a lot of people have labeled it as emo which is not that surprising considering this band's musical similarities with groups like cap and jazz or mineral or Sunny Day Real Estate and in my opinion some very very early Modest Mouse if you've seen the other bands that are sort of in this same style make music that a lot of people described to have a kind of twinkly quality to it mostly because of the very thin and dainty tone of the guitar and these sparkling notes that the guitars play music like this can have its own emotional intensity to it even if it does tend to be a little whiny and sort of overbearing it points now if you didn't know there's a bit of an emo revival going on right now and I do feel somewhat fortunate to have one of the more promising bands in this revival in my own backyard are you serious there's a bit in there no way I did not mean it that that way also it's like over this way even though there are a lot of pre established bands in this new wave of emo music the world is a beautiful place does stick out instrumentally and compositionally they are a little more refined than a lot of bands I think you're going to run across in addition to rock instrumentation they do bring piano since horns strings there are quite a few builds and song structures on this album there are very very post rock inspired especially on the longer tracks in this album but not all of the songs on this thing do run long it isn't the most intensive al on the planet running about 35 minutes ten tracks in this short amount of time though the world is a beautiful place does create at least some love an emotional roller coaster I feel like they're very successful at that with tracks like heartbeat in the brain which starts off with some very patient driving guitars the song evolves and do a very easygoing Rock groove they're cute synthesizers over all of this these quieter and just sort of sweeter and more sentimental verses build up into a sort of loud soft dynamic explosive chorus the song trends downward once again at a very weepy slow guitar passages accompanied with strings and then a final explosion comes I don't mean to oversimplify the song structure of this track because while listening to it it is easy to kind of get wrapped up into the emotion that the band lays out especially when it comes to lyrics in which imagery of home and friends and saying goodbye or thrown out there it's a lot of nostalgia via suburbia which might not be everybody's emotional backdrop but these topics are approached poetically so these songs about these very familiar ideas don't exactly feel obvious if your arms become smoke oh no nothing left to hold even though I do commend this track on having multiple phases and a really nice series of builds the vocals do get a little tiring for me after a while as I listen to this kind of short LP I know whiny emo vocals aren't exactly known for being incredibly on target when it comes to tempo and pitch but the vocals get messy in a very unenjoyable way especially as the band is putting group vocals together on some of these tracks it makes some of the crescendos that the group vocals sing against feel way way way less epic and instead falling a little flat because it kind of feels like listening to a group of people sing a song that they all didn't really learn the words to even though I'm not completely in love with the gigantic group vocals on this LP it is the longer tracks on this album that I think consistently dazzle especially a track like picture of a tree that doesn't look okay we watch the fallen leaves turn to frozen trees it's been another year where the echo from the echoes go I know not a passionate reading but it does sound great on the album and I'm loving the tents build of guitars and just rolling snares on this track it really brings the song to an amazing crescendo of weeping violins and moving vocals and of course this song segues right into the one right after it in fact this album gains an amazing flow between the songs right the kind of middle point of the LP which was really enjoyable considering how disjointed the start of this thing was especially with the somewhat underwhelming opener which sort of dragged on very quietly with a little bit of string and as the nelson finishes off with its last handful of tracks it it stays pretty solid the song gig life is a sonic encapsulation of exactly that life on the road touring playing with the band blended with guitar and vocals that are very ballad like in comparison with some of the other songs on this album the lyrics of course touched down on different places different settings it fits in very nicely with that sentimental nostalgic vibe that many of these tracks go for and strangely enough the group vocals on the track low light assembly go over pretty well I suspect maybe because they're so quiet whisper quiet really as the song rolls on through a bunch of guitar passages that remind me a lot of bands like let's say explosions in the sky or God is an astronaut for example but still it's not like the instrumentation gets that huge and the vocals are there still to remind the listener that this album is in an emo mindset which is fine and the band delivers a pretty ambitious closure as well though I am not huge again on the gigantic background vocals it is a finishing drag that does in its own right feel kind of cinematic I could really see the the credits rolling and I can't even read who was the key grip because the tears welling up in my eyes overall this is a really solid emo record I gotta say it's not one of my favorites of all time but it does live up easily to the standards set by some of the biggest releases in the genre people who are in love with this vocal style even though not all the lyrics are audible I think you will get into this album a little bit easier than me probably fall head over heels for it I'm feeling a decent Distronic seven on this album if you've given a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why and what do you think I should review next that's it this video was my opinion if you don't like it here's a straw I want to give a shout-out to Julia bad backyards Amanda Bynes feel better edie rest in peace and Doug only the strong subscribe all mistakes were intentional Anthony Fantana the world is a beautiful place and I am no longer afraid to die whenever if ever for ever [Music]

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for your review of the new classics album Hanging Gardens classics is a California electronic music duo this is their full-length debut LP and according to NPR music who was streaming this LP pretty recently they are in fact childhood friends who have been making music for quite a while now they have some new singles out from the cell P they've also got some remixes commercial remixes under their belts as well but this LP is really their first big outing it's on innovative leisure and stylistically what we have here are a series of tracks that are pretty much just very bouncy bouncy house music electronic dance music with a strong retro vibe that feeling is definitely in the air thanks to some recent releases like Daft Punk's random access memories and there are some other spots on this LP where the instrumentals remind me of this very warped strange otherworldly nostalgic sensation that I would typically get from something like chillwave music though this is definitely not as experimental or it is hazy I think Hanging Gardens functions off some very similar sentimental notions the grooves and the attitude that classics brings to the table reminds me of many a release from DFA records especially the one track on here that actually features Nancy Wang on vocals however even though I do compare this LP a little bit to some DFA releases classics definitely Nyx's the grit the urgency and the sort of Punk edge that releases on that label typically burn instead the beats the synthesizers and shimmering glistening piano chords on this LP add up into what is dance music's take on a smooth sailing sunny day it's Beach weather in the 80s in Southern California and as a result a number of tracks off of this LP are mint yes mint dance tracks that are worthy of inclusion in many many DJ sets tracks like all you're waiting for with Nancy Wang and I'll get you with chip Depp these tracks have snappy snappy beats and cyntha melodies that are so sweet and sticky it's like a drippy melting popsicle yet and then I want to lick it oh you're waiting for the vocal features on these tracks to me are just really confident they're bold they stick out I love the single holding on off of this LP - there's some really sort of cheesy 80s synth riffs soaring strings a punchy beat really great bouncy piano chords to me this track honestly feels like classics grabbed a little piece of each instrument from the hit song TV killed the radiostar and made some kind of weird house remix of it that was so manipulated it didn't even really sound like its source material these are just really sharp dance tracks in my opinion however there are other songs on here that are either so short they are so lacking in progression or they're so reverb heavy that they lack bayi it's to a point where if any of these tracks were to be played out in my opinion they would only be interesting as a transition toward something else tracks like rhythm Santa Clara as well as the song Domino's and two other tracks on this LP - that also have vocal features sadly the song long lost which features active child and a stranger love with Sara turn off both of these tracks while they're not terrible songwriting wise there are so much reverb especially laid onto the vocals in these songs that really sort of sucks the life in the body out of the voices especially active child whose solo material I have enjoyed I know from previous recordings his voice has quite a bit of body to it so I'm kind of shocked to hear it sounding so thin and and borderline lifeless on Hanging Gardens overall I do have to say this is a pleasant enough dance album with some real highlights and a few potholes as well there are quite a few sunny smooth and kind of beachfront inspired tracks on this LP put this album on and you will smell the ocean air I just feel like there needs to be a few more punchy tracks on here like the song super nature which is a pretty hard edged piece of electro funk and the closer on here a somewhat catchy and kind of sensual piece of synthesizer pop they're just a good handful of tracks on this LP that in my opinion are kind of like dancefloor wallpaper they're fine while they're on but I don't really miss them when they're gone I'm kind of feeling a light to decent sex on this album if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why that's it this review is my opinion if you don't like it here's a straw I want to give a shout out to Michelle Tony Brody Brody Brody fruit flies in my apartment and Jeremy only the strong subscribe all mistakes were intentional Anthony Fantana classics Hanging Gardens forever

wow that's good gonna work on that a little bit but it's coming together hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new this routine is hell album howl this is the latest full-length LP from this netherlands rock outfit recorded produced by kurt blue of converge fame a guy who must be one of my favorite producers of all time given that there are so many reviews in my back catalogue of albums that he produced and I would say on how Kurt strikes gold once again with these European up-and-comers now the band this routine as hell might not be extremely well known and it may seem as if Kurt Balu working with a guy of his stature would be a huge opportunity for them but this routine is how goes into this record pretty confident in their sound already back in 2010 the band dropped the full-length LP V Verve crusade which featured a lot of hardcore punk stylings slowed down to a slightly sludgy pace with some very heavy undertones but it's not like the band was particularly heavy production wise it's not like there was a lot of bass and Rumble in the mix the tone of the vocals were pretty average for hardcore but it was just the clarity and the passion and the directness of the lyrics that really sort of made the vocals stand out for me which in my opinion is a quality that I love so much about old old hardcore punk music where the lyricist really wanted to make a statement make a message on this LP this routine is held would occasionally speed things up like a hardcore band typically does but they would go on to their next EP repent repeat to indulge in a much heavier and sludgy er sound that was spring of last year and now with the album how will the band's sludge your side is in even fuller of effect but they still do maintain their hardcore punk style even as they're slowing things down a little bit more of course they still bring plenty of memorable readable and very message heavy lyrics and the end result on this LP is essentially 12 tracks and 20 minutes of some incredibly glass smashing bitter punk rock that I think fans of adrenaline pumping riffs and grooves and very fed up lyrics will enjoy this album kicks things off pretty well with one of the opening tracks on here in nostalgia which to be completely honest does have a riff a chord progression a groove and the pacing of the vocals on this track as well all of it reminds me of a recent track from the California hardcore punk band ceremony SiC it's really a dead ringer of course there are some small variations in the riff and this version is a lot heavier but I still can't help but love it the production on this track feels way thicker way more layered I'm loving the ominous guitar feedback as well and instead of a song about being sick very satirical e of a number of things this track is really a lyrical assault against nostalgia nostalgia burns us it does other things too according to the lyrics and there's just this impeccable energy even though the band isn't playing that quickly it almost feels as if they're playing very fast because of just how savage the energy is this track quickly segues into the next with a little bit of noise and I love that I love that this album really has a fantastic flow to it really it's just one song bleeding into the next and this happens in more ways than one - like the song shiver which really feels like an elongation of the previous track the title track from this LP howl now shiver is a slower track I wish it was a little bit more eventful though there is a great guitar solo on the end of this cut that just wails with passion as how progresses it just dishes out more and more tracks that feature essential grooves essential riffs which are backed up with some very interesting transitions and choruses really packed and condensed into songs that lasts about 40 seconds to two minutes like the song wrongdoer which has this just very stiff bashing intro riff which very quickly and suddenly transitions into the to this very sinister and gloomy guitar interlude and 3/4 overall in this LP I will say there are some unmemorable moments most notably the forty second long tracks which of course don't take a long time but still aren't that short in comparison with some of the other songs on this album I guess these songs don't really offer me anything to grab on to it's like they're here and they're gone without really putting out a riff or a melody that sticks in my head in their very short time span especially the untitled track on here which just is one short feedback piece still it's it's really the last portion of the cell P where I think this album gets incredibly solid the track I wait to see the world feels like a cinder block to the head it feels like a sidewalk faceplant with it's hard ass riffs and devilish melodies over the verses I think the song asleep has the same qualities as well I love the slow and sort of patient build of the song uncommon ground a lot of different parts to this track though I will say it does come off a bit more disjointed than some of the other songs on here still this song highlights to me was very important about this album and that's a lyrical theme it's a theme that many other tracks on here bring up through imagery of burning down towns breaking fingers from hands which at one time gave one a certain hand of cards anesthetize enjoy more than the ordinary there are just tons and tons of lyrics throughout this album which deal with not accepting what has just been handed to you and either fighting for or destroying what was given to you and trying to rebuild something better which in my opinion is a pretty strong and inspirational message even if it is expressed in a pretty angry way on this album overall I feel like this is a well written produced performed and pretty thrilling hardcore punk album with some strong lyrical themes there are some songs a few on here that pale in comparison to others but really I don't have many complaints at all I'm feeling a light a decent eight honest thing it's not exactly reinventing the wheel by do you think it's great if you've given this LP a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why that's it this review is my opinion if you don't like it here's a straw I want to give a shout out to Paris Hilton good job on the little Wayne song the national fans I'm sorry I'm sorry also Alicia bananas Edom and the city of Chicago whose school board voted to close 50 schools even Cal chest and all that not good only the strong subscribed all mistakes were intentional Anthony Fantan oh this routine is hell howl forever [Music] [Music]

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here intranets busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Anamanaguchi LP endless fantasy Anamanaguchi is a New York electronic music outfit who is pretty well known for combining rock instrumentation with bright bright super bright 8-bit style synthesizers and percussion it's the sound that they've been molding since those thousands to incorporate lots and lots of melody super distorted guitars pretty heavy drums taking musical cues from video game soundtracks like super r-type or numerous Mega Man games now there's a plethora of different video game musics out there and on amana Gucci definitely does not take a ton of influence from some of the more quirky dark or even dramatic sounds to come out of video game music instead the music that automata Gucci creates seems like it would be best set to visuals of epic space battles futuristic buildings colorful armored lasers and hover cars reaching speeds of 100 miles per hour now the band's latest LP endless fantasy also captures these vibes but does it while stretching out the band's stylistic basis meaning they take their 8-bit sound and they just try out more genres with it while primarily the band was known for fusing rock instrumentation with 8-bit sense and percussion like I said earlier now on endless fantasy the band is trying their hand at Japanese pop electro pop a little bit of house music now some of the genre hopping that the band does on endless fantasy is is very very much needed because this is a pretty long stretch of an album with 22 tracks spanning 76 minutes in a way it's almost as if the band is sort of making up for lost time because it has been a while since their last full-length LP if you don't count the soundtrack music that they did for the Scott Pilgrim video game with so many tracks on this album that feel very very similar emotionally and sonically I can't help but feel like even though I do enjoy endless fantasy to an extent the album is somewhat bogged down there are highlights on this album for sure very well written highlights and well produced highlights but maybe they don't stick out as well as they possibly could one of the songs that dropped before the selfie meow which I absolutely loved when I first heard it and still do loving the pumping bassline on this track the silly meow sounds coming through the song to the anthemic synthesizes lead melodies on this track that rush very colorfully as the chorus soars meeny-meeny-meeny this song really hits that sweet spot that Anamanaguchi is great at hitting which combines very awesome and anthemic and well written melodies with just outright absurdity while the band does have this real talent for writing instrumental rock tunes it just feels like they don't want to take themselves too seriously and just kind of keep things fun now while some people may hate the inclusion of this track on this album I will defend for sure the song prom night it is an electro-pop tune with a very radio-friendly vocal beat and hook and while I do think the lyrics on this track are kind of cheesy the hook the chorus is freakin killer and I actually think if the band comes through with the right music video for this track it could kind of be their crossover hit I dig the song in the basement because it does bring a little bit of variation with some breezier lighter instrumental verses with some very clear guitar strumming going on in there the songs snow angels and planets stick out to me because they are incredibly pretty slow jams I'm loving how the band can just take the tempo turn it down and make something that is as pretty to listen to as a very starry night sky is to look into and some of the harder hitting tracks like Veridian Genesis which is pretty exciting with it's very sudden tempo change in how a sort of blasts off in a very speedy way however other tracks on here just feel too similar in style whether it's to other songs on this album or previous material from Anamanaguchi like the song SPF 420 feels like the band grabbed one of their previous singles airbrushed drove it to a Chop Shop and then use parts from it for this song and oddly enough one half of the lead melody from the song pastel flag sounds just like Nellie's dilemma and tracks like a Keira or spaced wax America while I do welcome all Weezer and anime references I don't see what these tracks bring to the album others don't already and songs like endless fantasy as well as Japan air while automatic gucci is trying out house music and a little bit of Japanese pop on these tracks I don't see what Anamanaguchi brings to the genres other than an 8-bit aesthetic because I'm not really in love with these tracks for their Tunes or their structure I mean I consider myself to be a pretty patient listener for sure I have loved albums that are much longer than this one I just feel like their insistence on going for this one sonic vibe on many of these tracks drowns out some of this album's hidden potential because even when a song or a melody on this LP may be particularly good it doesn't really stick out because so many of the songs on this LP there's not a lot of sonic diversity for sure they're solid tracks on this LP that I could enjoy singularly but as I listen to this album as a whole the experience is kind of like getting belly sick off of a giant bag of candy that I was pretty convinced once I started eating it I could finish at their worst on the cell P the tracks are decent at their best they're great they're fantastic do give this thing a listen if you're looking for something very melodic incredibly produced fun and this feeling may last longer for you than it did for me exciting I'm feeling a strong 6 - Ally 7 on this thing if you've given it a listen what did you think did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it this review is my opinion if you don't like it here's a straw I want to give a quick shout out to Oklahoma get better repair rebuild also tiny mixtapes 5 second films and carrots eat them only the strong subscribe all mistakes were intentional Anamanaguchi endless fantasy Anthony Phan tanto forever [Music] you you

from sea to shining sea hi everyone Anthony Fantino here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for your review of the new national album Trouble will find me the National is an American rock band they've been dropping full-length albums since the early 2000s and they're relatively well known for their very gloomy musical attitude which is topped with the very deep monie and somewhat understated vocals or frontman Matt Berninger many of the band's tracks follow some pretty slow tempos are covered with very syrupy slow musical accompaniment and many of the lyrics that come through on the national songs deal with having a difficult time dealing with personal emotions heartbreak it's a formula the band has stuck to pretty passionately even as different albums of theirs have gone for slightly different musical vibes like the band OMS LP boxer which dropped in 2007 which had a pretty strong post-punk vibe on it but took a much more adult and mature approach to making music in this genre we have the band's earlier stuff as well which did delve into a bit of Americana all country at some points and their latest full-length album before the release of this LP hi violet was actually so adorned in extra instrumentation the band was pretty much in chamber pop territory at that point and it's pretty safe to say on this new LP of the Nationals that the band is in roughly the same territory that they were on hi violet especially with tracks like don't swallow the cap on this thing which are loaded with refined strings the swell and bounce against very gently pulsating guitars drums and bass however hi violet was an LP that I didn't really care for as much as many other people did for one there were not enough punchy highlights on the album that were as good as lead singles like blood buzz Ohio and on top of it the extra instrumentation that the National were laying into their songs which was playing very slowly and really really made the tracks on this LP in my opinion kind of impenetrable because the guitars bass and drums playing under this dreary instrumentation was already slow and kind of dreary to begin with in my opinion it made the band's music rife with apathy and an interest when clearly at least to me anyway it felt like they were going for something a little more sad and somewhat depressive now even though I didn't really love hi violet and this new LP as well sadly maybe the Nationals approach to making sad music is a little bit more true to form than some other sad songs that we know of out there today that might be a little bolder in terms of instrumentation and melody like it or not the Nationals music really draws a line between music where sadness or depression is merely the subject matter in the lyrics and a song when sadness and depression as a feeling as an emotion literally permeates every single element and characteristic of the music that you're hearing from the tempo to every piece of instrumentation to the melody writing through the chords the lyrics the vocal delivery and while I may see that in their music at least the National is conveying these feelings in a very personal way as an outsider as a listener to me the band's music comes off consistently as sort of boring and emotionally stunted and melodically bland listening to this album is like watching a guy bum around in his New York City condo in silk pajamas on a rainy day while listening to losing my religion on repeat through his iPod speaker dock with three days of stubble on his face now let me say that existential crises are real and should be face down if you overcome them they can't become moments of personal growth or fester if you completely ignore them however the crises that Trouble will find me presents feel so temporary from the first chord strummed on the opening track of this LP it doesn't even feel like there's any reason to get invested for sure there are moments on this LP where I feel like the band is channeling Leonard Cohen a little bit but never do they come off as dramatic or maybe even a little bit of magnetic fields comes through but the national was just not as quirky though they don't really try to be as quirky but I wouldn't say they're as clever or as melodically memorable either or as poetic I feel like the band can definitely be pretty engaging or dramatic when it comes to writing a hook or throwing instrumentation out there the song fireproof is definitely example but when the verses come through Matt's vocals the pace of his lyrics and what they're saying is well to me personally feel sort of unengaging with how slow they're moving I guess in a sense I just get a little impatient waiting for something that would justify all of this there are other highlights on here in my opinion like the song pink rabbits which is a pretty solid piano ballad melodically the song demons is very interesting in its seven eight times signature puts an interesting groove out there which the band performs very nicely so smoothly that it doesn't even become apparent that the song is in 7/8 and the song sea of love which is one of the more epic songs on this LP very passionate background vocals rapid-fire snare drums shimmering guitars building instrumentation but once again on this LP all of these very pretty colors and pretty pieces of instrumentation pretty individually meld together and blend into a uniformly unappealing and uninspiring it's hard for me to just dive into these things and say hey this is great this is great this is great because I don't really care for the Nationals music on this record simply based on its premise all of these ideas which may be great on paper are filtered through this very syrupy slow no justification lethargy Len that just doesn't really appeal to me this album in my opinion is just well-dressed listlessness overall I'm really sort of feeling a light too decent for on this record if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it this review is my opinion if you don't like it here's a straw I want to give a shout out to Austin for being a cool bro Kieran Leonard for being an even cooler I want to give a shoutout to Kanye for not sounding like Death Grips and of course Justin Bieber don't worry Cal takes you seriously Cal is a believer throwing through only the strong subscribe all mistakes were intentional Anthony Fantana the National Trouble will find me forever [Music]

random access memories hi everyone Anthony Fantino here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for you review the new Daft Punk album random access memories the kings of French house are back with a new full-length album that has been quite the buzz for a good chunk of this year thanks to an incredibly hot single that was dropped before the release of this album get lucky and what has also really turned heads about this new full-length is the very diverse set of collaborators that Daft Punk is brought on board to create this album guitarist Nile Rodgers panda bear from Animal Collective pianist composer Chilly Gonzales songwriter Paul Williams Pharrell and Julian Casablancas from The Strokes but what's even crazier about this LP is the direction that Thomas and guide man take the music in if you're my age or a little older you remember growing up and sort of coming of age with very hot singles like one more time harder better faster stronger and around the world of course the LP these songs came from discovery is solid from front to back on top of that the release of interstellar five five five five and prior to that homework it was almost as if Daft Punk was getting better and better and could do no wrong however the duo did hit a minor snag in the mid-2000s with the release of human after all the album overall was much less thematic than Discovery on top of that the very thin distorted production all over this album with the very repetitive grooves and slight rock influence certainly some good singles came out of this LP but there were some kind of shaky deep cuts because the effects and the aesthetic that Daft Punk were going for on this album really overshadowed and sort of choked off what quality the tunes had to offer still as Daft Punk moved on past human after all it was the timelessness of their previous singles that went on to define them not only that but they dropped a very stellar live album in 2007 and went on to produce what some people consider to be a pretty quality soundtrack with Tron and even though that was a huge project for Daft Punk and brought them a lot of exposure this new album of theirs might be a bit more ambitious especially since they're kind of throwing their trademark sound out the window on this album they're abandoning house music and instead embracing the sounds of 70s and 80s synth funk disco soft rock as well and this isn't like another human after all whether taking on rock music and doing it with electronics there's a ton of live instrumentation on this new album while some people may argue that this is Daft Punk drifting away from their roots I think that this is them getting to the roots of their roots and re envisioning it in a way that feels like it's authentically them it's kind of a risk for Daft Punk even if they do keep their handy vocoders very close at their sides now this new sound that Daft Punk is shooting for on this LP it spells out a much livelier and lighter sound on this album tracks like get lucky sound like a very nostalgic pastel fun-loving night out at Studio 54 not some kind of 2:00 a.m. rave session with banging bass and massive speakers in a gritty grimy downtown club Daft Punk is not the only major electronic music artist in recent years to trade in many of the electronics that they typically futz with for more live instrumentation and a somewhat vintage feel you can look at square pusher with a few of his most recent albums as well as what he was doing with Shova leader one or even Daft Punk worshipers justice with what they were doing on their last full length album audio-video disco an album where justice was fussing around with a lot of the same musical movements that Daft Punk is on random access memories now this new LP of Daft Punk's has a very clean shimmering rich production sound lots of drums very snappy tons of kick and hi-hat on this thing the guitars have a nice sharp metallic tone to them and bounce very playfully when Nile Rodgers brings his trademark strumming patterns this album doesn't really get hot and heavy with the horn sections this isn't a KC and the Sunshine Band kind of thing as shown on the opening track from the cell P a lot of the crescendos builds and extra instrumentation is executed with electronics vocoder vocals synthesizers of many shapes and size as many tracks on this LP field disco but it's executed with a somewhat more modern flair as if this disco music had occurred and had been recorded in the 80s and I do realize we've seen melds of these two ideas in the past through genres like euro disco electro disco Italo disco historically we can see that the music in the 70s and that the music in the 80s happened right next door to each other but Daft Punk makes a record here that brings these eras right on top of each other brings out their commonalities in a way that feels very natural light-hearted fun occasionally cheesy but also ambitious and kind of cinematic it points like I said they're very sharp punchy disco tracks on this thing like the opener give life back to music the song has a sweet infectious vocal melody that I love and I love the mantra of this track about man giving life back to music I'm feeling that and when this song goes for a rush of instrumentation the distorted guitars come in and it kind of feels like I'm listening to some kind of huge instrumental break from an 80s arena rock or prog rock song instrumentally tracks like this one don't just feel like loosely grooved out and perform dance songs they feel very methodical and kind of composed like the song lose yourself to dance come out come out come out come out moments like this are very carefully layered over the grooves and happen at precise points to make the music continue to be engaging from beginning to end this song and the track get lucky are both fronted vocally by Pharrell and these songs take a lot of disco sounds a lot of disco grooves but repeat them out with sort of a house electronic music mentality I will say the only shortcoming of these two tracks and it hurts the song lose yourself to dance even more is that Pharrell's falsetto on these songs isn't the best he's no Barry Gibb get lucky because he does work in more of his mid range does go over a lot better and has grown on me since I first heard it and believe me I've heard it dozens of times since it first dropped on the Internet the hook on this track is hella catchy and I love the way the beat shifts from when Pharrell is singing to when dat Punk comes in with the vocoder vocals it is a nice change in groove the track is so good it's making Cal want to get lucky yes baby even the song instant crush isn't bad which features Julian Casablancas on vocals the only thing I didn't really care for on this track was that the vocoders were just a little Miravalle for me on this song still tuned wise the track wasn't bad it had some downstroke guitars on it sort of felt like a stroke song but with a bit of an electronic edge to it on the song fragments of time which is one of the least electronic tracks on this LP Daft Punk brings on electronic music producer Todd Edwards to front this song vocally which is essentially a pretty sweet piece of soft rock though this track does sort of expose a flaw overall on random access memories yes Daft Punk is reaching back but there are some spots on the selkie where I wish things fell or just sounded a little bit more novel and I think some people are going to feel that way considering Daft Punk's pioneer electronic music status they've got their own sound they've got their own style why copy ideas from the Boston playbook still the song is done pretty well and the way I see it and enjoy is just by sort of taking it as one part in the larger picture of random access memories which to me is an expression of a group of different musical eras enacted animatronic Lee in this glorious Museum of the future disco smooth funk and soft rock are not the only things that are worshipped on this LP there's some very sensual and beautiful slow jams and ballads on this album as well songs like within beyond and the game of love now think what you want to think about these tracks they're soft they're not the most hard-hitting or anything like that but to me these songs are the closest Daft Punk come to doing something that is more alike to their older stuff if you take a song from Discovery like something about us where you've got very jagged bass lines a slow groove that's very disco influenced guitars and since adding a little bit of color here and there and of course vocoder vocals those robot vocals singing upfront a very strong melody a ballad and lot York's about love what daftpunk does on these slow Jamz off this album they've done before and they're doing it just as well here as they have in the past while some people have criticized the lyrical content of tracks like lose yourself to dance and get lucky certainly Daft Punk makes up for that on these tracks by proving that their lyrical prowess is still there the track game of love is incredibly heartbreaking with its portrayal of dying love in its lyrics the song within lyrically to me is very surreal and gives me the listener a sense of just smallness in this gigantic big difficult to understand world and lyrically the song beyond to me is like a very passionate journey of the soul somewhat sad and forlorn one too and on the beginning of this track Daft Punk bringing in a huge epic string section really flexing that instrumental muscle that they brought through on Tron it speaks of places never seen it is the birthplace of your dreams and as far as another slow jam on this LP doing it right with pandabear actually surprised me a lot and turned out to be incredibly good and enjoyable typically when I catch a panda bear feature on an album with another artist panda bears vocals come through and totally derail whatever vibe the album add going on however that didn't really seem to be the case on this LP I actually think pandas vocals not only were complemented really well at the very spacious music on this track but the way that he sung on the song lended itself well to the vibe that Daft Punk was going for on this album maybe it got a little eccentric as he was climbing up in range ah-ha-ha-ha-ha but still it did not become over bearing good job I love the subtle progression of this track instrumentally it was a nice song to tag on the end of this LP it felt like the slow motion montage soundtrack to an unforgettable night out with your friends now I really dig the disco tracks on this LP I love the slow jams on this LP but this album really dazzles when it comes to the longer more ambitious and more instrumentally fleshed out tracks like Giorgio by Moreau dare to have this dude on this album just shows how far that Thomas and guy man will go to get that authentic sound for this record to really pay homage to the musical eras that they are worshipping I love the students narration on this track his personal story that comes through he is just telling it how it happened and how he sees it and how his life went and what brought him to this point and the music is incredibly epic against his vocals the sequence synthesizers which really create a saga of sound the song sounds a little cheesy at first but there's an incredible energy to it as it progresses the song eventually turns into what I think is kind of a synth lead progressive rock jam it's incredibly ambitious especially as strings come in through on the latter half of the track and really fill the song out beautifully and the very dramatic song touch on this album which totally makes sense if you take a look at Paul Williams career writing songs for his singers writing songs for television writing songs for soundtracks I love the opening of this track Paul's voice sounds fantastic emotive as hell the song picks up steam eventually going into a string of very funky disco grooves that are incredibly again smooth and then on the latter portion of this thing it slows down and brings in a huge chorus again Daft Punk going for that epic musical accompaniment and some of the things that Paul is singing on this track about touching feeling being convinced that he's he's real almost it's like Daft Punk is bringing lyrics that sort of toy with the idea of being a human having feelings or being a robot and and what it means to kind of cross those planes to me the song is rock opera s maybe something meatloaf fans can really appreciate and there few other tracks on here which are very instrumentally impressive too like the track motherboard which to me isn't one of my favorite songs on this LP I think the composition the structure of this song could have been a little bit more interesting but the woodwind on this track the pace of it is very tense and it's again Daft Punk flexing that instrumental muscle and the closing track on this thing contact epic epic finish it gets so intense so distorted so heavy it really finishes this album off with a bang overall God's a incredibly impressed with this album not only did Daft Punk recapture all these old musical styles redo a lot of them with a new modern flair and kind of their own twist on it mix them all together onto this one LP where they all have a lot of different qualities to them stylistically because the duo covers a lot of different genres on this thing not just a handful and they have an incredible flow to them from beginning to end on this LP sure there are a few tracks on here that sort of paled in comparison to others but even though Daft Punk isn't pioneering into some kind of new electronic music territory what makes this album so amazing to me is that it is a tribute a tribute to music and it's a passionate well produced and well performed one at that I'm feeling 80 on the cell peak if you've given it a listen what did you think of it love it hate it why that's it this review was my opinion if you don't like it here's a straw want to give a shout-out to Dodie Bob Tammy Timothy and Big Joe only the strong subscribe and all mistakes were intentional Daft Punk random access memories Anthony Fantan Oh forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Dillinger Escape Plan album one of us is the killer The Dillinger Escape Plan is a New Jersey lab rock outfit who since the late 90s has been one of the most interesting groups out there to meld elements of hardcore and metal now despite the band's very complex and type playing heavy guitars they have pretty much avoided many tags from the prog metal or the gent direction and on the new LP as well the band deflects those labels mostly because of their post hardcore influence which occasionally pops up on these tracks and they're very Mike Patton inspired chord progressions and vocal experiments it's stuff like this that has kept the band's music pretty interesting over the years as they have stayed devoted to their very spastic fast disorienting musical style now on this new full-length LP The Dillinger Escape Plan is just as hard-hitting as ever matching up difficult to pin down guitar riffs with drums that are dizzying to say the least thanks to Billy rhymer for those and the band's frontman great but not only is he an aggressive fierce vocalist but he is very dynamic as well sometimes channeling vocal ranges and Tambor's that remind me of guys like Mike Patton as well as Trent Reznor many of the tracks on the selfie feature speedy riff laden versus but slowed down almost instantaneously as soon as the chorus hits and soar melodically and not to mention our incredibly catchy Dillinger clearly displays the line separating a melodic chorus from a Wimpy chorus and they don't cross it not even once on this LP as if it's easy even as they present songs on here like the title track which has a very ethereal intro sort of has a a very moody tumbleweed spaghetti-western kind of set up to it and Greg comes through singing swapping out his very fierce growls and head's splitting screams for very passionate falsettos and some really great singing in his mid-range - they're just really crushing chords on the hook - this song [Music] loving the melody on this track and at the end of every measure I believe that's the term I want to use the band has a little bit of variation on the riffs and the grooves just to bring just a touch of newness freshness anymore it keeps things interesting and also with the chorus on this thing it is so sweet and it's so catchy and I actually think this track could do some radio play if you're talking about you know a modern metal hard rock station and nobody would even flinch at being offended or this is too loud or this is too aggressive a lot like older bands like Faith No More who clearly have at least a little bit of an influence on this record The Dillinger Escape Plan finds a perfect balance between extremity and accessibility this track is just really really easy to get into even if you're not a huge metal fan even if you're just a regular rock fan however it doesn't really feel like the band compromised their sound that much to make this track there are other tracks on here too which come off a little mr. bungle esque as they switch their drums and guitars from metal mode to kind of jazzy lounge mode tracks like nothing's funny which to me has one of the most stellar hooks on this LP and paranoia shields this track in particular shows the band bringing in some really nice background instrumentation this is a move that the band is no stranger to there have been plenty of LPS in their back catalog that have featured strings but strings don't actually play at least a noticeable role on this LP on this particular track horns and epic huge background vocals this track is one of the longer and more multifaceted songs on this album I love how much the band is able to throw at me the listener and yet keep things pretty cohesive the song cross burner is pretty long and multifaceted as well to go back to instrumentation the only moment we're adding a little bit extra see if that old was with the song magic that I held you Dillinger works in what feels like a little bit of glockenspiel on the track however it melds with the heavy metal guitars in the song horribly it feels as if they had to mix it over the guitars much louder than anything else actually just to get it to read audibly against the distortion the banging drums now these very catchy sweet straightforward and instrumentally refined tracks or counterbalance very nicely with tracks that are nothing but earthquake like Furies of riffs and drums they're bloody they're like the song Prancer that opens the cell P up Oh tons of shrill chords all over this thing it's just a pummel session at the listener and it's really one of the most blazing openers I've heard on a metal record this year I also love the chord changes that come into play and the epic melodic ascent the song makes toward the end as well it's a nice second half at this track presents also the syncopated chords and vocals that are met with skipping drums on the next track on this LP when I lost my bet our masterfully played that track and understanding decay are more examples prime examples of this band playing grooves that are so odd and strange and yet they rock them so fluidly to the point where yeah sure they're technically proficient but the listener has such a straight visceral reaction to it you don't really need to sit there and think about what the groove is or how you should Bob your head to it it just comes so naturally with how they play it off showing that The Dillinger Escape Plan is the band for you if you're more into just being rocked and having a reaction than just simply flashy playing because certainly they have that the only track on here that really kind of left me cold and still you know do you really have a lot of momentum - it was the eighth track on here which was relatively shortened to me really felt like more of a riff idea than a song and the closer on the end of this album didn't really feel that climactic in my opinion it was rough it was wild but maybe I was waiting for a bit of closure or something at the end of this LP overall I have to say maybe this is slightly a little bit Dillinger Escape Plan by the numbers and it sort of wears a lot of khatyn isms on its sleeve still this is an incredibly performed written and produced metal record very solid and I would I commend it to anybody who was looking for some loud rock that is not only accessible but has a little bit of an edge to it has a strong element of surprise and some interesting riffs I'm feeling a light a decent eight on this thing if you've given it a listen hey what did you think what should i review next that's it this review was my opinion if you don't like it here's a straw want to give a shout-out to Timmy Michael Joe jr. Sarah and Ashley all mistakes were intentional only the strong subscribe Anthony Fantana The Dillinger Escape Plan one of us is the killer forever [Music]

no doubt that if you were to catch these guys live yourself that you would end up with something a little bit different than what I actually did I really did enjoy this set like I said earlier if you do get a chance to catch ghost and Adrian Young's band Venice Dawn on tour the there's 12 reasons to die album then absolutely no question do it cool cool Anthony Fantana Ghostface Killah Venice dawn 12 reasons to die forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd guy and it's time for Vampire Weekend now fires of the city Vampire Weekend is a New York indie pop and rock outfit who annoyed me on their first album captivated me with their second and has had me patiently awaiting the release of their third this now for better or for worse Vampire Weekend has easily been one of the most standout groups in indie pop over the past handful of years the band's fun pop hooks are seamlessly blended with classical music style Arrangements colorful production and instrumentation with a lot of personality and texture the band also has the capability to play tracks that are incredibly fast loud sort of noisy but still very fun and playful and occasionally they'll drop a bit of musical elements from sky muzac or reggae and singer-songwriter Paul Simon influences coming from his solo stuff has shown up stronger and stronger and stronger as the band has released more material and most of these elements show up once again to create a pretty worthwhile sequel to the band's last full-length LP contra and I say most of these elements because the band does change up their recipe a little bit on this new LP Vampire Weekend subtracts the world music element out of their music in a really big way on this release none of the tracks on this album really come through as being influenced by anything more than Western popular contemporary and classical music which is kind of strange because sounds coming from ska and reggae most notoriously have helped the band to find their sound since day one but it would seem on this new full-length LP the group is really trying to get their songwriting to stand on its own two feet and not be enjoyed relative to how many steel drums or thumb pianos manage to show up on a given track and for the most part Vampire Weekend does bring lyrics and Mel that are up to the challenge of this change with refined instrumentation with a very strong classical music vibe to it the band will occasionally throw out tracks that are adorned in strings or very beautiful chorus vocals I mean gargantuan chorus vocals which show up most notoriously on tracks like yeah hey or on the track Hudson one of the closing tracks on this LP that actually on top of the course feels as if it's backed up orchestral II the production and effects are just as dynamic on this LP as they were on contra and the lyrics are romantically poetically passionately descriptive on subjects such as life love and a really big topic for this new LP religion God it would seem almost as if this subject matter comes up on most of the tracks on this album in ways that are subtle and not so much like the track obvious style that kicks this album off which through its melody and it's chord progression has a huge gospel vibe the track features a somewhat borrowed melody but the band is able to keep things interesting musically by evolving the instrumentation as the song plods along bringing in more and more electronically tinged sounds but still managing to keep the track feeling very delicate refined and beautiful it's like a sunshiny morning day morning the track unbelievers also has a very strong religious tone to it with Ezra throwing elements in his lyrics that reference unbelievers sinners fate and being bored again the instrumentation has a really fast peppy pace to it that really really reminds me of moments from Paul Simon's Graceland same with the track worship you which has a very steady gallop to it and even though the song does add an incredibly catchy chorus this track really really caught my attention when Ezra threw the lyric out there that will die unbelievers bound to the tracks of the Train and one more note on this LP in relation to religion the song yah-hey has to be mentioned it's one of the longer tracks on this LP and obviously the chorus on this album could sort of be a plan words for the word Yahweh and lyrically the song seems to be somewhat of a calm conversation directly with God sort of displaying this loss of faith with certain groups of people on this track much like on the song unbelievers Azra paints this difficult picture with religion this difficult personal relationship this desire to believe or this passion for the will to believe but there's something sort of holding him back or at least the person he's singing from the standpoint of a relationship that I think most people with a modern mentality have with religion due to things like modern science and contradictions and holy texts or just long unanswered philosophical questions though I'm sure many out there with an internet connection can easily point out the faults of religion still it doesn't make this song feel any sort of less heartbreaking for me especially since Ezra's performance on this track seems so sincere however if there is a downside to this track it is the annoyingly chipmunk vocals which pop up all over the already strange and slightly obnoxious chorus on this track in a way it kind of reminds me of the track California English from the band's last full-length LP which a lot like yeah hey was overall pretty good tune a tune I really want to like but then the band incorporates this really sort of obnoxious element into it kind of ruining it for me as much as I love Vampire Weekend because of their boyish vocals their ability to woo me with their lyrics and their beautiful melodies they're playful light-hearted yet methodical instrumentation the band occasionally breaks this love streak by putting out a track that I just can't stand not that the band should take my personal taste into account when writing music but there are tracks on the cell P like finger back which in my opinion is from front to back annoying it's the constant staccato instrumentation that never really seems to relax until the band reaches a bridge which isn't even that interesting to me and the melody that is being played with the staccato instrumentation and edge we're singing on top of it essentially results in no the docs go found love but fluffa Shep and she averted a gaze the melody is so freakin jumpy I kind of want to just try my best to grab at it except it's so repetitive throughout nearly the entire track I just lose interest the song worship you also sort of loses my interest as well by being just a little too hmm the verses on this song are so speedy that Ezra's words all sort of blend together in this really unrewarding way you know a vast majority of the songs on this LP are enjoyable like the very eerie moonlit and epic track Hudson toward the end of this LP the song is fantastic it's like a battle epilogue it's it's really just a big finish for this album outside of these sort of short shrug like semi instrumental tracks like step and Diane young I have sung their praises in the past I still enjoy these tracks quite a bit but I still can't help but feel like to an extent around the halfway point of this album the album sort of loses steam and gets kind of spotty first off you have the song everlasting arms which in comparison with many of the tracks on this album the annoying ones and the good ones just kind of feels like wallpaper doesn't really stick out in any significant way and then following this you have in my opinion the three most annoying tracks on the LP back to back to back still the the first half of this LP is is great it's incredibly solid it just seems almost as if on the second half of this album they didn't really want to copy themselves whether it be their past material or just the earlier material on this LP so they started to wildly experiment which I guess is okay in a sense because it did bring this album variety but then all of a sudden it drops off completely emotionally with the very downtrodden and subtle quiet Hudson which does finish epically but it feels as if there's a complete stop in terms of flow on the album at this point and the band just completely changes gears and then puts out a really short track to kind of close the album out in my opinion definitely not as much cohesion track for track as an album like contra I'm feeling a light too decent seven on this thing if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and washing machine hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music bird and it's time for a review of the new cola album moody cute Cola is the musical project of electronic tinkerer and extreme sampler Michael this is his new full-length under this name with which he has released other following albums which not too much unlike this one our electronic sample based and have a sort of neo psychedelic tone to them I would actually say an earlier releases like dial tone Earth there was a really clear Animal Collective influence in how some of the samples were executed there were even some really strong dub reggae vibes which continued very strongly on his next full-length daydream repeater that dropped in late 2011 moody coupe though if you're familiar with colas earlier stuff still very much feels like a Cola release mostly because of these Spacey's synths and the way that vocal samples and just samples in general are chopped on this thing but surely this album comes off as being much more abstract and complex on this thing Cola grabs samples from across the conceptual plain everything from scissors cutting to drink sipping spans of music pieces of percussion weird unidentifiable noises breaths a lot of familiar sounds that are executed in such a strange way that I feel like I've just transported into this completely different world where nothing makes sense it's like an electronically generated Dali painting or something my records behind me are melting and kouchuu chest is playing them a lot of CO solo on a dog it is difficult to make sense ibisworld acting the rhythms throughout this album are incredibly cheery and and strange very oddly shaped and the samples are twisted pitch shifted manipulated in a myriad of different ways the synthesizers feel as if they're playing sequences that were programmed on some computer from the late 90s early 2000s they kind of have a tone to them that feel as if they were borrowed from like a self-help video or something it's kind of vaporwave if you ask me there's definitely an element of plunder phonics on this album I'll OneNote Rick's point never or Matt mos there's some glitchy music sampling abstractions on this thing too that remind me of Early Girl Talk and many of the samples on this record are pasted out in a way that feels as if they're spelling out some kind of experimental techno structure that I can't quite make sense of even though there are artists in sample-based music that I can't point to in reference to this album this LP feels more like a personal exploration of sound and music as opposed to some kind of ode to anyone influenced even though this album can be very disorienting at first because of its sounds once I listen to it again and again and again I really kind of got a feel what each track was going for stylistically and emotionally and it just wasn't this very confusing jumble for example the opening track on this thing sukiyaki to die for which in a way really has a strong jazz fusion vibe to it with its constant ride cymbals the piano and since on this thing too but of course the samples in just the the very Spacey production the reverb production makes it feel pretty futuristic and sort of Cosmo grama Flying Lotus esque it's a pretty intricate track that I dig a lot and the song deaf Christian is is another favorite of mine from this LP the track has a really busy beat and it feels as if it's sampling these Motown era vocals the words that are being sung and the melodies really ring true from this era of music but the way that this song builds especially with the hi-hats on this thing it feels as if it's also borrowing from trap music to the track is really an incredible and creative set of influences samples and edits and there's a hard groove on this track too even though many of the sounds on this album may seem strange with how they're placed and where they're coming from Cola is typically not mysterious when it comes to grooves the grooves that these beats rock are really the most straightforward thing about this album in my opinion if there is a major downside that some listeners may find on this LP though it's that the constant and strange samples being repeated over and over and over on many of these tracks can be a little overbearing and the sounds that Cola assembles on some of these tracks most notably on a track like melters Delight it's not like all the sounds in my opinion really come together into something that feels cohesive with all the synth arpeggios on the song really clashing more than they come together really makes this song more of a mess than a triumph I can see that the hi-hat really references kind of a techno thing on this song but kholat definitely makes it experimental by omitting the constant kick drum but I still feel like this track and many others on here don't go on for as long as they possibly could maybe string these ideas out a little bit make some space and build up to the most intense and really kick off in this part instead songs like melters delight really make a ruckus and and bow out pretty quickly I pretty much feel the same way about the track redeemable features songs like unfor example really take their time going somewhere set a very patient pace I love the woodwinds sense on this track which are matched up with other synth tones as well which are equally lush that combined with some of the weird clicks and hi-hats and the beat on this thing this song is much more palatable the song suspicious kind of has that dub reggae feel creeping back into colas music it has these guitar samples that really it skips across the ocean like rocks and on top of it the song takes these chill though khals and sax samples that are warped in this very strange way that's sort of unsettling and sour this album to me is really more of an experimental mind game and while it is really intriguing it is very playful that can't be denied either to listen to these songs over and over and over again the novelty of just how weird and out there they are wears off moderately quick and the fact they don't have a really strong structure to them it does make this album lose its flavor a little bit though still it is it is very admirable and likeable to kind of pop on an album that is you know sort of throwing all these unexpected things at me a little bit I'm feeling uh pretty much like a decent two strong six on this thing if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it kolja moody coupe breath you

hi everyone Anthony Pham tan oh here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Charli XCX album true romance Charli XCX is in English pop music singer who has been gathering quite a bit of buzz over the past few years over a bunch of pretty hot singles songs like stay away which in my opinion is attractive is incredibly well written really melodic and has a very modern synthetic feel to it but with a bit of a tease New Wave chic or the song you which a lot of people remember for its very interesting use of a gold panda sample tracks like these that featured really interesting and sort of progressive production really forecasted Charlie to be an artist who is going to be a little bit more eclectic than your average modern pop singer however I don't really feel like that ended up being the case even though there are a handful of decent songs on this album and some likeable instrumentals I think this album is sort of a case of taking something smearing it in some extra makeup wrapping it in some edgy clothing and then selling it as being sort of original or different I gotta say track after track on this LP Charli XCX has a very very passable voice and not that she doesn't have pitch or range really my issue with a lot of these tracks is a lack of interesting emotion coming from these vocals despite a lot of the emotional and sort of romantic themes that come out of the lyrics on this album Charlie's voice doesn't really come off as all that moving to my ears it almost gets borderline ridiculous as she embarks upon many many very slowly wrapped verses and what makes these parts so ridiculous are some of the silly just sort of cliche lyrics while I have nothing against this album's blend of house pop music just dance pop in general as well as synth pop I just feel like Charli XCX doesn't bring that much flair or personality on this record though an album like this a very short sort of concise very bright electronic pop record can be great sometimes sort of a breath of fresh air a break from some of the more serious music out there I just don't really have a lot of faith in this album to navigate its way through the modern pop landscape when it doesn't really make an effort to define itself within that instead there are too many moments on this album where it embraces some of contemporary pops worst characteristics like the song nuclear seasons that opens the cell P up while I do like the start of the track Charlie's voice is just really ethereal off in the distance it has this really Airy production that sort of reminds me of Grimes a bit once the song moves past its intro and the course is pretty decent on this thing too the verses are absolutely boring don't feature any interesting vocals or melodies whatsoever and the reason that is is because this track like many on the radio today brings pretty much Moaning that is supposed to be sold as singing and the melody on this part seems really half-baked I just find so many pop songs today where it's like the verse is completely neglected in favor of just having an incredibly explosive course which you know is said because Charlie seems like a capable singer I don't know why they would want to throw out a verse like this as opposed to something that was a little more well crafted to be completely honest there isn't a single song on this album that captivates me until the fourth and fifth tracks on here stay away and set me free these tracks to me have solid melodic writing for beginning to end explosive choruses sweet verses production that actually rings through as being very punchy and clear the instrumentation seems like it's oriented in a really clean interesting way whereas tracks like take my hand instead just feel like a jumbled mess where Charlie and her producers are trying to make as much synthetic noise as possible to make it seem like something interesting is happening when maybe it's really not the case the songs stay away really nice solid breakup song a track about not wanting to be around someone because they sort of bring those old emotions back up in you again it's torture to see them again and the track feel my pain sort of a lust song not exactly new and refreshing angles in pop music but still the singing goes overwhelm the production feels really synthetic futuristic and slightly dark unfortunately the album doesn't continue on this great songwriting streak that it sets up with these two tracks the grins the really terrible off-pitch background singing and rap verses on this track make the song nearly unbearable to me and what's even worse is the track cloud aura which features the rapper Brooke candy it's one of the few tracks on this album where the writing credits are just sort of written to Charlie and her feature spot on the song and it really sounds like it with an incredibly monotonous lead melody that seems to drone on and on and on until Brooke and Charlie just trade really annoying and underwhelming rap verses and moments on this album we're like I hear Brooke candy rapping about life in the trap and Charlie referring to getting sexy and addressed with a love interest as gangsta there are just some points when I want to ignore the lyrics just so I don't have a stronger negative reaction to this album we on some husband-and-wife but I don't care because I know I really like it they're really moments on this album where these rap verses give me a nervous tic that is so intense that I'm just begging for more parts with tacky auto-tune overall with true romance there are a few very good singles on this LP I will give it that but many other tracks on this thing feel too much like I'm listening to Rebecca Black go through her goth phase when I don't get that vibe unfortunately so many of the terrible rap verses and just trashy auto-tune get in the way of what really could be a good pop song there are moments where I really do feel like this album is lyrically shallow like when Charlie is moaning over and over and over how can I fix what I up not exactly poetry but there are some moments on this album where Charlie does come off authentic because of these sort of conversational words that she works into her verses I don't doubt that Charlie feels sincerely about some of the things that she sings raps and and says on this album but very rarely do melody production lyrics and structure actually come together into a great tune on this album really I'm feeling a strong 3 to a light for on this thing if you've given it a listen what did you whoa hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for you review of the new included album hokey fright the included is the collaborative musical artistic duo of have more in common than it would actually seem to be just by looking at the genres that people typically throw them in for one they're obviously friends - over the years both of them have shown that they have incredibly potent dark sides although kima's does tend to get a little more personal three both of them in their songs can be incredibly playful when it comes to writing lyrics both of them are incredibly worthy and verbose what's not is this enough to forge some kind of significant artistic relationship they seem to think so this thing has sixteen tracks worth of artistic relationship on it and it's not like this thing is their first real collaboration either as I mentioned in a previous video Aesop Rock showed up on a number of tracks from Kimmie Dawson's last full-length LP thunder thighs and Kimmy did make a one track appearance on Aesop's new album skeleton like thunder thighs on this new LP there are moments where it seems like Kimia is playing her guitar and singing into a recorder making a somewhat lo-fi recording while Aesop spits over her guitars when she doesn't seem to be saying however that's not the only angle that the uncle'd it takes on this LP at times this loaf i recording is backed up with drum machines or it would seem that nearly everything that kemiya and Aesop pulled together on a track is drummed up in a professional studio through and through this album really seems to explore every possible way that this collaboration could have worked expanding a little further into kimiya style sometimes a little further an esop sometimes and as it could be assumed there are some parts on this LP that sort of crash and burn a little bit or where Kimia and Aesop really get maybe sort of too indulgent like on the song why do you hang up on me which is this weird beat collage with interruptions from either Kimia or s after saying why'd you hang up on me which is sort of funny though and I will leave it to you to decide whether or not thirty-eight seconds of Aesop and Kim naming different kinds of sandwiches is a fulfilling part of the album and there are some tracks on here that to me are sort of ruined by a bit of a technical issue tracks like delicate cycle or Scissorhands or earthquake were the vocals with Kimia singing and Aesop rapping right over her singing it sounds like a complete mess the vocals clash in a really ugly way as if they were mixed at the same volume and they're competing to be heard it's like you have to foreground vocals instead of a foreground vocal and a background vocal sometimes the vocals on these tracks don't even seem to sync up completely which makes it even more difficult to decipher them I see Aesop sort of conforming to Kimia style a little bit on these tracks but this could have been done better it just seems like a weird issue not to take head-on especially since not every single song on this album suffers from this problem like the song zombie cafe which sounds completely clean and and fine as well as the track the aquarium actually a lot of songs on this album go over well really well to the point where I think this is some of Kimia and Aesop's best stuff if there's one thing that makes this album aw inspiring at its best it's that Kimia and ASAP really love to go into songs with concepts and it seems that coming together only enhances that side of their artistic psyches like the song TV on 10 which essentially feels like Kim collaborating on an esop song where he throws out these riveting verses about this plane crash and losing someone in a plane crash and hearing about it on TV and hoping that the plane you're hearing about doesn't have the person you love on it the song has really murky moody beat and the more I listen to it just the more chilling it is in the song organs which sort of continues the morbid theme of this album feels like Aesop sort of rapping over a Kimia song and this track is like a hilarious PSA for donating your organs after you've passed on the song captures the philosophy of the sentiment perfectly it's really the best musical PSA of 2013 hands down Aesop's really wordy verses on this track are fantastic and I love the verse when kami comes through talking about animals passing different parts on to other animals they may thrive like when the whale gives its tail to the cat or the bird gives its wings to the bat it's ridiculous and the song bats which is the longest track on this entire LP Kimia and ASAP come together and mourn the death of Minnesota rapper idea they do it with some really really awesome just inspiring wordplay with Kimya talking about him saying he's the Minnesota Dalai Lama Kimmy and Aesop go on to sort of mourn his passing by watching bats fly and with the Lofa sounds the warm bass the guitars the choppy beat on this thing is fantastic meld of both of these artist styles and the song alligator is a really dark and strange look at sex lust and specifically pornography with a really heavy verse from Aesop talking about how when one gets into porn or is first exposed to porn there was sort of a changing point there there's a certain experience there that changes your mind makes you look at things completely differently I love how Aesop can really get down to cameos level and do something incredibly tender on a song like teleprompter and there are moments where they come together for tracks where it totally feels like they're goofing off on some abstract ideas like eyeball soup or the last track on this thing tits up which does get a little just overly long and kind together so well on this project I'm feeling a decent strong seven on this thing if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should
