baby boo-boo hi everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Phoenix LP bankrupt Phoenix is a French pop and rock outfit who has been around a lot longer than some people assume mostly due to their very recent spike in popularity with their fourth full-length album Wolfgang Amadeus Phoenix in 2009 an album that made the band a bit of an overnight sensation going gold in America Canada as well as Australia which is absolutely no surprise whatsoever considering how many sharp-ass singles are on this LP 1901 Armistice Lisztomania and lasso this album was filled with catchy sweet quirky memorable guitars really bouncy synthesizers some very agreeable vocals and overall just a really poppy sound I did like quite a few tracks on Wolfgang Amadeus Fenix but I've never really been a big Phoenix fan to be completely honest the band's sound to me has always reflected sort of a loss in personality within the genres of indie pop and indie rock over the years but it's not like there's any reason to hold negative feelings toward the band and it's not like the band came out with this fourth album changed their sound and sold out the band's music has always been really sort of sweet and hook heavy it's just like Phoenix had the right idea the whole time and had foresight and I commend them for doing that and also making music that they want to make still I have to kind of raise an eyebrow when it comes to people who were big fans of maybe the band's past few LPS and are giving a listen to this new LP and are a little disappointed with bankrupts lack of surprises I wonder when his Phoenix ever really been about surprises at all their discography they're a musical trajectory has been over the course of their career incredibly safe about as safe as taking a swim in a puddle with a snorkel and water wings as far as indie rock and pop go Phoenix's music has incredibly standard there's not an angle that you can look at it in which it does look standard you can't even call the band obnoxious or overly romantic in the way that you would Vampire Weekend or over loan in the way that you would say Arcade Fire is sometimes or even too sweet and saccharine in the way that man Kim or even Passion Pit can be the band's vocals consistently just don't really stick out to me with any sort of flair if anything they remind me of like of Montreal's Kevin Barnes if he had never had his heart broken or if he had never heard a David Bowie record all these issues aside Phoenix does bring a notable change on this new album and that change is an increase in synthesizers and electronics guitar still has a real presence on these tracks but these synthesizers they're really turned up to make the overall feel of this record thicker and bright a drum machine occasionally pops up on this album and there are a lot of grooves whether it be in the hook or the verses on these pop tunes that feel like they're ripped straight from old 80s new wave b-sides who we couldn't even find on Google if we could remember their names the band's approach on this LP is far from original these guys are not the first to rock grooves like this they won't be the last but still sharp songwriting does stick out like the song entertainment opening this LP up really driving groove on this LP and it starts out with this killer burning synth melody B nee nee nee nee nee nee nee nee nee nee nee nee me me me the vocals come off pretty emotive on the verse with a nice down stroke guitar in there it's really good tune and the song trying to be cool the song has a sticky melody and this groove that feels like it's a bridge between funk disco and 80s new wave the song is so good I totally suggest it as this album's next single because it's definitely more entertaining than this albums other single chloroformed which has all these dinky drum machines that just don't do anything for the track are very redundant and almost pointless cyntha melody that copies exactly what the vocals do and this weak gutless piano phrase that feels like it's just a direct copy of the pianos from Elton John's Bennie in the Jets it's a really lackluster tune in my opinion and one of a good handful of moments on this album where the band is really mucking up their sound mucking up these tunes with just too many elements to the point where the songs just really lose their pop their snap they're instantaneousness in translation like the song SOS and bel-air which not only hits the listener with many pieces within a short span of time but all of these pieces are layered so heavily with numerous ideas flying around into this jumbled whirlwind there are some sweet melodies that are in this tune and others on here but they feel that they're canceled out by a hundred other ideas competing with them like on the song Drakkar Noir or the very drum machine driven tune don't or the track oblique City these Tunes are a little more clear than the track SOS and bel-air but still not many songs on this album come off as meticulously crafted as tunes on Wolfgang Amadeus Phoenix as almost as if the band had the approach of just sort of throwing everything at the wall and just sort of seeing what sticks there are some other songs on here though that are interesting take me by surprise like the song bourgeois which is very 80s 80s esque slow jams very easygoing it's got a sweet melody sensual vocals on the track it's a killer and the title track surprisingly enough is is nearly a seven-minute synth Odyssey with a vocal part on the back end which is actually incredibly entertaining the band did a great job of crafting some sounds on this thing overall I have to say this album wasn't terrible but it wasn't great either it's really sort of middle of the road for me mostly because of how spotty it is there's some sharp songs on here backed up against some very jumbled songs as well a lot of tracks here pretty much for the whole album the band is rocking this just nearly dead deathbed 80 chic revivalism that they don't exactly make feel fresh and even though I did like some of the tunes on here I still can't help but feel that when I listen to a Phoenix tune there is something there whether it be the vocals the way the band plays are instruments there's just some sort of lack of character there to be completely honest I'm feeling a decent strong five on this thing if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana Phoenix forever [Music] you you

York jazz noise improvisational avant-garde music outfit little women and all these genres combined together with some very intricate math rock grooves made this band's debut LP in 2010 really dense difficult to make heads or tails of but still some real moments of beauty and some great plains shine through these very tough moments and made this album one of my favorite LPS in 2010 I was absolutely psyched to see the band returned with a new full-length a new piece if you will and instead of parsing it out into different tracks like they did on their last full-length they have presented listeners with 142 minute long track on this new album the recording on this new LP feels roughly the same as the last one more of an emphasis on technique and playing than trippy or distorted effects it feels very intimate freewheeling kind of in the moment really letting the rawness of the guitar the tenor and also saxophones and the drums speak for themselves this new LP just like the band's last full-length is a multi-faceted piece for sure but I guess the question is do the pieces on this new LP also come together into something that is thrilling moving exciting as well the LP throat was never the most avant-garde thing on the block it was never meant to be artists like John Zorn I feel like push weirdness much further to me the album throat was kind of a balance between composition and chaos and for sure lung also tries to find its own combination of those two characteristics as well this LP kicks things off with an intro that features very light drums sparse guitar serene harmonized saxophone phrasing it's seven minutes or so of just rock jazz bliss but then all of a sudden these stringy lanky weird mutated guitar chords come crashing down with drums and everything in terms of just goes right away the music all of a sudden becomes very and very cruel to the listener with just it's it's oddness then after this comes these long spans of chords and melodies intervals that it seems like the saxophones dance around in this very tribal primal way with how they move with one another and interact with one another it's almost as if they come closer together in terms of harmony and and drift apart as the band trips through these pieces meanwhile guitars and drums are just providing very light quiet backdrops and the only thing separating these different parts from one another are the occasional jazz freakout that lasts for a very short amount of time and just comes in and jars me for a few moments it's a sort of cruel joke that the van punches at the listener with these very loud moments like a merciless bully and then right afterwards the saxophones return to dancing around some musical phrases very quietly again but each time going for a sort of different musical vibe sometimes sounding very soft pretty calming others dissonant and then again fiery this goes on until about the halfway point of the album where the band really introduces the mother of all freak-outs on this entire LP which is one of the most jaw-dropping ly intense moments on this album to jar the listener feels like it might have been the intention and to go back to this album and listen to it again and again these jarring moments become so much less surprising or moving because it's kind of like you know you know when the Sharps got to jump out of the water though the quiet parts may feel very pretty it's not like they build or evolve in anything that that really sort of touches me an emotional way the stringy jagged guitars that occur earlier in the album end up showing up later as well bringing somewhat of a theme to this album some consistency I'm hearing pieces again there is kind of a circular quality to this composition the band is pulled together and maybe people will gravitate toward that more than some of the stuff that the band put on their full-length debut which can kind of feel like this disjointed linear musical experience even though I like that the band trying to build this piece of the more consistent structure I'm not really all that enamored with the pieces that this structure is built out of it seems like many of these louder more abrasive moments that come on very suddenly all function on the same techniques and ideas coming from each player really the only interesting moment that came out of these abrasive spots on the album was the final Ascension of the album which really really hits a high mark in terms of just volume and intensity ear piercing howls coming from the Sachs's stuttering guitars and very busy drums all over the place it's like this album is trying to oppositely mirror the very friendly beginning that this LP started off with honestly this sophomore full-length didn't really take me on the emotional ride that the debut did while I'm still into the production I think the playing is pretty solid and that the way the band likes to create just a very intimate recording around their stuff I just think they put a little bit too much of an emphasis on putting parts in this album that would grab the listener and shake them violently and then just sort of put them back down in their place and you know pet them a little bit and then grab the gun meanwhile in the midst of these moments where they're not being shaken things are just you know feeling alright very few spots on this album filled me with wonder especially from a melodic perspective I for the most part really just stayed intrigued and that's about it I'm kind of feeling a light too decent six on this thing if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and yeah Anthony Fantana little women forever

hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for you review the new altar of plagues LPT 'the glory and injury altar of plagues is an Ireland based atmospheric black metal outfit who began around the mid 2000s and if you listen to this bands music their two previous LPS or some of their early EPS you can catch influences from not only black metal but shoegaze as well as post rock and they hammer a lot of these tracks out with typical black metal sounds and instrumentation tremolo guitars harsh distortion blasts beat drumming retched vocals and the winding passages very long song lengths in their albums hint toward a lot of ambition especially on their last full length album mammal which did have some really epic and beautiful moments on it but rarely from beginning to end with an altar of plagues album did I feel like the writing was eventful enough or unique enough to justify the very long lengths that this band stretches their tunes out to certainly the band would add details like some chanting or some female vocals their writing and the variety across their albums is is definitely a bit meteor when compared to a band like ash borer but I was really caught off-guard when I was hearing some tracks initially coming out from this album tracks like god alone a track that is incredibly straightforward very riff oriented amazing vocals on the track that are just chilling I'm positive after listening to this album a lot of people are still going to file this record under the atmospheric black metal genre label but the band's compositions on this new LP are much less drawn out the longest track on this LP is 8 minutes with many of the other songs on here landing in about the four-minute range and this time around the production is much less cavernous as well with the drums the vocals and the riffs being right up front and much more substantial on this record they really have brought fire urgency and detail that I feel the band's other stuff might have been kind of lacking for sure teeth glory is a step a big step toward the engaging angular jagged riffs strings faint electronics really strange synthesizers intense vocals shouts howls and dissonant strange guitars that feel like they have more in common with noise rock than they do black metal these are just a handful of the elements that the band uses to really sort of tear out everything that you once knew about altar of plagues and really remodel their sound and style from top to bottom because they've really turned it into something that is not only sort of unpredictable and challenging on this record but very brutish very rarely does the band throw a sort of expansive black metal scape out there that you can sort of get lost in or really admire the haze and kind of you know sit back no this is much more fierce and groove oriented and the grooves and occasionally melodies on this LP are grooves and melodies that are usually rocked in black metal music like the song 12 was ruined where the beat as well as the guitars have a really strong middle-eastern flair to them it's almost something I would see like the band Grails playing on one of their albums the song god alone is a track that is played in three four with a huge emphasis with dissonant guitars on the one and two beat and the song Bert year almost has this one two one two strange dance music like feel to it with this looped polyrhythm it feels like some kind of noise or percussion loop going on in the background just adding another element to the rhythm and to make the track even more of a standout this song may just have the most intense and just huh fear inducing vocals on this entire record I mean they really sound freakish and that's another thing I really admire about this album before I go on about any other tracks the vocals do have some real personality occasionally they toy a bit with those typical black metal matches but some of the lyrics are very audible on this LP and everything from the more guttural growls to the ear piercing shrieks make many of the songs on here just stick in the back of my head furthermore with the song burnt year the song progresses into some black metal drum blasts that are backed up with shots of noise eventually the song melts into these droning somewhat ambient tones surprise surprise surprise and then the band finishes things off with a really epic and somewhat noisy ascent it's a thrill ride and it's an incredibly grim thrill ride it's like a funeral march through a river of blood that is pouring into some kind of gargantuan demon's mouth quenching his blood thirst anyway this thing is loaded with riffs and grooves of different shapes and sizes really adding variety across the nine tracks on this album and what medium these grooves sort of come in whether it be guitar or drums or some kind of electronic loop which is the band surprise of choice right in the middle of the very vast and slow track a remedy and a fear and this surprise loop eventually guides the song into some really heavy heavy guitars and mind you that these heavy guitar passages sit in between a very quiet moment with chilled out harmonious chorus vocals that that almost sound cultish and how they're delivering their there stone-faced singing and after all this comes distorted dissonant over modulated guitars and electronics that just overwhelm the senses altar of plagues is taking some serious risks stepping outside of their black metal comfort zone and writing some really exciting songs in the process the song quickly segues into the next track with a quick drone and that's another thing I like about this LP so many of the tracks segue into one another whether it be very logically with the same tone or the ending of one song really going to the beginning or maybe just sort of a quick rush to sort of overlap the two elements of the album and this really makes teeth glory very holistic listening experience for sure that was also the case with altar of plagues other releases but as I've already said I'm a little crazier for the material at their writing this album especially since one four-minute track on this album may contain a handful of different ideas that are pieced together in a really interesting way for the most part the production the recording on this thing is pretty straightforward it kind of gets the job done which isn't necessarily a bad thing because it just presents the instrumentation and the band's great playing and fantastic writing and surprise song structures on this thing make that a delight but there are some weird recording and mixing choices on this album for sure the loops and some of the electronics the band chooses to use on many of these tracks don't exactly meld with the instrumentation in a very natural way from time to time songs may make a huge jump in volume from one moment to another there may be a riff that jumps out feeling as if it is 2 times louder than anything else in the mix on a certain track considering the unorthodox past that black metal has had in terms of recording and mixing I actually thought a lot of these strange quirks brought the album more character rather than kind of ruin my experience with it despite the saturation of ideas and sounds that are thrown at the listener the flow and the evolution of this album is really sort of clear and impressive the album is just like a mess of different ideas but they're stitched together into this evil quilt of evil and it just feels like there are a lot of stylistic inspirational points for this album everything from metal to maybe a little bit of noise music post-rock experimental rock electronic music a little bit of industrial music - it's amazing that all these influences come together in a way where it's very obvious where it's all coming from and yet it's so uniform in its mood and its sound the album is so tortured it's so head splitting it is so pained the only variation from this mood is really the last track of the album which features a pretty heavy post-rock like ascension that brings things in a pretty triumphant territory I'm really impressed with this LP I thought it was great one of the better metal experiences I've had this year if you've given to listen what did you think of it I'm pretty much feeling as strongly to a light 9 on this thing what should I review next and yeah that's it altar of plagues teefed glory and injury forever [Music]

chance the rapper acid rap hi everyone Anthony Fantana here intranets busiest music nerd and it's time for you review the new chance the rapper mixtape acid rap chance the rapper is a Chicago rapper and singer and this is his follow-up project to the 10-day mixtape that dropped last year which you could definitely say is kind of overlooked considering just how much speed hype popularity that chance is gaining off this new project and if you compare acid rap to 10-day you can definitely see an uptick in quality or at least memorability because there are less moments on 10-day that seem to feature that very quirky nutty over-the-top personality that people seem to be celebrating on this new project plus the production on this new project is flashy er the recording quality is better too now as far as the personality that chance brings on this mixtape it seems to be much of what his focus lies in chance is personality his voice that he delivers his raps and his singing with is done in this sort of high mid pitch register and there's a sharp rasp in a lot of his vocals too and he comes off incredibly energetic for somebody whose head seems to be very riddled with drugs acid xanax weed and alcohol seem to be major players and a lot of chances lyrics with Molly and wax as well as many other things kind of hopping into play cameo roles in fact the song push a man kind of paints this drug-dealer image of him in the hook of the song anyway with very smooth jazzy production and the song is peppered with his nananana yeah ad-lib that he likes to throw around everywhere when rapping chance paces his words out in this Rastafari style flow and the hook on this track is sort of backed up with some chopped and screwed vocals it's a killer hook there's actually a bit of space as soon as this first portion of the song finishes and then it leads into a sec portion and I mean it's a big gap of literally silence which according to Twitter chants says that if you're on acid while listening to this project don't skip it because it takes away all the feeling but while listening to this I was pretty sober so I'm not sure if I should skip it or sit through it either way the track breaks into this very Spacey lush synth heavy beat that feels very nocturnal and has a huge good kid maad city kind of vibe to it and when chance finally pops into the track his flow gives off the same feel and on this latter portion of the track which is very quiet very subtle chance paints himself as this guy with a blunt on his lips he's got his 9 on his hip and it's got the shit's at this point the song chance comes off very druggie very violent but then he sort of turns around and wonders why the media doesn't really cover the extreme gang violence that goes on in Chicago it feels like to me that chance has a love-hate relationship with where he comes from and violence as well while he sees Chicago as a place that has personality and has built him as a person he hates the violence that goes on there and while he does seem to fear it in a very serious and real way he does use it occasionally to sort of further his persona maybe just sort of throwing some tough talk out there in order to counteract some of the more vulnerable and personal moments that are spread throughout this tape musically he even celebrates Chicago a little bit with some Juke influence on the beats from the opening track and the closing track on here too which I loved still on this track and maybe a few other moments on this tape chance is taking some really important social issues in his lyrics setting them up against a great instrumental but the urgency of these issues to me doesn't really come through all the time chance may have some strong personal feelings about some of the stuff he brings up but he doesn't come off to me as like a serious voice on some of these topics usually when he tries to take on a tangle the difficult issue like drug addiction or violence or one's relation with God it comes off very surface and just barely scratched I feel like I'm just left with some messages and some images sometimes that thickly glazed over with a layer of inebriation there are moments on acid rap though where chances very personal relationship with drugs does seem to help them out and lead to some real song inspiration like on the track cocoa butter kisses not only is the instrumental killer on this thing really smooth great organs on this track fantastic melody very memorable really tasteful hook soulful singing coming from chance and I love the sentiment of this track basically talking about how when you smoke a lot whether it be cigarettes whether it be pot you have your life especially your relationships with people who aren't in on that part of your life kind of change because the smell is there people who you have a relationship might have strong feelings against you smoking it's a part of smoking that is is really real but it's an element of this life that isn't really explored through song all too often because there's nothing glorious about it it's kind of awkward and chance does a great job of capturing this awkwardness on a track with a guest verse from Twista that is absolutely awesome as acid rap continues chance comes through and exposes his more tender side which I'm sure a lot of you saw coming he delivers a pretty interesting love song with the track lost which makes the idea of dropping acid with someone sound really romantic the track has a beautiful piano led production awesome jazzy flute and guitar on this thing lyrically chants delves a little bit into the specifics of the relationship that he has with this girl and though the track does have a really sweet sentiment to it there is a bit of speculation left in the verse drop by no-name gypsy which is a great verse where we are left off with the line where she says the only time he really loves her is naked in her dream sort of illustrating some kind of disconnect between the two of them when maybe they're not high the album gets even better on the next two tracks with the track everybody something which is a really fantastic sentiment on this album just talking about everybody is somebody's everything that's essentially the message of the song it's talking about relationships whether they be family or romantic and though chances Ryan's come off angry sometimes on this track he goes on to say that he is who he is because someone loved to help him beat his demons and basically get him through harder times there's a funny spot toward the end of the track where he goes on and on about how he talks white or just sort of has this white inflection to the way that he converses in everyday life and sort of an underlying subtlety to this point in the track is that he uses a flow that feels completely ripped from Eminem's Slim Shady LP Chan's had some great wordplay toward the back end of this track and the way he sings on the song is just another reminder that he has a very strange voice but can definitely sing I love the song that's love I feel like it's a great middle point on this album another passion is spot on here but for me the LP really loses steam after this moment acid rap continues with three pretty major features from childish gambino action bronson and absol on the next three tracks but i really feel like these songs are some of the most lackluster on the album and it really has nothing to do with the features whatsoever i feel like on these particular tracks the production is the weakest a lot of chances hooks on these songs are the most forgettable and half-assed and I don't really feel like there's a strong message or sentiment to any of the tracks either they just feel like really breezy moments the track favorite song is really poppy it has a sweet instrumental but the moment were chance flies in with thee that's my jam that's my damn but that's gonna that's gonna do it just feels like he's not even trying the song Yan yak comes through with that Rastafari flow again I like the heavy bass line on this track and action bronson delivers a fantastically just over-the-top and funny verse on this song but chance essentially makes a hook out of his somewhat obnoxious ad-lib that I feel like keep peppers way too hard on the album anyway and smoke again maybe this track is my least favorite of the three the beat to me doesn't really feel like anything but a trap beat with the hi-hat stripped out of it chances lyrics don't really hit me in in any way whatsoever no surprises nothing really all that interesting and absol on this track may have dropped one of his most lackluster guest verses that I've ever Hurd especially with the line where he says no doubt like Gwen Stefani's group let me put my mouth where you potty boo after these moments the album returns back to that production that feels very refined its melodic it's chill it's sweet on the ears but on the track acid rain though chance is getting really nostalgic in his lyrics it just feels like there are too many moments on this track where he's grasping for something to struggle over personally and the closer was really the best thing the end of this album had to offer overall I didn't really dislike this mixtape I thought I was really likable and I liked the personality that chance brought to the table and a lot of the hooks on the first half of this LP for sure there is reason to celebrate chances growing popularity because he is certainly different than your average ignorant Trapp rapper but with a lot of the things that he says in his lyrics I don't really feel like he's a breath of fresh air or anything like that because lyrically he doesn't really come off as enlightened or as progressive as one would assume just by listening to his out-there persona I guess there are just a lot of moments where he lets hooks beats and his ad-libs carry his songs from beginning to end there are these spots on this album where he feels like nothing more than a goofy acid dropping cartoon character who is way too jittery and unfocused to drop some lines that would really sort of widen some eyes and surprise some people when it comes to some of the serious topics that he attempts to tackle on some of these tracks overall I'm feeling a decent two strong six on this tape if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it Anthony Fantana chance the rapper forever you you

savages silent yourself ah hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new savages LP silence yourself savages is a UK post-punk band and this debut album of theirs they have landed a release for on Matador Records off the back of a very strong single flying to Berlin slash husbands the band put out some pretty impressive live recordings of their stuff last year as well and the band's sound has a very authentic retro post-punk vibe to it but it's very clear that the album we're dealing with here could have only been made today there's a very modern volume and brightness to the recording on this album and the band does a great job of mashing together some of the best ideas in the genre savages clearly works with a bird eye view of this musical era because they're able to appreciate the eccentricities and the aggression of a band like the liver the raincoats or the fast paces and the moodiness of some of the best tracks to come out from Joy Division in Bauhaus the vibrato of the band's lead singer Jenny Beth may make a Siouxsie Sioux comparison very easy on this record but savages show very little of the pop appeal that Suzy would show on some of her and her band's later records on silence yourself if anything the band is pulling more from Suzy's earlier more Punk driven stuff I could go on and on about the influences on this record however influences are not really a need to know you don't need a bachelor's degree in post-punk to enjoy or get this record because the biggest thing this record has going for it is that a rock driving bass lines guitars that blare out into the night with a really sharp tone and are emphasized with reverb pounding drums and Jenny's vocals atop all of it which just raises the energy level of these songs higher now among the 38 minutes or so of music that savages lays onto this LP there are some surprises namely tracks like hit me which are incredibly noisy and chaotic the guitars and the drums come together into this thick thick mess of sound that kind of reminds me of like an Ice Age record and on this track jenny has some really nasty just swagger to her vocals or the track waiting for a sign which is very spaced out slow and dismal or the piano like closing track on this LP where Jenny's vocals turned from a shriek to a beautiful Kroon and the transition is really nice the piano isn't stuck playing the same dumb progression the whole time there are some flourishes there there are some little changes little additions that are nice keep the track engaging of course Jenny's vocals her lyrics are very dramatic on this song and surprisingly there is like a jazz bass clarinet solo on the tail end of this thing that goes over pretty well as well the song dead nature is a bit of an oddball on this thing as well as kind of an intermission that separates one half of the album from the other half but the rest of this LP is just brash hard-hitting post-punk body moving beats coming from the drums guitar leads that burn themselves into the eardrums this record sounds like the world is on fire and this record is the only thing that could put the fire out open up your windows play this album and let every neighborhood America hear this and this feeling is partially due to the incredible urgency that savages delivers on some of these tracks with things like their tightness on tracks like she will as well as this new re-recorded version of the song husbands the band is just they do not miss a beat they are just a well-oiled post-punk Machine muscular playing on this thing the instrumental side of these songs is just really really impressive from just catchy melodies to just hard-hitting riffs but the vocals and lyrics really enhance these tracks with subject matters and poetry that can be kind of a widening and disturbing abstract song I am here is a bold statement about the existence of oneself and it is said with no fear and these lyrics are backed up with guitars that are so loud they cannot be ignored the riff on the course this thing actually sort of little bit my Queens of the Stone Age the song city's full of has it's really driving hook just guitars propelling this chorus in the tale that's being told in the track is one of love dancing lust jenny is sort of describing the wrinkled eyes and the stretch marks of her love interest and the song no face is an awesome statement of somebody who basically copycats their personality from really anywhere they can desperately grab it and lyrically the song she will is an exploration of femininity sexuality desire songs melody though it's eerily similar to Joy Division's level tear us apart the song Striped has this great slithering guitar lead and this totally lip biting groove to it I will say that this is maybe one of my least favorite parts on the LP though because of the chorus which feels kind of flaccid the guitar phrasing and the vocals aren't as sharp here as they are on many other spots on this LP overall downsides with this album there aren't many there are some tracks that I just don't love as much as others but if there is sort of a nitpick that I have there are tracks on this album where Jenny vocally lyrically comes across with a very direct direct statement and I'm just saying there are moments where what she's saying feels so esoteric I just really can't make heads or tails of it but beyond that the energy is stellar the songwriting is really great the structure on these tracks is solid they're very straightforward they're hard-hitting and yet they have Peaks they have valleys they have different pieces to them the production is freakin top-notch think about it if you've given it a listen what did you think of it did you love it did you hate it why what do you think I should review next and yeah that's about it Anthony Fantana savages forever [Music] you

the hexan hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new hacks and cloak LP excavation this is the sophomore full-length LP from this uk-based musical project its self-titled full-length album came out in 2011 this new record is out now on triangle records a label that specializes in the dark the moody the atmospheric through artists like Balam akka as well as clams casino avian Christ even vessel whose last full-length LP I reviewed pretty recently and the label is kind of picky only choosing a handful of different artists for its roster and all of them sort of bringing their own unique brand or flair to these moods these vibes that the label sort of specializes in and certainly the haxon cloak has no problems meeting these needs on this new full-length album just look at the title if this album is an excavation certainly the accent cloak gets very low it gets subterranean I haven't heard electronic music or at least electronically tinged music this frightening since some of lust mort's best albums I also would not be surprised if the Hexen cloak took a lot of influence from horror movie soundtracks on this LP and I don't just mean the music that may be composed for a horror movie soundtrack I'm talking about like the gargantuan bass hits and the very sharp jump out in your face noises that appear in about every modern horror movie trailer this is essentially the opening track of this album in a nutshell like I said earlier this album is essentially dark ambient music it lasts for about an hour stretched across nine tracks a lot of the tracks on this LP are incredibly vast and tall and wide thanks to the incredible reverb that the accent cloak employs on this album but many of the songs are beat driven as well which does give these tracks pace does give them direction a lot of the tracks on this LP though don't really rise in a way that is traditionally exciting in music the accent cloak kind of prefers to hang down in the deep bassy murk of low end frequencies this album is so dark at times you can even see your end front of your face which is also a description I threw at the vessel album that I also reviewed on triangle records but the Hexen cloak is much more obsessed with low frequencies than high creating rumbles creating fuzz a physical experience with the music that feeling definitely comes through on parts one and two of the title track on this LP the first of which features all these sputtering clicking very busy electronics matched up against some very eerie and bacey atmosphere tones the second part of this title track has all these kind of metallic waves of sound repeating and just cycling over and over and over it's like an industrial anaconda and the song eventually gives away to some very beautiful synthesizer arpeggios the accent cloaks sort of tossing very sparse moments of beauty at the listener matched up with just this grimness the horror movie sound play gets intensified on the next two tracks of the selkies starting with Mara these massive drum hits and I mean massive are pulsating throughout the track huge piano hits on the song as well from the low end of the pitch spectrum and these wailing strings coming like the strings creep like drips of blood coming down the wall of the horrible torture chamber that all these sounds are clearly coming from the song leaps right into the track mist which starts off with a voice that literally jumps out at the listener like a knife-wielding psycho the song has this dragging double bass line it sounds like a horrible fog lurching out from some kind of creepy forest and the way the vocal that popped up right at the start of this track is edited and placed throughout the song in this sort of skippy strange way it's kind of creative odd and very memorable there is more appeal to this LP though than being completely creeped out though being creeped out will be the most obvious reaction to have when listening to this but let me say this if the sounds on this album weren't crafted amazingly well and if the songs weren't sort of built and pasted in a way that kept them engaging and interesting these creepy feelings wouldn't necessarily even come about in the first place it's the very last song on this album it feels kind of like a legitimate change of pace this synth melody comes through that is actually pretty serene and in comparison to a lot of the other stuff on this LP is kind of obliphica the song grows very dark and very cold over a slow period of time though the song is 12 freakin minutes long but as it gets darker and heavier with some very eerie strings and some double bass and a very heavy heavy bass drum the slow very basic and over the course of the song boring beat actually where's the songs welcome out really fast the song slowly decays into staleness over its 12-minute run time unfortunately the most obvious downsides to this LP is that there are some moments that drag on and don't have an incredible amount of musical detail or just sonic detail in them it seems like the hacks and cloak gets more joy out of the space left than space filled which isn't necessarily a bad thing in and of itself certainly it helps along with the very potent and amazing vibe that is conjured on this album but it does keep some of these tracks from being engaging throughout on the flipside of this complaint there are some songs on here most notably the ones around the three-minute mark that just feel too short half-baked kind of underdeveloped like they could have gone on longer or evolved into something else still these problems only reflect a minority of tracks on this album as is this album is incredible when it comes to sound play and just pulling a very very strong emotional reaction from me there are moments where I do wish the sonic palette was a little wider and that the accent cloak found different sounds and different textures to sort of bring more variety and that the structures and the rhythms behind these tracks weren't quite so basic but man is this album like an experience I'm feeling a strong 7 to a light 8 on this LP if you've given it a listen what do you think of it do you love it hate it why what do you think I should review next and that's it the haxon cloak excavation forever [Music] [Music]

Jenny haha innocence is kinky hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the Internet's busiest music nerd and it's time for a review of the new Jenny Havel album innocence is kinky Carol Cheech esta spoken poem pistachio pistachio green green bean PAP tamale I'm sweat well Jenny caval is a norwegian singer songwriter and this is her sophomore full-length LP under her own name previous to the release of albums under the name jenny of all she was putting out music under the name rocket to the sky she's had other musical projects as well she is also a writer an occasional music reviewer a jack of many trades of Jenny now Jenny's last full-length album a few years ago viscera does deliver what the album title suggests to an extent it's kind of a singer-songwriter affair very powerful emotive vocals instrumentation that occasionally is climactic growing and growing and growing as the song progresses but still a little toned down in comparison to summer for rocket to the sky stuff on this new LP of hers innocence is kinky and boy is it spanking jenny has gained a somewhat spontaneous edge the songs on this new LP overall are shorter follow a very linear surprising kind of jagged unpredictable structure there are more noises and effects employed on this new LP and overall Jenny does cover a slightly larger genre bass like on our previous LP there is spoken word on this new album but I would say Jenny relies on it a lot more it's almost as if that eclectic kind of confident side of her music that was very prevalent in rocket to the sky has returned on this new album but with much more impressive production which is brought to the table by John parish PJ Harvey's producer who most recently worked with her on her fantastically huge album let England shake now if you're sad to see Jenny's more straight forward side go on this new album innocence as kinky might not appeal to you exactly there are a lot of tracks here that suffer from abrupt ends there are songs right next to each other or motifs that have a completely different vibe than the song that they follow in the song that they precede there are some sudden shifts and instrumentation as well that are interesting but I can't help but feel like some of the discord that Jenny drums up on this LP is made to throw the listener off of the breadcrumb trail of very obvious influences for one PJ Harvey and a lot of her spoken word moments just breathe Kate Bush's fifty words for snow which aren't bad influences to have or wear on your sleeve it's just that as I listen to the album more and more the novelty of how disjointed this album feels wears off and then not much is is left over in terms of tune or songwriting to keep me there and keep me engaged and keep me returning to this album how disjointed this album is can sometimes feel like assembling a thousand-piece puzzle but without knowing a tenth of the pieces on this album are missing still a great deal of the parts that have all has left on this album are very enjoyable and range from being hauntingly beautiful to twisted - even uncompromising interestingly enough a Vols refusal to blend many of her ideas together on this album actually keeps her from being completely in the shadow of her influences most definitely on this album the production brought by John parish is kind of a double-edged sword as beautiful and as detailed and as textured and is well put together it is and many times on here there are a ton of spots that just sound very much like instrumental flourishes from let England shake and while Jenny just like PJ on letting gland shake has a strong narrative voice there are a lot of parts where she instead comes off as very cerebral abstract sexual a bit of spoken word on the opening track with the self he delves intimately into a late-night session with some online porn the synth and drum groove that pulsate against the spoken word and eventually roll the track into a full-blown song is met with a very sharp jagged guitar lead that just lurches and creeps forward feels very nocturnal and kind of dirty just like the words that Jenny is laying against this music there are moments where she's just belting and calling out within her high range and other spots where she just really tones her voice down and coos very softly her Ange of pitch and emotion is really one of the most impressive things that this album has to offer especially when on this track and the song right after it she's going through this weird thing with the song I called those a very sort of loud and catchy change of pace with its constant snare drum a sort of paces itself out like it's a 60s pop tune with some guitar arpeggios that feel like they're coming from sort of the same field of range but totally panned over in the right channel is this screaming noisy chaotic guitar playing not only is this totally just mucking up the vibe and a kind of exciting and noisy and just destructive way but Jenny's voice goes from being very high and sort of bright to being completely tired and depressing like she's having this sort of schizophrenic episode right in the middle of the song on the other side of the spectrum Renee Falcon Eddie of Orleans on the next track has more of these coud narrations matched up with sort of knife style vocal effects that call out very eerily emotionally the vocals feel really passionate they're backed up with some throbbing electronics and while it is a really cool combination of influences and ideas that I applaud Jenny for there's nothing here in terms of an interesting song structure or tune the song really kind of feels like it bumbles around just tossing together some concepts that might have been interesting I do like the track is there anything on me that doesn't speak because it does get more and more intense as it goes along and the song amphibious androgynous is another very cohesive track on this album actually tells a pretty clear story from beginning to end with Jenny falling in love with this stick man and literally he is made of sticks and she's having a difficult time because of their mismatching physicalities loving him kissing him a lot like how
